review_text: Want a real wild ride? Get the Luke Ross mod and play this thing in VR, its amazing

Despite the issues with bugs and glitches, I adore this game. The story is great and the side quests often surprised me with how detailed they were. When I could slip into a side quest and it felt like it was a main quest of its own with a few branching secondary quests, thats when I fall in love with a world's lore. The fact that Pondsmith does voice over for a radio station also makes me feel as if the Game master of this vast campaign is letting us in on the deeper sectrets of the world as he starts arranging the next part of the story. Its the small details like that that really make this one of my new favorite games. The game has tons of issues, from grindy crafting that takes too long to buggy vehicle physics that pull me out of this wonderfully immersive world. those are what some will feel like great let downs in this gem of a game. Those issues make this a diamond in the rough until CDPR fixes and improves those glaring problems.
I am running above the recommended specs and can only get 45 fps on low quality graphics. Once the game is fixed I'll re-evaluate

10/28/23 Update:
Decided to try this game out again after phantom liberty came out due to a friends suggestion and i gotta say, WOW. What a complete difference from the mess that this game was when it first came out!

Ive beat the game again and played through the expansion, and my experience this time was much much better. In my original review, i complained about not needing the hacking all that much.. but in retro spec that was really up to me since this game allows so many different ways to be played. Wanna be a shoot and run? go for it. Hack everyone and everything? No problem. This time around, i played with the focus of hacking and i had a lot of fun with it. 

Story is great, game play is great. Im changing my review, and i'd recommend this game for sure. 


AMD Ryzen 5 3600
32 GB Ram
RTX 2060 Super

I played the game on Normal.

For 60 dollars, I do NOT recommend this game.
For 30 dollars, pick it up, but expect bugs.

With that said, I cant stop talking about this game to my friends. 

34 Hours in, and i've beat the game. From what i understand, there are multiple endings to this game, and I've seen one of them so far. Honestly, I'm not a fan of how my story ended, and thankfully when you beat the game... they allow you to load your last save before the ending so you can pick an alternative timeline. Other endings are unlocked by doing side missions.

Let me just say, when it comes to suggesting this game or not suggesting this game, its close. I had a lot of fun with this game. With that said, there are a number of bugs.. some game breaking. If you haven't already, you absolutely need to download gpu drivers. They fix a lot of visual bugs. 

[Visuals : 5/5] Visually, it looks fantastic. A large  open world with tons of unique buildings, stuctures, and scenery. That[ alone is in my opinion, the best part of the game. I had a lot of fun with photo mode, and just taking in the sights. I truly did feel like I was there.

[Story 4/5] The story comes in a close second. Fantastic story, believable characters, and i found myself having a few "feels" when certain events happen (your my boy jackie). However, i will say that at certain times.. i did feel a little lost in the story. Especially at the beginning. They dont tell you a whole lot, and they expect you to care about characters that obviously your guy would care about in real life,but as a player.. im left wondering "wait, who is this again?" 

Ever watch the move 8mm? Its a great movie. This game reminded me a lot of that movie, except for searching for a woman on a tape.. i'm trying to find someone to help me with the chip in my head. However, go to sex shop 1 to see so and so. then go to bar 2 to see so and so. Then go to club 1 to see so and so, then go to sex shop 2 to see so and so. You get the point. For a world as massive as this, i feel they repeated a lot of the places you went to was just another variation of the place you just left. Cool places, dont get me wrong, but i feel like they could of varied it a bit more. 

Gameplay [3/5] In this section, im going to cover most of the game. I felt the visuals and the story needed a seperate category, but everything else can be summorized under gameplay. Again, the game is fun. However, like everyones been saying.. there are a number of bugs. Some bugs i personally experienced...

1. Camera getting stuck
2. Weapons cant be drawn (restart didnt work, had to get to next cutscene to fix)
3. Falling through the map (had to restart)
4. Enemies glitch/clip through object
5. Unable to exit the vehicle (had to restart)
6. Bosses bugging out and freezing, making fights easy.
7. Unable to change camera views while driving
8. Gigs glitching out, unable to complete.

I had to restart the game a number of times while playing in order to get around game crashing bugs.  I cant remember the last time i payed 60 bucks for a game, and had this many issues. 

But lets forget about the bugs for a moment. Without spoiling the game, i'm going to touch on a few things here that others have stated. In no particular order...

1. Police AI does not exist.  If you kill a civilian or a cop, expect to die within a few second. Yes, I know this game isn't GTA, but something in the middle would of been great. Cant tell you how many times ive run people over by mistake trying to take a corner, just to have a crime reported and cops spawn right next to you to put a bullet into your dome. Try to drive away, and the cops become kobe, and lob grenades. Bottom line... if your not killing a gang member, or on a mission that specifically says to attack someone, expect to get attacked pretty quickly and die. For a dystopian world filled with crime, the cops respond very quickly. This is a huge immersive breaking issue in my opinion, and would bring me out of the game every single time it happened. 

2. Player clothing / stats is horrible. Hope you dont mind wearing a bra and a dress. For some reason, those 2 items might have better stats than what you currently have. I played as a male character, and at the end, i was wearing a hood, with a gas mask, a long trench coat, a pair of blue shorts, and a pair of dress shoes. Why? Cause they had the best stats. Thank god this game isn't third person, cause i must of looked insane. 

3. Hacking is a cool feature in the game. I would argue that most of the time its not needed though. However, because i didnt use the upgrade system much, there are probably a number of hacks i didnt use. However, i beat the game without hacking except for a handful of times, and even during those times, it was just to do something different.

Overall, the game just feels unfinished. I was not a hyped up fan boy, and i picked it up because it finally dropped and i said f it, lets give it a go. With that said, i wasnt expecting some amazing game like a lot of people were, but i can understand why people are frusterated. As of writing this right now, sony has pulled the game from the store due to the massive amount of bugs. After completing the game, i do want to go back and check out some of the other endings, but i estimate i have about another 5 - 10 hours of enjoyment from this game before i uninstall it (or at least forget about it).

Update :: I've since spent some more time playing side missions and im still enjoying the game. I will admit though, everytime i get to a point where im like, "you know what.. this game isnt that bad, i should edit my review" then BAM... gotta restart due to some weird shit. LOL.  When i see weird graphical stuff, i just say to myself "ah, its just v's optics messing up"
Review_Angles: Post-Launch Improvements, Gameplay Versatility, Narrative Quality

review_text:
Editing this review for the time being. The game has gone through a lot of bugfixing now and finally feels fairly stable. The NPCs are still bland, but cars now see the enemy as a passable collision and drive around you. Cops spawn further away making it seem like they react to a crime rather than just teleporting to you. 

The game has its bright sides (namely story and graphics, especially if you play with RayTracing), but the downsides still don't justify full AAA price IMO. The AI is bland, the gameplay is just okay and the open world feels entirely lackluster. At some point during the game, you turn into an unstoppable powerhouse that one-hits every enemy. Harder difficulty merely increases damage output by enemy AI, they can now one-shot you. Not a fun way to balance fights. 

Speaking of balanced fights, f*ck the fist fight missions on anything above normal difficulty. The melee combat feels wonky and sluggish at best and unfair at worst. The enemy slides across the room as if magnetically drawn to you, he one-hits you, you need 100 hits in on him. Blocking and dashing doesn't guarantee damage reduction. 

There is no point in driving around except to get to a (albeit sometimes well designed) job contract. Empty streets, local vendors ignore you or say the same, uninspired line every NPC has in offer for you: 'Go away.' 'What a nice day!' 'What a lazy way to implement AI interaction!'.

Making choices throughout the story only has an impact on the mission that follows immediately afterwards. After said mission, the choice you made will now be forgotten by everyone. Street credit does not exist, not street gang member ever mentions your name, your reputation or any of that. 

All that being said, and I forgot a ton, the story still has great moments and lovable characters. The game just isn't worth full price at the moment. Get it for 20-30 bucks at most, if you can.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Balance, Consumer Value

review_text:
This game has by far the most beautiful and immersive world in any game or piece of media i've ever seen. 
There will be plenty of other reviews talking about the gameplay and performance, but man the world, what a sight to behold.

The people walking by, the ads, music, graffiti, authorities speaking through PAs to the city and just breathtaking views of a massive corporate fortress everywhere you go. The political and actual setting of Cyberpunk 2077 is absolutely fascinating.

Seriously, I havent even fast travelled once yet, in fact most of the time I dont even drive. Simply walking through the city is an experience worthy of the price all on its own.
Review_Angles: Immersive World, Atmospheric Setting, Exploration Value

review_text:
So, this is definitely an interesting game for a number of reasons, most of them good. 

Overall: There is an immense amount of detail in this game, from the characters to every corner of the game world around you. I find myself getting lost in just walking around the city and enjoying the sights and sounds. There is a lot to do, especially as you progress through the game. It's almost like a cyberpunk gta in the best way possible.

Performance: For some reference performance wise, It's no secret that as of right now the game has a lot of bugs, but from my experience none of them are game breaking, more of them are the type that make you laugh, honestly. I currently play with a nvidia 1660 ti with a ryzen 5 3500, so no ultra settings for me, but It still runs very smoothly from my experience. The game has not crashed on me after 30 hours of play so far. Even on just high settings this game is visually stunning, a lot of that has to do with the theme and the source material. I highly recommend looking into the old rpg from 1988 that this world is based from for reference.

Gameplay: This is a very dialogue and story heavy game, yes there is a good amount of combat encounters, and the shooting mechanics feel very good and well thought out but don't expect to be getting into a gunfight every 10 minutes. Although when they do happen, boy does it feel good so it's worth it.

Verdict: Personally I absolutely have been enjoying this game and it was worth the 8ish years worth of development to wait. I can not say it's perfect, or that it will please you personally, but if you enjoy this type of theme or are just looking for a immense game world to immerse yourself in, this is a very good one. 

Side note: Like I said previously, at the moment it is pretty buggy, but not game breaking. Regardless, if that is something that would really bother you, I would wait for a few months for major updates.

Sailed the seven seas to play at launch, was impressed enough to buy it then put nearly 200 hours into it. i am happy to see it come back with Edgerunners pulling in new fans.

Story is neat, Corpo backstory is probably my favorite with Streetkid being a close second. 

Modding support is huge! all your issues can be addressed via mods NG+, Models, and even new content.

Games a solid 8.5/10 even with the odd slang, choom.
Review_Angles: Narrative Quality, Modding Support, Personal Value

It's just not that compelling for the asking price.

Dialogue is well written, but the plot itself is pretty dull so far, don't feel like any dialogue choices I'm making are having a perceptible impact on the game. The characters are likeable and distinct from one another, so that's good. The open-world aspect seems like set-dressing since very little of it seems to be meaningfully interactive. 

At least on hard difficulty, the combat is a clunky mess of damage sponges that don't pose much of a threat. It's reminding me a lot of Fallout 3 combat, and that's definitely not a good thing. There are options for stealth/quickhacking but they don't really feel necessary when shooting people in the face works extremely well.

So far gear is boring. It's a bizarre choice to have clothing be strictly-better on armour values. If you want to not turn into a puddle in combat you'll need to equip the 130 armour fedora and cargo shorts, sorry. The perks seem kind of cool until you realise they're interacting with a combat system that's baseline boring and has you up against relatively braindead AI. 

To top it off, the framerate is all over the place and the graphics presets don't seem to adjust the fact that performance is erratic despite GPU utilisation being inexplicably low. [Yes, I updated my drivers :-)] Sure, the game looks pretty good, but, it doesn't look good enough to explain whatsoever the insanely bad performance. Lots of visual bugs, but those are the least of your worries.

review_text:
Pre 2.1:

Alright, listen up, choombas! This game had all the hype, all the expectations, and let me tell you, it delivered in some ways, but fell short in others.

First off, Night City. This place is a damn masterpiece. The neon-soaked streets, the towering skyscrapers, the gritty back alleys - it's everything you'd expect from a cyberpunk world. The atmosphere is spot on, and it truly feels like you're living in a dystopian future.

Now, let's talk about the story. CD Projekt Red tried to weave an epic tale of rebellion and corporate greed, and they did a decent job. But there were moments where the pacing felt off, and some plot lines didn't get the attention they deserved. It's like they tried to cram too much into one game, and it suffered because of it.

Gameplay-wise, it's a mixed bag. The gunfights are intense, the hacking mechanics are solid, and the character customization is top-notch. But there were some bugs, glitches, and AI issues that took away from the overall experience. It's like trying to jack into the Net with a faulty interface - frustrating as hell.

Look, Cyberpunk 2077 had the potential to be a game-changer, a true legend in the gaming world. And while it falls short in some areas, it still manages to capture the essence of the cyberpunk genre. It's a flawed gem, but a gem nonetheless.

So, if you're willing to overlook some rough edges and dive headfirst into Night City, give Cyberpunk 2077 a shot. Just remember, it's not perfect. Stay rebellious, chooms!

review_text:
Cyber Punk is an amazing game! At first it didn't grip me til I got more into the story and figured how to play the game. I know a lot of people rant about how broken the game is, but I didn't have many problems through my play through. Occasionally there would be funny glitches like Johnny Silverhand's cigarette would be floating in mid air while he's talking, dead people would have one leg up in the air, and at times the lips wouldn't sync up to the dialogue. There have been a few patches since I bought the game, and the game seems to run much smoother since. Not that I had any major problems in the beginning anyway. So this game is very story rich, and the action is great as well. It took some getting used to using the cyber attacks instead of  always the guns. Unlike in a lot of games where you have a bunch of throw away characters, this game has characters that you build a relationship with and tend to legit care about. You also can control how you talk to the characters, whether you want to be nice or a straight up jerk. Keep in mind, how you treat people will affect the ending. The game has really high replay value! You can choose between three life paths: Nomad, Street Punk, or Corpo. I started with Street Punk, and just put 34 hours into completing the 
 story, and I still didn't complete everything, so you won't have to worry about it being a short game. Trust me! I played the game using a RX 5700 XT,  Ryzen 7 3700x, 1440p monitor. I had settings set to high with a couple of things switched to medium, which kept my FPS between 50-60.  I know its not a Nvidia 2000 or 3000 series like they recommended, but the game looked amazing to me anyway. If you love story rich, FPS, RPG, immersive , action adventure, then you should get this game.

Awesome game.. awesome story.. thank god for quicksave though; there are currently numerous bugs in the game that will result in your character's very unexpected and frustrating demise. So, yeah the game's autosave/quicksave will end up being your best friend at times.

This game *in it's current state* is  riddled with bugs and glitches that will frustrate a great number of players. But at the end of the day, your still getting a game with extremely complex story structure and character-building, and an open-world exploration experience like no-other. 

Despite the bugs;
Great F#cking Game.

review_text: masterclass in storytelling, every time i beat the game i don't feel a real human emotion for like 3 days. I might put it down for a few months at a time but I always end up coming back, this game and this story has so much to offer, not to mention that phantom liberty is incredible

Are there some things that could have been more polished on release? Sure, but are the bugs or graphic issues on par or in some cases even less noticeable with a lot of other triple A titles, yes. Now you might comment on how long we waited for this game, and that is a fair point. But, at the end of the day this is still a video game. It doesn't matter if it take 1, 8, or 20 years to make, I'm sure that it will always come out with bugs that's what happens when you are consistently developing. People are acting like we waited 8 years and got another Duke Nukem Forever. Do I wish that it had been more polished, yes, but am I also glad to finally be able to play a game I've been waiting almost a decade for absolutely. I have enjoyed my almost 10 hours thus far and look forward to the future. See you in Night City.
Review_Angles: Technical Polish, Development Wait, Personal Enjoyment

review_text:
I came to the game late, only picking it up a few weeks (a year after launch).  I had low expectations based on what I'd seen online about the game.  However, I thoroughly enjoyed the story and side quests.  I thought the game's aesthetic was spot on for a Cyberpunk world.  I have only done one play through, but that was well worth the money. 

I did encounter a few bugs on PC, but nothing game breaking.  I had one crash to desktop, some stuck bars / text of prior conversations, and a few glitchy scanning issues.  Otherwise, I didn't notice any other major technical issues.

Combat is fun and diverse.  The ability to play as a netrunner, tech weapons wielder, stealth class, regular weapons, or melee class (or combinations of the above) was really fun.  A sneaky netrunner with a silenced pistol made for fun combat to me.

I did not really care for a lot of travelling, the vehicle system was a tad tedious for my tastes.  Otherwise a really good game, and provided around 50 hours of good quest content, with some follow-on time to grind experience to complete my build.
Review_Angles: Narrative Quality, Technical Stability, Combat Variety

review_text:
Running with 0 issues @ 4k on my system (RT is OFF, though), average 55 FPS is decent. Only encountered 2 "game breaking" bugs so far, both were easily fixed with a Re-Load. 

Immersion is amazing, the end of ACTI blew my mind. Haven't played beyond that point yet, but it is an amazing experience so far.

When this games gets a proper update, I'll adjust this review accordingly.

This game, in terms of substance, is brilliant, super vivid world with memorable characters. In time, I'm confident it will live up to the legacy of Witcher 3.

Before I say more, I take my time with RPGs like this. Meaning I spent the vast majority of my playtime doing side quests, and in this game that can help you a ton in the main quest line. 

Side quests are unfortunately bugged to hell and back. I currently have several side quests marked in my journal as unfinished despite me having completed all objectives. I have overlooked nothing, these quests are bugged. I cannot track them and I do not have any unfinished objectives. I am a spastic reloader playing a stealth netrunner. It seems reloading a save makes the current mission in progress less stable and is likely why I have so many of them bugged out.

One or two broken side quests would be fine, but four is too many. Game really feels like beta testing sometimes.
Review_Angles: Narrative Quality, Technical Stability, Side Quest Integration

Cyberpunk 2077, a vision of the future where greed corruption and hedonism reach an apex. You play as V, a merc of the city with a dream of being a legend of night city by either dying in a blaze of glory, or with a whimper. Its your choice.

Developed by CD Project Red Cyberpunk 2077 launched in a failed state, with massive technical issues and wasn't feature complete, Fast forward nearly 3 years and Cyberpunk 2077 has pulled 180! With multiple large patches fixing the majority of bugs, adding secrets, a gameplay overhaul, vehicle combat, and additional mission content. The transformation from launch to now is Night and Day.

Night City is truly an immersive experience, with a scale and density that I've never seen in any game. Then combine the visual splendor of night city with downright the best selection of radio and synth based scores I've ever had the pleasure of hearing in any game. And you've got a title that is not only immersive but truly captivating. That not even to mention the story, which might just be the crown on top Cyberpunks experience.

Lets touch on that for a brief period. Before release we were promised a certain type of "web of branching mission paths" based on choices, and at release that's what a large portion of the player base was expecting. We did not receive this experience, instead we got a more straight forward story experience with about 7 different endings base of a final choice. Phantom Liberty does rectify this with a point where you get completely new content depending on choices you make, and I truly think that the base game would've benefited from a system like this. However the story that is currently in the game is fantastic and leaves a decent amount of player choice. Especially how this story concludes based of relationships made while completing the main and side content. 

Overall Cyberpunk is in my top 5 games of all time. The setting, story, music, gameplay all fit my tastes, And I am very happy that with the final updates coming in, Cyberpunk is now in a place past where I visioned it on release. That not to mention Phantom Liberty, which might just be my new favorite DLC CD Project Red has made. 10/10 Breathtaking.

Never Fade Away.

[h1] Yes, it's playable now.[/h1]

Just for better context, here's my setup:

[list]
 [*]AMD Ryzen 3 2200G
 [*]Asus Prime A320m-K/BR
 [*]16 GBs of RAM over two 8 GB sticks
 [*]NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2060 Super
[/list]

Notes on performance through the 60 hours I played:

It ran very stable on Ultra(without Ray Tracing) throughout most of the time, though when in the city itself your frames may drop a little. In the Badlands, it usually ran at 60 frames. Some minor bugs here and there, particurly texture pop in. However, two things of note and how to get rid of them.

[olist]
 [*]The game sometimes would take forever to save, as in, the next sections would not load due to the game trying to save and not managing to do it. To fix that, I went on the settings of the game itself and disable cloud saves. That fixed and it never happened again.
[*]When I was doing something else with my computer, the game ran notably worse, so if you see some drop in perfomance, you might want to pause downloads and other things to focus only the game. 
[/olist]

My thoughts on the game itself are: if it had came out on a stable state at launch, it would very easily run for Game of the Year. So if you think your rig is good enough, go ahead and have fun, choom.

I've been in many virtual worlds including both game worlds and social worlds and I have to say Cyberpunk 2077 is one of the most interesting I've been in. There are lots of really interesting characters, places to visit and discover, and missions to complete. You really do feel like you are in another world.

I think i'm recommending this game because I feel I NEED to!  I've been a fan of this genera of game for decades.  Love the feeling and love the vibe.  But for Christ sake why does every game I ever play "feel" the same?  Seriously...
There's this really strange feeling I have playing it where I swear I feel like i'm playing Skyrim only in the future.  Maybe It's Braindead Jackie then endlessly gets in the way. Maybe it's the glitches(that began happening in the first 5 mins of my experience)  Maybe it's the random npc's that, if you follow one of them, will just all of the sudden disapear in the middle of the street.  Like actually just pop out.  That's all Skyrim stuff.
Is it beautiful?  Yeah.  It is.  Nothing limit pushing or groundbreaking or unique.  It's new.  Never saw a big ass city like this before.  That's cool.  But I never saw big ass mountains before Skyrim either and I wouldn't have said that it was groundbreaking either.  
I don't know what I expected.  So much damn hype and so much damn expectation that I placed on it.
At the end of the day, it's a good game.  I'm enjoying it.  I'll p lay thru the main story and see where I'm at when it's over.  Honestly though, one play thru and I think i'll be ready for something else.  
Good game but yeah...
Review_Angles: Originality and Feel, Technical Stability, Visual Aesthetics

review_text:
I bought the game a year and half after its release so a lot of the bugs had been fixed. I am a big fan of the cyberpunk genre and played many of the classics like System shock, Bio Shock, Prey and Deus Ex.  Cyberpunk is a lovely game. I highly recommended it if you are a fan of the genre. I do wish CD project had taken its time and delivered a finish product and avoid the bad rep and drama.  

Cyberpunk does feel like a real world.  The architecture and level design is amazing.  The buildings make sense unlike most video games. Night City feels like a real city with all sorts of stores, neighborhoods and peoples. The story lines are interesting and engaging.  The characters are complex. 

My only complains are that many talents in the talent tree feel underpowered. Also, driving a car is rather annoying and the map doesn't seem to mark vendors. 

If you are a fan of the Cyberpunk genre. This game is a must.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, World Immersion, Narrative Quality

review_text:
I was fortunate enough to not experience the issues that plagued the game at launch and waited a long time to start playing. 145+ hours and completed my first play-through. I can confidently say that Cyberpunk 2077 is not only a great game, but the epitome of creativity, storytelling, visuals, and pure experience.

The characters, to dialogue options, to combat, to moral choices, everything piles into a melting pot weighing on you as you press on in Night City. And if by any point of it all you still don't experience a wave of emotion... dust yourself off cuz you are dead.

Despite the bugs and lack of polish the game is actually really fun. My game hasn't crashed once though i know some people have had issues with that. There are plenty of activities to take part in so the game never really gets boring, with the addition of multiple ending makes it worth replaying, Big recommend if your PC can handle it
This game may have been a broken mess on release, but its great right now. They should really make the NPCs jump AWAY from your car though.

I don't get impressed easily.  But Cyberpunk 2077 truly impressed me.  It's one of the best PC gaming experiences I've ever had.

TL:DR - It's a great game. Get off the hypetrain and you won't get cucked again by a marketing department in the future.

After seeing the first announcement trailer and nearly wetting my pants at the idea of a futuristic witcher (futuritcher... whuture...) I immediately felt that familiar sting in my memory. The memory of the last hype train I rode to the end and was burned hot by an entirely good game because it hadn't lived up to the unattainable perfect game in my imagination. Never again was I going to pre-order. Never again was I going to put a game on a pedestal. I watched the gameplay trailers every month or so in the dry months but that was it. I had no expectations except more Witcher 3 and in the future. And it delivers.

Playing the game and then reading reviews referencing the hype-train content I can see that they really did slim down on their promises of something that was INSANE in it's scope that they definitely could have delivered with more time.

That said, going into it blind meant that it was the game I was expecting and I'm not even 20% of the way through and enjoying every second.
Review_Angles: Hype Expectations, Marketing Critique, Delivery Satisfaction

braindance tapes useless aside from main story ones, non-functional clubs/food vendors, pedestrians do nothing except tell you to fuck off or miraculously get hit by your car when you're 3 feet away from them, ai cars are on rails, car physics are done with low quality raycasting so there's no real suspension or anything, "police chases" entail about 3 ai cops spawning 5 feet IN FRONT of you because there's no car ai, not to mention how unplayable this game is without dlss at 1440p. the game also somehow manages to 100% max out my i7-6700k while in the city, with its impressive ai constantly telling me to fuck off. my cpu is relatively old, but the fact that the cars are literally on rails and the pedestrians have no real coding, the performance makes zero sense. also 75% of the times that i launched the game, the performance decreased by about 40% after a few hours, 95-100 fps at 1440p down to 50 fps for literally no reason. ram usage is normal, same with cpu, game just slowly runs worse over time. there were only 2 times that i had truly game breaking bugs where i had to restart: early in the game jackie got locked behind a door so i couldn't talk to him to continue, and in the last missions i offed multiple guards and 2 didn't count as dead, even though they were laying on the ground and lootable, so i had to restart the entire mission to continue. outside of those, i had a few cutscenes with missing dialogue, jackie walked straight through a wall, and one t-pose npc in freeroam. 

while this game has a lot of shit wrong with it, it's still a great game. the hype is what's really killing it, because the fact that it was hyped so hard amplifies how bad some of the bugs are. it should honestly be labeled early access because it's pretty obvious that it is. cut/unfinished content and awful optimization, i have no idea how anyone with a non-rtx card could even run this game since they don't have dlss. but if you have a very beefy pc, this game is worth it, otherwise just wait for a lot more optimization patches.
Review_Angles: Narrative, Open World Gameplay, Technical Performance

"Eh"

Before I start my tirade, I must say the overall visuals are fantastic. I've dreamed of being able to wander around a virtual city like this since I was a kid and, many years later, I'm now able to do it. Bugs? Sure. I've seen much worse. I won't comment on those; I haven't had many issues.

I was originally compelled to get on the hype train in large part because of the genre and The Witcher 3. I didn't realize that a lacking main story would be a huge problem, though. Here, the setup is you're some merc in a dystopia that gets the short end of the stick in a heist. The rest of it is about you trying to get this chip/shard out of your head that's going to kill you no matter what.

The side quests/"jobs" are great since it expands on something I really liked in The Witcher 3. However, after a while it starts to feel repetitive like Metal Gear Solid 5: just taking out one outpost after another. Shoot some more baddies, and move on. Some of the side jobs have a bit of substory to them but there aren't as many of them as I'd hope. Couple that with the main story of "hey, by the way, you're still dying" - it doesn't feel very satisfying to me.

I think the biggest killer for me - and this is me personally - is that it feels more a commentary on today's world than an escape. Megacorps as portrayed in the game don't exist, but they aren't entirely fiction either (Amazon, for instance, makes more money off its cloud services than it does selling goods; Google and Facebook have aggressively bought up other companies unrelated to their core product solely for the purpose of building personal profiles to market towards). While it's true that, this narrative exists in an entirely different reality than the one we live in, I think this past year and the years to come have and will start to resemble this paradigm of unrest, violence, and environmental disaster.

Over 30 hours on the cracked version and I finished almost all side quests and experienced 2 different endings so far, I'm planning to get every single one of them. When the DLC is gonna release....I'm gonna scream.

Ok, bit of context, I bought cyberpunk over the winter sale and I've played the game like a total of 75 ish hours.  I can't remember the last time I played a game this much and felt compelled to leave a review.  I didn't play cyberpunk when it released, so this may color my experience in a way that isn't the case for many who played on release.  I am laying this review out in terms of what I think is most important. 

specs: I am running a Ryzen 5 5600x and a GTX 1080

[b] THE BREAKDOWN (short N sweet) [/b] :
[b] -Graphics [/b] 
[b] -Audio [/b] 
[b] -Story [/b] 
[b] -Gameplay [/b] 
[b] -Bugs/Issues [/b] 


1) The graphics:  Visually this game is stunning, like you can literally just walk around Night City in awe of the beauty and size of it.  It feels massive and the atmosphere of the city is enticing and fun, like you want to be apart of it.  Truly, Night City is immersive and keeps your attention, it did mine.  Character models are pretty good, not hyper realistic 4k models, but they compliment the aesthetic and art style the city and/or game reflects.  Weapons look great, definitely better than the character models.  The in game cinematics are amazing, you can tell the Matrix is a huge influence on the game and they captured the vibe of it well.  Can't really say enough about the visuals in this game, definitely a highlight.
10/10

2) Audio:  The audio is are good, can't really complain about this too much.  Guns sound punchy, the samurai swords sound great, especially with the animation you get when you first pull them out.  Most of the sound design works for this game, the hacking noises, breaking bottles, and etc; all sound just fine.  When you zoom in, you'll notice they've drowned out outside noises and if you zoom in on a conversation it'll have this ting like your listening in from a wiretap.  A nice small detail.  It's really the music on the radio stations that didn't do it for me, mind you they aren't all bad, Edgerunners theme song is in there some where, but overall its nothing special.  Finally, the dialogue can be heard easily, haven't had to really listen in on a conversation.  Overall, I thought the sound design was pretty good.     
9/10

3) Story: The story is actually really good, something that I thought people really didn't touch much on from release and further YT reviews I've seen.  They get you to care about these characters in the game and your choices have consequences that affect you later.  Nothing groundbreaking about those statements by themselves, but its how its executed that made me enjoy it so much.  I maybe biased here, because the whole dystopian / cyberpunk future is really cool to me and I loved how they created this world and story for it.  Keanu did a great job I thought, although I wasn't crazy about Johnny Silverhands.  In lieu of spoiling things, I'll just say from gaming, this is one of the few stories that I reflected on and thought about.  It made me care about a fake world and pixels, which anytime art does that I think speaks volumes about it.  
10/10

4) Gameplay:  This is a big one, there's a lot to unpack in the gameplay, as the scope of it is ridiculous.  There is sooo much you can do in this game, there's the gunplay, the blades, special weapons like the mantis blades or monowire that give you so many play styles and ways to approach a given situation.  Gunplay is pretty standard in terms of modern gaming and isn't the best, but isn't terrible either.  There's the tech and hacking abilities you can deploy, which adds another level of dimension to the game.  Then there is the RPG aspect where you have perks you can add to your character building up your gun skills or hacking skills, you can craft items, change your clothes/style, and basically modify your character as you see fit.  Continuing on the builds there's cyberware which effectively give you superhuman abilities.  You can slow down time, hack everything, or doom slayer your way to victory.  It's got to be one of the most ambitious game's ever made for the sheer amount of things you can do and how you can do them.  
10/10

5) bugs/issues: I'm real late to this party of cyberpunk 2077, so I didn't (personally) see how buggy the game was at launch.  However, I am playing on a PC with a 1080 GTX and for the most part this game runs well.  I've mainly had lighting or flickering with lighting occasionally on this game.  Just restarting the game seems to fix it, but it is annoying and happens enough.  I've only see one T pose and a character sliding on the ground as opposed to walking.  The only weird bug that I have seen was in the prologue, I couldn't bring my weapons out for some reason and had to revert to a older save to fix this.  Only happened once, but ya.  Technical bugs were fairly minor playing on PC, but they do appear.  Lighting/flickering being the biggest issue for me; however, I'm sure everyone experiences this differently and I totally understand how last gen console players would basically be SOL playing this game. 

Now, I'm not sure if this should be in issues or gameplay, but I'll keep them separate for the review, the work around wasn't tied to the real gameplay.  Aiming, aiming is atrocious, I guess they are expecting you to be on KBM, but if you have a controller then pay attention.  You can get the aiming to be manageable through changing the settings in the game.  There are videos and guides on how so just Google them to find out and adjust to your comfort, it makes a huge difference.  Second issue is driving and holy shit, is it rough.  I can't imagine it was worse at launch, but prayers to the players that experienced that.  Like aiming, you can improve driving in the settings menu, but this doesn't work nearly as good as it does for aiming.  Honestly running and fast traveling seem to be a better option than driving, for the most part.  I'm not sure why its so bad, but it really is. For reference, I find driving in GTA: SA more intuitive and more functional than cyberpunk. This is by far, the worst aspect of cyberpunk 2077.  
5/10

**I've added mods into the game and some were for driving, this is necessary to do if you want to play a great game vs a decent game.  These are needed and also what I based my final score around.**

Final score (normalized): 8.8/10 
CP 2077 really is a great game (thanks to the mod community) and with sooo much potential.  After playing it, I see why development was like 9 years or whatever.  Frankly, it still needed time in the over at that too.  It does a lot of things well/pretty well and with the amount of freedom and scope it gives, its truly impressive from a technical standpoint that they got all this in the same game.  Easily one of the better games I've played in recent years, all things considered.  Its the bugs, settings, and driving mainly that hurts this game for me.  The bugs hopefully get worked out over the various patches (as I'm sure as been happening).  Fingers crossed that the driving mechanics get improved too.  Barring those problems, this would be a masterpiece and one to remember, one of the few single player games that offer real replay-ability to it as well.
Patient gamers stay winning
Pretty FUN

I honestly feel bad for the people mindlessly shitting on this game.
It's such a shame how the gaming community has progressed to be this toxic.
I've never been more engaged in a game than I have been these last 65 hours. I care about my character. I care about the characters around me. I care about the game's world.
There's just so much to love here. You could spend thousands of hours exploring every nook and cranny of Night City. Finding every choice, every route, every character build, and it would feel immensely satisfying.
I honestly couldn't recommend a game more.

Visuals
The game is (for lack of a better word) breathtaking. Honestly breathtaking.
I'm playing the game at mid settings and I couldn't be happier with the way it looks (and that's without ray-tracing). The wet roads of Night City provide and excellent canvas for the neon lights of signs and billboards to reflect. I could stop and look at this game for a very long time. The way light cascades around a location feels intoxicating. The shadows can be a little grainy at some points but it's not really an issue.
9.5/10

Level Design
Night City is packed. It's the densest game world I've ever seen. Everything is so detailed and meticulously thought through and (as previously stated) it's fucking gorgeous. Every district feels unique and every wrong alley turn could lead me to a possible crime scene or hidden market. Even the cultures present in Night City feel expertly realised.
10/10

Story
This is an important one. Stories have always been very important to me in terms of video games. This one has been no different. I haven't yet completed the game, but I can say without a doubt that I'm engaged as hell. It's a little slow near the beginning but once you get into the swing of things, it clicks.
Even the side quests are interesting. Unique as well. I'd probably say this game has the best side content I've seen in an open world. Some of the concepts for these quests are ridiculously insane and they're all the better for it.
8.5/10

Characters
They're real people. I've grown attached to them (I've cried for them). They are real people. I feel like I could practically touch them. This game has astounding levels of characterisation with fucking spot on voice acting. The writers knew what they were doing. They know how people's minds work.
There's so many characters to love, so many to hate. Most of all, I remember their names. Coming from someone that struggles to remember names in real life, I remember these people. They're memorable. I couldn't of asked for more in this category.
10/10

Gameplay
I feel like there's many ways to play this game. There's so many features and things to do. It can feel overwhelming, but you should just choose something. Go about it a step at a time.

Driving: Driving around Night City in the cars you have is fun. It's an amazing way to see the city and you get to listen to great music as you do so. It does feel a little slippery however. It depends on the vehicle, but turning at full speeds can send you going out of control (I've heard people call it boat-like which describes it pretty well). It's something you need to get used to. Bikes however, work great. I really love the attention to detail in how different cars control differently. This difference is even extended to wet weather or rough terrain. Each car is specially tailored to work a certain way on each environment. Despite sometimes losing control, it's never a big deal as your car always comes back fixed with no price (unless you blow it up which costs a small sum). 7/10

Shooting: I've heard some say the shooting mechanics feel clunky. Personally, I've not felt this issue as I've never been one for first person shooters. The shooting seems perfectly serviceable for me. The amount of weapons you can find is insane and there's light customisation involving scopes, muzzles, and mods that increase specific attributes. All weapons (and clothes, mods, etc) are in a tiered system with white, green, blue, purple, and gold indicating their rarity. I've had no trouble with these systems. 7.5/10

UI: The UI in this game is also pretty serviceable. It looks great, fits its purpose well, and is easy to navigate. There are a few quality of life improvements I'd like to see, such as being able to move a group of something with a singular key. Aside from small things like that, it's pretty good. 8/10

Dialogue: This is a big thing for me. I've never liked voiced protagonists in RPGs, but this game, has probably fixed my issues with them. Unlike in Fallout 4 where dialogue feels stilted (you choose an option, speak, they respond for a bit, you choose an option, etc) this game feels my character is having an actual conversation. You choose an option, and your character plus the person you're speaking to have an actual conversation (with your character sticking to the option you chose). This allows the main character to feel like their own person. You guide the basis of what he/she says but he says it in his own way. This is the best way I've ever seen a voiced protagonist work.
In terms of dialogue choices, there's no bullshit - no illusion of choice. The game tells you by the colour of dialogue whether what you've asked will move the conversation forward or whether its "filler". Blue text asks a question or adds context, and Yellow text continues the story in different directions and you can't go back to blue options. You can play the whole game without choosing a blue option, but it adds in lore and characterisation.
There's also dialogue checks in a similar vain to Fallout 3/Fallout: NV/Outer Worlds. These are based on your perk points which allows them to factor them into your character's dialect. It even has specific options for your chosen life path. This works wonders to make each play through unique.
Also, the game isn't limiting on how dialogue occurs. It's very free form. For example, you can walk around an area while speaking to an NPC as long as you don't move to far away. You can even speak to multiple characters at once, telling you which text will be said to which NPC.
Dialogue is one of my favourite parts of this game. 10/10

Issues:
There's no denying that this game has issues. It's pretty buggy at the moment with me encountering a minor bug every 20 mins, but it's constantly getting better. However, so far, I've only encountered one game breaking bug that was easily fixed and I haven't crashed once. Eventually, this won't be an issue at all.
Acceptable performance can be difficult to achieve according to your standards. (I'm playing on a GTX 1070 with an I9-9900k and I'm getting around 45 frames at mid settings and 1440p which I'm very happy with).
There's also some A.I issues. Traffic and pedestrians will get stuck if you place something in the way of their pathing, pedestrians will disappear if opening menus, roads sometimes seem empty etc.
My biggest issue is the police system. If you commit a crime in-game, there's no police chase. The NCPD will teleport behind you dealing devastating amounts of damage. If you drive away, after a few blocks, they'll forget about it. It's best just not to not deal with this feature. Besides, it's a small optional component of the game that you could completely overlook (and that's my main issue).
There are also some features that I wished the game had such as house buying, house customisation, and mid-game appearance editing, and car customisation, but it's not too much of a problem. Besides, I'm pretty sure the majority of that will be added as free DLC later down the line.

Overall, I've had such an incredible experience with this game. I seriously haven't felt this strongly about a title for a very long time. It saddens me to see people taking the few problems this game has and blowing them out of proportion. Trust me when I say this, this game is fucking incredible.
Go play it!
For me, it's an 8/10 currently and will be a 9/10 without bugs.
Review_Angles: Player Immersion, Exploration Depth, Visual Quality

I bought the game when it initially released. The game back then did have a lot of issues, mainly in the technical department. Back then, I saw that it also had a lot of potential. The writing and style of the game were great. The gameplay itself, though not perfect, was enjoyable.

Now, the game has achieved the status of one of my most liked games ever. A game, which I'll know I'll be replaying often in the coming future. The patches and updates have reduced the technical issues nearly completely (or at least to a state where I don't experience any of them). But what I did not expect, was that they reworked various parts of the gameplay to fully improve how the game played. A point which I initially did not deem necessary, though something which is very welcome, and gives way more variety in how the game is played.

On top of that, they released the Phantom Liberty DLC, which brings an entirely new type of story within the base game, without losing what I thought made the game great.

In conclusion, this game is one of the success stories, of a game that was flawed, yet had great potential underneath, that rose from its ashes to form something truly magnificent. If the game did not have great writing, an amazing style and excellent world building, we would have never gotten here, so I'm glad I was able to experience the transformation this game has made.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Narrative Quality, Gameplay Improvements

review_text:
1300 hours, 98% completion, just missing the APB achievement. How do I feel about my many hours in night city?
I started with my first run, as Male Corpo V many many moons ago and I started with 1.6. The edgerunners trailer got me interested and the edgerunners in game brain dance item/trailer forever won me a cyberpunk fan for life. 

I played and finished my first run, Corpo male V around November 2022. WOW what an experience going through the first time through night city. HUGE, vast and many many things to do. NCPD scanner, side quests, gigs, main quests etc etc. Lots of gear, ammo, weapons, clothing, cyberware and many many other lootable goodies. I was so amazed so many ridiculous moments, the views of the city are nothing short of breath taking. I can't believe I waited this long to play this game. BUT I'm more than please that I did. Because of the known issues at launch, good things come to those who wait.

Didn't start my 2nd run as Nomad Male V, till June 2023. YEAH, sorry I was playing others games during that time, lots of metal gear solid 5 The Phantom Pain and resident evil 2 remake on ps5. BUT that being said, I returned back to night city and half way through my 2nd run, we went from 1.6 to 2.0. 

Around October of 2023, when I updated to 2.0. WOW ok, what a HUGE difference, coming from 1.6 and now we're on 2.0 version. The game was overhauled completely. Can't compare 1.6 to 2.0 because the changes to perk tree system and re balance of the law watned/police system has made this game EVEN MORE worth the experience to night city. I spent many many many hours trying different builds, BECAUSE all my perk points were reset after the update. Did I want to go shinobi? Solo, enigineer, headhunter etc etc etc. And So began the HARD and long process of fine tunning my 2nd run, which was Nomad Male V.

After many hours of building v to my liking, finished my 2nd run as Nomad Male V on Valentines day, February 2024. Yeah, I wanted to make sure V, was ready for the new 2.0 updated game. I'm very happy how the re ovehauled perk tree/point system allowed us, to try and remove the point and try something else if it didn't fit our play style. WOW, finishing the game with 2nd time around, with the 2.0 update, in contrast when I completed the game 1st time through on 1.6, felt like a different game, especially the hacking. Only a handful of the hacks were untraceable, I had to adjust my stealth/hacking play style. BUT all those many hours fine tuning V, was more than worth it. Which leads us to my 3rd run, as female, Streetkid V. 

Began not too long after finished my 2nd run as male nomad v, I started March 2024 in my final run of the main game, as street kid female v. I already knew what build I wanted to go far, hacker/stealth build. Using hacking, silenced weapons and katana. Finally finished July 2024 on my 3rd run. WOW, what an amazing expereince. The entire game 2.0 update. Because my 2nd run with nomad male v, was half 1.6 and the other half 2.0. Thank you CDPR, what an amazing game. YES it was terrible at launch, but you gave us an experience, that will forever talk, as one of the best games ever in history. You just connect V, connect with all the characters in night city both GOOD and BAD haha. 1300 hours on record, WORTH every single second, every single minute and every single hour. 

Wake Up the F*ck up Samurai, we got a game to play.
Review_Angles: World Immersion, Content Variety, Visual Appeal

review_text:
🚀 [i]Review contains main game and DLC spoilers, continue reading on your own risk[/i]

“The Tower” ending hit me hard. I get attached to my own created characters and ones with a strong story and deeply written personality (for example, Daud from Dishonored). 

I remember plain as day death of Jackie and V, covered in blood, looking in the mirror. 
I remember Victor getting emotional and screaming at V that this can’t go like that anymore, he is afraid to see one day V walking down the street… but not V anymore. I remember Misty taking V to the roof to make a choice, telling that right here Jakie made a decision to become famous in Night City. I remember V’s words “I can’t believe it. Everything. All we did - it was pointless” when Alt stunned her with words that death is irreversible.    

This ending was unexpected due to the amount of cruelty. I could never even predict how things will turn out for V (I have seen all endings). It was “obvious” she would die anyway, but still had the choice to spend last days in a preferable way. 

NUSA operation ending is soaked with despair. Once you run Night City - the other moment not able to defend yourself from one thug. Reed’s words “Your body… it ain’t goin’ back to what it was. And NC’s a city where you just won’t manage. Not anymore” were the last nail in the coffin. World moved on. In reality we face the same - the world keeps going and never stops to wait for us. 

Honestly disliked the plot of Phantom Liberty, the amount of manipulation breaks all records. Fearless merc gets treated worse than a dog and okay with it. There was a goal to get treatment and fight for life, but there were so many red flags. When I was left with two options - “Betray Reed” or “Betray Songbird” I couldn’t make a choice. Both didn't inspire sympathy. 

Dogtown by itself is not memorable as a city at all. Ruins, cars, thugs. I “enjoyed” sharp bright white light in a face that I didn’t experience in the main game. Come on, as I have seen - issue is not one-time, it happens frequently to many players. 

[b]Also lets talk more about game condition in late 2023: [/b]
Last NCPD ambush doesn’t spawn near stadium that blocks from achievement
Last gig in NC requires to be failed because needed car doesn’t spawn or spawns underground that also blocks from achievement
I have seen that they fixed gig in the last patch, but… it’s been there for years. Imagine having last to obtain achievement back in the days, waiting for a fix and when you are done with waiting - here is the fix that is not desirable anymore. 

But, anyway, thanks for another type of bug where I got a lot of achievements that I didn’t complete. Seems like a present for patience. 

[b]Conclusion: [/b]
I would strongly recommend playing the main game for the story. Dialogs, music, actors performance - that is needed to be heard and seen. DLC could be much better, like in Witcher 3 (that I enjoyed with all my heart being non-fan of the Witcher world). 

Thank you for emotions and unique memories, CD Project.

review_text:
My first play through was when this game released, and even though it came with bugs and glitches, it ran smoother than it does today after patch 1.31 - I have no clue as to what has been done by the devs, but the game doesn't feel as smooth any more.

If you are a gamer thinking of playing CyberPunk 2077 for the first time, I highly recommend you start with NOMAD. Best story option by a mile.

Warning: you will get attached to some of the main characters, and you will get your heart broken. Excellent character (NPC) writing, sadly not enough of it. This game does leave you begging for more and a feeling of 'something unfinished'. There are characters who you do not want to leave, but I've said enough already.

Forget the hype, the trash talking and the spoiler videos on YouTube, just go into it, immerse yourself and enjoy the whole experience.

EDIT - update: It's now patch 1.5, and to be honest, I find it disappointing with what has and hasn't been done. The game, in parts, now feels sloppy. Yes, CDPR have added some things, over looked others (Police AI, still no Police car chases - to name but one). 

In some respects, animation-wise, it looks as if they've let their interns loose on the game, and after playing hours in GTA V, I come back to Cyberpunk 2077 and see how massively it still falls short of what was promised, what it has the potential to be and what it should be. The rag doll physics are shameful, funny at times, but not for the positive.

I just wish Steam had a 'neutral' tag option for rating games, as that's what I'd give Cyberpunk 2077 now. But as it stands, it has to be a thumbs up just for that reason.

As of update 2.2 (2025) I still can't understand why CDPR devs have vehicle speed displayed in MPH, when every other aspect is in metres and kilometres - and for sure, the speed vehicles travel DO NOT match the MPH shown on the speedo, it should be in KPH without a doubt.

If you're not chomping at the bit to play this game, I would suggest hanging back, wait for price drops, better updates (if they ever happen) and take reviews on YouTube with a pinch of salt in the main.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Narrative Quality, Character Development

This game is anything but short of amazing even with all of its known bugs and issues. If you're looking for an in-depth story that keeps you compelled for countless hours with tons of side missions, then you'll have no problem enjoying it. The story feels rich and full of alternative paths even after completion of your first run. The few critiques of the game boil down to it being rushed. The free roam world is lacking a lot to be desired still with countless graphical and audio glitches, shoddy A.I, and discovery. While this is disappointing, it is one of the better outcomes for a game with issues. It's easy to fix bugs, poor performance, and less than desirable A.I. It's not easy to fix story and game mechanics. Once they fix a lot of the known issues it should become the GotY without a doubt!

review_text: the guys from fortnite
so far so good. will come back after i play more

This is a bad game. I bought this post patches, so it's mostly been stable. Still get t-poses and some other weird things, but Cyberpunk 2077, after playing, it's clear was never going to be a good game.

It gives off a vibe like Deus Ex Human Revolution meets Skyrim, l but I cannot advise enough not to buy this. Do not give anyone any money for this.

The intro is you're ushered through cutscenes that show you becomes a netrunner instead of actually letting you do this yourself. A game so bored of itself it find it necessary to try to skip ahead to get to the "good part" except jokes on you there is no good part of this game.

The vehicles should have been removed. The controls are clunky and the handling is awful. You would think that anyone who made a video game on PC would have a driving mode with the mouse where your mouse input mimics analog stick input from a controller and you can steer by moving your mouse. You would be wrong. This super-intuitive driving control scheme on PC does not exist in Cyberpunk 2077. Also, in a cybercity in the distant year 2077 apparently I can't do what I can do in 2021; tell my car to drive somewhere for me so I don't have to bother. They don't have Autopilot in 2077? What year did all the Tesla and Waymo cars die out? Hello? CDPR? Is anyone there? Why is your driving so bad in your open world driving game? What's good as new? Who's talking? *Pets Horeshoe Crab*

Combat is an afterthought-- Or at least I hope it is! A chaotic mess with poor gunplay, awful melee combat, and some kind of hacking thing? It's boring, unsatisfying, but the important part is, it's not fun. None of this game is fun. Some games have crouch as a setting, regarding if you want it to be hold or toggle. Some games have both keybinds if you want to use them. Cyberpunk 2077 (whose name is obnoxious to type, please name your game something else next time assuming you don't go out of business) has both keybinds, but the tutorial specifically uses the toggle one because they hate you. I use crouch hold, like a normal human being, and I spend most of the tutorial holding down crouch toggle wondering why it wasn't responding. Gun combat sure exists! But it has no depth at all beyond that. Melee I actually thought would be better coming from the Witcher lineage but it is even worse than the gunplay. Def don't specialize in melee, but the tutorial for that was not good. You have to hold down RIGHT MOUSE BUTTON to charge a melee attack, and so I would hold it down and wait for some kind of visual cue to tell me it's finished charging. But there isn't one. There is no way to tell. The arm placement is different, but charge to me indicated like, it takes time to do? But charged 'heavy' melee attacks charge almost instantly to the point where if you're not tapping RIGHT MOUSE BUTTON constantly, probably you're doing charged attacks. It's so gross how they don't understand or implement any kind of basic video game conventions in this game.

The actual cyberpunk parts of Cyberpunk 2077 are stupid and boring. A lot of the pistol skills for example are just "do more crit damage when you crit someone." It the "just get all; head shots bro" skill tree. Wow that's so imaginative. In the far flung year of 2077 did you know you can kill people by aiming for their heads? The rest of the skill trees repeat this ad nauseam. There's no really cool cyber tech in this a la Human Revolution, it's... just stupid treadmill crap. It's the kind of game where enemies remain at a fixed level advantage above you no matter what you upgrade. It's just, "Hey you like strength right? Well you should upgrade your strength so you can keep it hovering just below the AI's strength level.

Like many of these games, the developers decided stealth is the correct answer so you know, just play into stealth and don't do any other kinds of builds. The city itself is poorly designed so much as to be hostile to the player, which, why would you even do that?

The UX/UI is the worst part of the game. The PC controls are just absolutely terrible. Most keys toggle menus, right? Like M opens your map, and then press M to close it again real quick. But M doesn't close an open map. It does something else after the map is open, and ESC closes the map... or C? Or Q? I don't remember, but you can probably close it. Game designers have spend many years perfecting dialog interactions with NPCs. CDPR like, threw that out to do it wrong on purpose? So... when you interact with a computer terminal or machine, your crosshair becomes the cursor when you're close enough to that interface. When you speak to a person though, virtual dialog options come up in the air in front of them, but you cannot use your cursor, you have to use your mouse wheel and then awkwardly press F while probably your fingers are on WASD? It also mostly doesn't put you into dialog mode like Skyrim does, so you can still move around, but you have to stay still in front of the people you're talking to in order to talk to them anyway so I don't understand the point. The WASD keys can't be used to pick dialog options, nor is it even a dialog wheel like Mass Effect. It's a different system I guess just to be poor? To be a bad dialog system? Why did you do this? Interactions with things is poor. In your inventory trying to equip things had me constantly dropping things on the ground because you can't click on something to equip it, it's like clicking drops it? But if you hover an item and press F you can replace the item you're wearing in that slot. You can click a slot to see items from that slot to equip, but then there's no way to back out of that menu once you do? I don't completely remember how inventory works because it's the worst and makes no sense based on the convention other PC games have set up over the years. The game is full of stupid and frustrating inconsistencies like this. Most vending machines for example you can buy things from by using F. There is a machine you can sell junk to and this machine only operates by you pressing... R? What? Why?

I'll give you one my best example of how apparently no one at CDPR understand what video games are or how to make them. So you know elevators? You know how an elevator works by coming when it's called, and then you press a floor, and the elevator goes there and the door opens when you reach the requested floor(s)? Like the door opening signals it's reached its destination? In Cyberpunk, a futuristic city in 2077 I have to keep pointing out, the elevator doors remain closed when the floor you requested is reached. Nothing will happen to notify you that you have arrived and can exit. Being that you're unfamiliar with the game, you might be waiting for the door to open to show you which way to go because some elevators have door that are open across from each other instead of just the one door that you came in by. But no. In the futuristic world of Cyberpunk, in Night City, the stupidest city on Earth, the doors remain closed unless manually opened. (But by which button? F? R? .. MOUSE WHEEL?) Although even this was inconsistent because at some point the doors despite, having a prompt still come up to open them with F, would open when approached, but still not automatically. Someone actually had to program the elevator to work like this. Is this real life? Am I in Hell?

The overall theme I get from Cyberpunk's awful controls is that they apparently had developers who only play on console come up with all of the controls schemes for PC? It's clear no one who worked on this game has touched a PC before, with the exception of the PCs I assume they use to program the game in the first place? But why the devs, if PC is an afterthought to them and they don't understand what a PC game is, or how it's played, or what PC game conventions of the last decade are, they'd even release this on PC is baffling to me. But hey, here's another terrible PC port of a console game. Enjoy!
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Gameplay Mechanics

review_text:
TL;DR: Is this game still chock-full of minor bugs and some game-breaking bugs? Yes, but it's fun and maybe worth it.

- There's more oddities in this game than your average Bethesda game would have (NPC weirdness, objects shifting when you turn to look at them, etc.) and some big bugs that still have yet to be fixed apparently (You can lose your ability to scan/quick-hack which may force you to go back to a previous save, and another one is Rogue's questline is bugged at the end and requires a lot of finagling to try and get it to work. I just gave up on it eventually as it wasn't the ending I was going for anyways.)

+ However, the combat is incredibly fun, albeit a bit too easy as you level up (seriously, I don't know how you can die after halfway through the game except for getting sniped.) You definitely feel like an all-powerful god once your build gets going, but I'm totally in for that, especially since this game is pretty much a looter shooter more than an RPG.

~ The voice acting is insanely good-- Except for Johnny Silverhand (Keanu Reeves.) That man didn't even try, and it sucks every time his (major) character speaks, because it made me not give a shit about Johnny the entire game. V and the rest of the main cast are exceptional though. The ending is good, but leaves a lot of loose ends as sequel bait for sure.

+ Game looks incredible, and even on my medium-tier specs, I was able to enjoy a lot of it without any real hiccups. The world does feel pretty alive when you're moving around, and the sights to see are crazy good.

- A small gripe is that it feels like there's *too* many quest-givers. Every 5 seconds it seems like some random new side-character will call you and go "You don't know me, but I've heard of you, and I got a job for ya." Like, your quest log fills so fast from just leveling Street Cred or just running around to certain areas, it's a bit annoying.

~ Another issue I'd say is the lack of *wanting* to be in the world. Like, why would I bother going to another area of the city to buy a new apartment? I went back to V's apartment maybe twice by my own free will, because there was just no point with how much carrying capacity you're allowed. Same goes with buying the many vehicles available for purchase-- Who cares? You just drive from point A to point B in this game (because driving is atrociously bad.) It's a lot of fluff and not enough substance outside of story missions and side missions.

Overall, I'd give this game a 7/10, because it's carried by the combat, characters, and voice acting. The rest is very muddled and is either mid or bad. Hopefully when they release DLC for the game, they'll fix a lot of these issues, but after 2 years, not holding out hope.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Combat Enjoyment, Consumer Value

[h1] Review: Cyberpunk 2077 - A place where all kinds of people meet [/h1]
2020 | played time: 112 hours | 8/10 

Cyberpunk 2077 is a very story-centric role-play game based on a tabletop role-playing game from the late 1980s. It is developed and published by CD Project Red which pulls you into a potential dystopian future of our world.

The game begins in one of three variants in the year 2076 depending on the background choice made for V, the protagonist, in the character creation. The first act begins with V working as a mercenary in Night City. However, after working a few gigs life takes an unexpected turn. In the second act, V is hit by the reality of the aftermath of the preceding act and tries his best to survive. 
The story of V progresses through the main story missions and a vast number of optional side quests in the open world. The relating cutscenes and dialogues are mostly set within the open world creating immersion, however waiting for a quest to start at the given location can feel disruptive. The side quests also include options to have romantic affiliations with some characters depending on the gender and sexual orientation of the protagonist. Night City is traversed by V in first person, by different means of transport such as by foot or in vehicles. The latter has an unusually unnatural handling to it. The fighting system seems rather unrealistic in a game with an immersive intent where one shot to the head does not result in immediate death of either V or some enemies. One the other hand, this would make certain play styles such melee builds unviable. Cyberpunk 2077 invites to capture moments by providing a photo mode. The world provides several apartments, and looting is possible at almost every corner. However, a missing survival system makes the apartments and most of the lootable consumables close to obsolete. 
Cyberpunk 2077 can be modified which is made very accessible through third-party mod-menus. These modifications offer extensive possibilities to improve graphics and visuals, immersion and quality of life, or simply adding assets such as cars.
The world is created with a lot of attention to detail though the huge size of Night City and the vastness of the Badlands. The city and the surroundings can be explored by various modes of travel such as by foot, with the metro or with vehicles. The latter have a unique and unordinary futuristic design due to the view of the late 1980s. The city captures the feeling of a de facto corporatocracy and the power of corporation through the many towering skyscrapers and other buildings. The 3-dimensional possibilities of such building by using balconies, bridges and other levels reachable through elevators are well explored though substantial potential in this area is left untapped. Night City offers a huge variety of places including bars and other vendors which can be explored. A short fall is that not every street vendor is interactable by the protagonist. Completely missing but essential in a city of this size are supermarkets and at least one proper mall. Though there are several markets which are a substitute for the latter. The city offers different districts, each with a unique style and architecture reflecting the different socio-economic backgrounds living there. However, the gradient between districts can feel noticeably abrupt. The world experiences different weathers such as rainfall or fog. Analog to the previous aspect, the weather changes in the game are also very abrupt. Although the map is beautifully created, the slope changes in hilly areas are jaggy and some on- and off-ramps are unrealistically steep. While walking around in back alleys, piles of garbage can be found. However, due to the solid design of the assets any disturbance in the arrangement of the piles results in a hail of garbage bags.
The sound is very neatly designed. As such stepping on different materials makes different sounds. The immersion is furthered by having sounds for moving glass bottles and cans. The sound design of the vehicles is very well made. The radio and the music selection offer a good variety and various genres. All the characters’ voice actors did an astounding job capturing the emotions of the characters. Unfortunately, very noticeable is the sudden high-pitched detection sound which is played upon detection by an enemy while stealthing ripping the player out of the immersion.
Overall, the game is nicely balanced from a graphics point of view. Though the resolution of the textures and the fidelity of the assets are below the expectation of a game released in 2020. Additionally, though pleasing for the eye, the color grading is rather warm which is a mismatch for a dystopian futuristic megacity. Furthermore, the contrast in the game is tuned a bit too high resulting in an unrealistic feeling. Fortunately, modifications to adjust the postprocessing filters exist to remedy these shortcomings.
The main story of Cyberpunk 2077 is structured into three acts including a prologue, interlude and epilogue. Most notably, the storyline is anything but railroaded. As such a huge amount of optional side quests are available forming V’s story in Night City. The order for the parallel running side storylines is mostly irrelevant giving the sensation of immersion in the world and actually living the life of V. Also noticeable is the feeling of impact of the decisions that need to be made in the life of V and the related events and people. News coverage of world events also increases immersion and the sensation of living in Night City. Unfortunately, due to this setup, the urgency of progression created by certain events is disregarded and minorly breaks the logic of the plot. However, time is still given the due significance by having waiting times between quests and forcing the player to explore the world. 

Cyberpunk 2077 is a must play for any singleplayer roleplay game enthusiast. It offers a great and very immersive experience. The story offers a lot of freedom in decisions all affecting the outcome in some way. Graphically, the game is not up to par with other titles released in that year. But the story and the world design are worth overlooking the minor flaws the game has.
Worth the buy, in my opinion its not as much like gta as people say, most of the bugs have been fixed, and past it being a really good single player shooter game, theres a lot of heart in it as well.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Narrative Depth
