I've put in 173 hours of game play. Honestly love the story. Can't wait to hop in and blast a few more baddies. I haven't found a game this addictive since Fallout 4 dropped us mod support. 
This game is running quite well on my 7 year old laptop, not really sure what all the gripe is about crashing and glitching. Its not really upset my game play that much. Taken with a helpful dose of salt knowing my PC has been through a lot over these last few years.
I've had my gripes about some of the actual game play. Of course i feel like i grew up playing games you cant change how they work. Even with current mods, I still choose to play the base game as it is. I take that as a good sign that I'm still enjoying the game the way it was built.
Mods will be this games saving grace. Its forced early launch has left that window wide open. And i would highly support the community mods and mods support.

Lets get this out of the way first, this game is a lot of fun. The combat is a good time. The story is great and filled with characters I enjoyed so much that I was sad when their quest lines ended. I am happy I finally bought the game, and even though I haven't finished it yet, I am very excited too.

However, this game is still buggy. I had a quest line I wanted to continue but couldn't get the character to call me no matter what. Had to look online and discover a way around the bug was to skip time and stand still for ten minutes. Doesn't feel great when interesting quest lines are halted for no apparent reason. If I hadn't wanted to continue it, I don't know if I would have realized it never came back around.

Also weird when there is a street of all one character model of a citizen. Cars headlights ahead of you will disappear and the cars will disappear with them. Just little odd things that just make the game less great. The presentation is so stellar though, that when these things happen it is hard to ignore. 

Also having characters just walk through cars or phasing through you feels a bit bizarre too. 

Still, a great game. Fun time. But quest bugs and some odds presentation glitches do detract from the game.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Enjoyment, Narrative Quality, Technical Stability

review_text: Based game! Solid 9/10
Cause I really wanna stay at your houseeeeeeeeeeee
Talked a car out of suicide. 10/10
This game is one of a kind. Very addictive just like witcher 3 was, well done CDPR!

First of all, yes i really do recommend this game for "visual freaks" out there with neat set up, but but but, something i notice that, the steam version got a sized about 60 gigs. but the PS ver got 100 gigs, i dont know what it affects or is it because its compressed or whatsoever and i dont really care, but i do care about the gameplay and mechanics as i followed the witcher series (except gwent).

Second of all, about the story, yeah....i havent got that "so far" enough to bring the conclusion, but ive already expect that this game will not get "too far" as how the witcher progress through the timeline. And damn straight i am. It got a long main story but as like the witcher series, the amount of side quest and hints about the the difficulty on the sidequest, some items that required you to lvl up first before you can equip it, the skill tree, and the "ETC" stuff that youve familiar with in the witcher or fallout series......well, its all there.

Long story short, well as what i expected of how the game is being executed/released, it truly is a mixed of "fps-adventure-action-rpg & fpsass/first person strange adventure stealth shooter". Where does the "strange" part comes in? Ill just wrap it all up, i doooooo got sucked in, in the story progression, but.....yeah theres a but, BUT it is kinda strange that knowing that its now an fps game tho it have a a-rpg/rpg elements, for me the dev does mixed it up well, very well indeed, give credit to that, but if you dont play an rpg game series and get used/comfy in crafting system, looting an enormous amount of materials, the large amount of skill tree options, it does took you some time to get used too, or maybe.....a huge amount of time just to understand and get along, be friend, be a buddy with all that kind-o stuffffff'sssss or maybe just to do the right combo for your playstyle. Well as for me, it does give me a real vibes of "im gonna play this MY-WAY" with stealth thing, combo, skill tree, attachment and some sort of stuffs. But im just imagining that "what about if im not an rpg guy, and i just want some action"........in that case, yea id still recommend this game, but..........you really need to spent hours on gettin a grip on the mechanics & how to play the game properly, afterall, its somewhat an rpg game, so you do need to remind that at some point, this game needed you to grind for exp & items. Well.....tough luck on wishin that the devs will shift sideways more to the "action only" stuff.

On the contrary, the game feels awesome, MEANING: big map to explore, many quest (even tho sometimes will get repetitive enough), cool voice acting, best graphics (im using rtx for short), the movement (well its still a bit strange, but if you already got comfortable playing PUBG, well you wont have any issue about the movements), good character editing (not that detailed but good, way way way more better than the witcher), detailed story line (moving forward & back like its predecessor....the witcher.....again....sorry).

For me, it does worth the money and the waiting time for the game released, i mean with big time mechanic & graphic like that, jeez if they sell the collectors edition on steam (digital game but send the goodies to my door step) id be down for that. 

Thats it from me, cant describe enough, its just a review not a blog, just givin impression, but note that im a witcher & fallout fan, so dont get me wrong about if i say "the game is good", but not sure for everybody.

Edit:
P.S
What do you think about the game?
Write down the comment, and lets discuss about it.
Ill be happy hearin on what you guys thought!

review_text: My god......Just... SAMURAI BUILD WEEEEEEEEEEEEOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO

This is a perfectly AVERAGE game. Not groundbreaking, not unplayable, a solid C+/B-. I might pay $15-20 for this game.

Appraises first, the aesthetic is all there and it seems a lot of effort was put into world-building. The setting is cohesive and believable. It's a cool concept, and if I don't request a refund, I will see it to the end. BUT...

Ignoring the bugs, which I believe are fixable and probably will be fixed, there are significant problems fundamentally with the game. 
- The keybinding are incredibly counter-intuitive and can only be changed by accessing your configuration files, not through the game.
- How to access your inventory, add points to your skill tree, what the different types of points do, other basic RPG features are not explained. How to shoot is explained; how to go into your inventory and equip any weapon is not.
- You can't equip things in your inventory while looking in your storage; you have to close your storage and separately open your inventory to equip.
- Appearance customization is limited and cannot be changed after you first create your character.
- The driving scheme is insane--camera is positioned with respect to the world, not the car, so if you are driving north and turn west, your camera stays facing north until you adjust your mouse. You end up spending most of the time running around the city or fast traveling because it's superior to driving.
- I'm not very deep into the story yet, but comparing my friend's and my experiences, it sounds like the story doesn't change much between paths (corpo, streetkid, nomad), just the tone of certain dialogue options and prelude, and that your action and dialogue choices don't have much consequence on the story (someone further in, please correct me if I'm wrong. I am hoping I am).
[b] TLDR, I want to like this game, but there are a lot of fundamental problems with the story and mechanics that I don't think can be fixed with patches. It's not garbage, it's not unplayable, but it's not worth $60. Wait a few months until at least some bugs are fixed and the price drops. [/b]
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Aesthetics and World-Building, Usability and Tutorials

review_text: A true masterpiece. I completed a full playthrough (60 hours) about two years ago, and recently dove back in with Phantom Liberty for another 60 hours. There were moments when I had to pause the game just to share with my significant other the wild twists in the quests and the weight of the consequences from my decisions. The best part? I know I'll do another full playthrough someday, and it’ll lead to completely different outcomes. This game is beyond exceptional—'masterpiece' is the only word that truly captures it.

How I feel about Cyberpunk2077 so far:

- Good points:
Storylines: This game has storylines which can't be described with words. So exciting, amazing and full of suprises are only a few words which I can use. An extraordinary creation which took its time. 

Graphics: The game also has gorgeous graphics. Everything is so beautiful to the eyes and with rtx on it is even better! The views u can experience are amazing and feel almost as if they are real.

Price: The price is absolutely amazing for a game like this, I would even be ready to pay more for this work of art.

Pc/system: Even tho the game has some fps issues for some people with lower end systems, if u have a new generation gpu you will be able to run the game smoothly at atleast 60fps or much more, but for sure needs to be more optimised.

- Bad points:
Guns/Mechanics : The only thing that disapointed me a little is the combat mechanics which are.. how do I say this weird. Apart from the lack of different types of guns and options to buy and customize them, enemies take way too long to be killed with common guns and other types. Imo it is not really fun to have to shoot 2 full mags onto a guy for him to die. Ofc if u manage to get your hands on the legendary or epic guns it is a little better.

Cars: I was really suprised when I learned that you'll only be able to buy cars from fixers in Cyberpunk 2077. They only offer random cars, so u cannot really get the car u actually want to own, which is kinda sad even tho u don't really need to buy cars into this game acknowledging the fact u can steal any car u want by shooting the driver and hoping in.

Bugs: The game may have a few bugs but trust me, they will be far gone and forgoten in a few weeks. Every game has her bugs in the begining, but with all the hard worcking and skilled people behind Cyberpunk 2077 they will be erased without you realising they even existed.

Character Customisasion: Even tho Cyberpunk2077 offers things no other games do, the lack of haristyles, colors, tatoos... and a few more things are missing from what I've seen.

Conclusion: An extraordinary game which fits the price and expectations by a lot. The game can be run very smoothly on lots of systems but ofc won't run very well on some lower end ones. Buy the game now and enjoy the amazing work of art.

Hope this helped some of you which had troubles deciding to buy the game or pass for now.

Completed the game and enjoyed it, but I didn't really know if I liked it until I was about 20 hours into the story. It was a good games, but it felt a bit hollow. There are a lot of bugs in the game, choices you make in the story don't really matter or affect the ending like they did in the WItcher 3, and overall it's just not that much of an immersive experience. A game I heavily compared it to was Red Dead Redemption 2 because I had just replayed it prior to getting Cyberpunk, and also because its probably one the best single-player RPG's out there, both in terms of story and technical quality.

I'm not gonna say the game's a buggy, unoptimized mess because that's not what I experienced. I did experience some bugs, but none were game breaking. There were instances where a mission was bugged and I had to reload the game, but nothing that actually kept me from progressing. The game ran well enough on my mid-range PC, ryzen 3700x, 2060 super, 16gb ddr4 2133, but there some graphical issues like after images on vehicles, certain areas of the city lowering performance, etc.. 

I do recommend this game, just not in its current state and definitely not at it's full price. Wait for more patches/updates for CDPR to fix/finish the game, and also wait for it to go on sale. I honestly wouldn't pay more $40 for it right now.

I like just about everything about this game except for it's story. I like the combat, it feels really cool and I think there are entire builds that I have never even touched. High risk high reward throwing knife build, charge up tech weapons, monstrous high strength pistols, melee, hacking, all kinds of great stuff. I like the world, I like the gameplay, I even like a lot of the quests(shoutouts to Brendan over by Megabuilding H8). The game works fine for me at this point as well.

The problem I have with the game is that it has the kinda story that I don't like to hang around in for the length of a whole open world game. I feel like it's well written and all, but I don't really want to be thinking about my own mortality and finding out the fate of the other people in my crew(some of this stuff can get EXTREMELY dark), for the length of time required to finish an open world game like this. I get the same feeling after playing through the main questline for a while that I do after reading the news, which I think is intended, but it just kinda starts to really suck the fun away for me personally.

Again I love playing the game, I bought it on Steam and GOG and even installed it on my steam deck to play with it there(bought it on GOG first at launch that's where most of my playtime is). But I don't think I'm ever going to finish the story because it really strongly feels like it's not for me.

life changing

I couldn't recommend this more. They're getting slaughtered with the "official" reviews but I think by now we all know not to trust the media. Plus I think it's messed up that they were getting their share price shorted into oblivion. Hopefully that changes post GME. Politics aside here's my review: 

The graphics are insane, this is the new crysis for sure and the atmosphere is incredible, I've wanted a game like this to come out for god knows how long since cyberpunk is one of my favorite genres of fiction. It meets the mark there and exceeds it. Just make sure you're ok with spending a fair bit on a PC for it. Turn DLSS on too and it'll hover around 60fps on a 3090. Worth it though. 

Story wise there's a lot of depth there, I don't want to ruin it with spoilers but they get the classic philosophical problems that the genre is supposed to deal with. These are questions about identity, consciousness, and where the lines might blur in the future between a person and a machine. More than that though it's accessible, and thoroughly well written. Reeves does an impeccable job. The whole atmosphere of the game changes for his sections and it's hilarious but at the same time achingly cool. Just yunno, painfully cool lol. Excessive in the best way. All the characters are very well written and acted. I straight up fell for Judy ;D

They don't shy away from creating a videogame that's adult too, which I honestly respect. I'm a middle aged dude so I hate it when things are half arsed and there's not enough gore or sex. C'mon other game devs we can take it. \m/

The side missions range from being just random encounters with gangs to a good amount of deeper stuff, I haven't really even scratched the surface there. The cool thing is that there are some really, and I mean REALLY freakin weird side missions. Again, no spoilers, I wish I could but it just wouldn't be fair. 

I'm 76 hours in and I love it. Gameplay wise it feels like we finally got a high-tech version of fallout or skyrim. There's lots of depth in the tech trees but I feel like it doesn't really matter where you put your stats most of the time. That said it's very enjoyable and visceral to blow someone's brains out with one of the more advanced weapons or cave someone's chest in with a giant hammer. 10/10 there. 

I think the main problem with the game is just that the corpos nuked the official reviews, so most NPC's are hating on it. Plus a lot of people probably kept binging on hype. I didn't see more than 5 minutes of footage before buying the game and that was mostly by accident. It's fantastic. A classic. It's not even that buggy tbh. I mean shit some of the stuff I used to see in skyrim was way, way worse. The game is fantastic, next gen, and I think that scares the competition so they're pulling some dirty tricks.
Review_Angles: Visuals and Atmosphere, Performance, Narrative Depth

Good day,
Be aware this is a long and detailed review with SPOILERS.

I started to play the game when it came out, but after some time, I felt like this game deserves to be played when it is more fluid and just generally more processed then what it was back then. So I waited until I felt it was on a satisfactory level, and then I started a new campaign. 

I will speak only about the present state of the game, I will not speak about already repaired bugs from now on.

First I will go with the rant, and later with the blessings. 

Rant part one glitches: 

1. The game still has many glitches, like invisible or blinking phones and tablets, peoples clipping through things or each other, floating food and I think I saw a guy with smoker shoes on sometime ago, seriously the thing spat out smoke like a steam train or something. 
The most annoying ones, at least for me are the following ones: 
-Mantis blade crouch position right hand looks really weird around the wrist area (on female body I don't know if the male body has this glitch)  
-The grey texture that blinks through your character skin when undressed around the shoulders and chest-neck area if I remember correctly also on the female body model.
-The character head shadow, that makes you feel like a skinhead, there is no shadow for your hair, I am not sure if wearing a headgear changes anything about the shadow, I don't really used headgear too many times except sunglasses.
-When you climb stairs, your characters legs often get stuck in a weird crouch like position and float away in that funny pose. 
-The character model shadows are generally stiff, but when you use mantis blade in combat mode, it is really hard to look at and beyond disturbing with some of the normal weapon armament too like the swords. 
-There is one glitch when you drive a car in third person view and when you leave the car and the camera changes back to first person there is a big grey glitch usually from the right side of the car when you leave the car from the driving seat. It is not always present. 
-There is a big glitch that made me use the cars in third person most of the time, if I want to be more specific there is two. reason for that. First one: you basically can't see out of the car good enough to drive efficiently, literally can't see half the street because I sit too low or maybe the character is just too short? I don't know but it is annoying. The other one, is even more crazy, in some of the cars usually with the nomad armored cars where instead of glass they use display type windscreen or something like that when you turn the car towards the smallest of lights the screen turns into a completely blinding white light, and there is no way to see anything at all, only if you focus the character view to an unnatural angle and look down to your legs then the view clears out but if you look back witch happens automatically through driving you will be blinded again.  There are some cars with display windscreens that are not affected by this, like the basilisk and so on.
-There is one more, and I am not sure if it is intended or not but it's still annoying. Around the end of the game I basically found a silver hand in my inventory. It is in the quest item area of the inventory, where you can see every item you found through the game. So I clicked on it, and to my not so small surprise V put it on her left hand. It is not a normal silver hand but the hazy version that activates in times when Silverhand is in control. To be straight for a time I was very happy about this, then the rosy clouds dispersed and I tried to put it down. But it stuck, so I panicked asked Victor for help but he didn't see any problem and chased me out of the shop so. I played through the game and Jhonny is not even here anymore, but I still have his arm, it would be a nice souvenir, if I could turn off the effect at will. Just saying.

2. Rant about things that I missed and would not be that much more work to make them (except brain dance).

-The obvious: customisation of character looks in game. This is so basic I wont even go into why would it be good, you guys already put this function into some of your games. 
-Walk button switch for PC players this was in your games already too, and I can't fathom why wasn't implemented here. 
-Mini games, the hours that I wasted on Gwent, nothing new here, I am not saying that you should put Gwent into this game, but something where you can use your money is needed! The whole game feels empty, because you can't use your money that you work for any normal way, you can become a terminator, jump 10 meter high but you can't play a simple game in a gamer corner or bet on the pachinko machines, you can't even use the bd-s that you bought and I am saying the bd-s creates so many possibilities and not using that feature to the fullest is a sin. In the end it is a shame that you have less possibilities to waste your money and time in a high-tech ultra modern city that was raised on primary desires then in a witcher like farming countryside. 

3. Rant about unreasonable choices: 
- This game is an adult game created to be played by adults 18 + only.  I understand the possibility to use the characters with underclothes and without them for preferences. But if I chose the first that means I don't want underclothes on my character. I don't get it why would half nude be good, and totally nude not? Especially if in the inventory you are nude anyway and even in some of the scenes? You guys gave us only the illusion of choice here, and even that is in a very unreasonable way. If you think that walking around the street totally nude is not realistic, than make a joke out of it, for example NCPD arrests you on the street and you have to pay money for public lechery or something.
- Many sex scenes are frustratingly prudish because of the same reason (don't cut out the good part), if you want to save us from depravity I would say you are not in charge of that, any kid nowadays can write three word in search engine and see things like even I would fall out of my chair from. 

Now comes the good part! 

1. The characters: I have never played a game that has this realistic and rich type of characters. Every main character is a unique world and this is not exaggeration, the voice actors did an outstanding job and the animators made them become alive and natural. The only games that I find close to this character uniqueness is my old favorites Dragon Age: Origins, KOTOR and the Witcher 3, but this game goes beyond those in this by far. Truly marvelous job.
2. Action execution: Most of the main battle or action scenes are ridiculously good there was some strange moments through the scripted fights but I can easily look passed those because of the overall coolness of the whole act. Those movie like moments usually left me awed and speechless for minutes. 
3. Ending/endings: There is not another game or movie that I played or watched that made me feel this close to death it creeps me out still when I think back to it, I played out the game with the Rogue way and I was shell shocked and I think I was depressed for few hours after that. The feeling of helplessness, hope, courage and panic, before the inevitable end.  That was deep. I am not even sure if I would want to go through that again if I had a choice to forget it. Some of my close relatives died a few months back, after a long-term illness I think I got a taste of what they went through, and it hit me in the guts quite literally.
 
Summary:

This game is a big gem that needs a lot of polishing and patience to reach its potential. In my play-through I felt the creators desire to make something remarkable, through they sweat, blood and tears. 

There were frustrating moments in the game, yet in retrospect I can only applaud. 

Have a nice day.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Mechanics, Narrative Quality

Cyberpunked by CD Projekt RIP. (Continued in comments, reversed)
The Acknowledgement
Let me start by saying this; I wish I liked Cyberpunk 2077, and in theory I do. Sadly, that is only in theory.
Additionally, with my background in business, I am sympathetic to the plight the company.
The impressive marketing leading up to the launch combined with the exceptional reputation of CD Projekt Red (Here after referred to as CDPR) had me within inches of investing in the company. Instead, I did what I never do; I intentionally bought the game on day one at full price, intended to reward a game and developer that were guaranteed to be so exceptional.
Six weeks later the only thing I feel is betrayal and disappointment.
I understand why this happened too. When every delay of the launch causes a forty percent dip in the stock of your company and loss of investor confidence, it makes a certain sense to release a game that can be fixed later. That certain sense is a short-term financial sense. And it was the absolute wrong answer.
This was the moment to show backbone and play the long game, releasing the game when it was finished as promised and showering in the praise and money long awaited but well deserved. But that is not what happened. Cooler, more rational heads did not prevail and the gamers, the employees, and the company are paying for it every day.

The Main Issue
Let’s talk about the main issue.
This is not the game I paid for.
This is not the game I waited for with bated breath for eight years.
This is not a game I would buy had I known the enormous gap between the image projected and the slap of lackluster reality.
The game I have been playing (when I can force myself to) is half of a chintzy, incomplete Bethesda RPG that feels like it punishes you for playing it. 
I use the reference to Bethesda RPGs (Any Fallout [Except New Vegas, although not Bethesda] or Elder Scrolls game ever) very very intentionally and it is applicable here because of the many similarities and poor design choices made. So, let’s power hammer this out.
As with any Bethesda RPG you can expect the following: 

-(Menu Simulator) 
You will spend no less than half of any gaming session ripped from the world you are trying to immerse yourself in, staring blankly at a poorly executed menu instead. Typically this happens because in your desperate attempt to earn money or collect the best loot/items/crafting material, you will pick up almost everything you see, leading to over-encumberment and a trip into the game menu where you will agonize over what to keep and what to break down/sell/dispose of. Having done so, you will close the menu, walk five feet to the next corpse and begin the process all over again.
Solution; Give V a backpack drone that can deposit loot intelligently based off player preferences. Perhaps it can make trips to V’s apartment where you can sort through it later, or you give the drone instructions about what items you are not interested in and it can dispose/sell/breakdown for you. Also, limit how many guns and items V can equip. Make him choose a loadout with limited resources at his apartment instead of letting him carry around twenty guns, four hundred hypo’s and eighty grenades. The drone can resupply him if he runs out between jobs.

-(Item Fomo [Fear of Missing Out])
Compounding the above problem is the issue that the world is littered with useful and useless items. Even in the middle of combat, you will never feel free to progress until you have inspected every corpse and every box and every item laying about. You will stop advancing and intentionally take damage just to make sure you haven’t missed something incredible or even something slightly helpful, which is about as immersion breaking as you can get. Suddenly you don’t feel like a cybernetically enhanced mercenary of the dark future; you feel like a high-risk scavaging, cleaning lady suffering from intense OCD. If like myself you actually have Obsessive Compulsive Tendencies, this is likely to make the experience incredibly stressful rather than enjoyable. Gearbox’s Borderlands games suffer from the same issue; sure they’ve got a billion guns, but player’s don’t want to spend five billion minutes figuring out which is the best one and if they might have missed a better one.
Solution; Declutter or make further use of the drone discussed above. Anyone in touch with reality knows you aren’t going to get gun parts out of condoms and ashtrays and they aren’t worth their weight in Eddies. Either let them fulfill their intended purpose or let us let them go, please.

-(Tiered Loot)
I cannot emphasize enough how much tiered loot does not belong in this game. You want to put in some unique weapons and cyberware? Sure, by all means. But when you introduce Tiers you create a hierarchy, and no one is satisfied with a hierarchy unless you are at the top. So if you put twelve legendary/iconic weapons and cyberware in your game, the truth is those are the only weapons and cyberware in your game, because no one will be satisfied with anything else. Combined that with the price of purchasing some of the items, and it flat out doesn’t make financial sense to waste your money buying anything but the best.
As a secondary issue, tiered loot forces players into an immersion breaking choice; do I stay immersed in the game and try (and fail) to be satisfied with whatever items I have, or do I stop playing and look up guides on how to find the best items and just make a beeline for them using knowledge the player has and the character wouldn’t. 
Tiered loot has a place; it’s called Fortnite. Leave it there.
Solution; Rather than create hierarchies, give us variety and customization. Give the game more weapons and more versatility and actual meaningful ways of customizing them to our play style. There should be a full fledged system at V’s apartment wherein you can change out every piece on a weapon and see it reflected in visuals and performance. Just don’t create a hierarchy within that customization. Please.
And if you really want to include iconic weapons, make it so V can receive one absolutely unique weapon based on how V plays, similar to how Johnny Silverhand was gifted his one-of-a-kind pistol by Malorian.

-(No meaningful customization)
For a game that centers around literal body modification, there is almost no significant customization options for V. Sure, you get a standard (not exceptional as promised) character creator at the start, but aside from visiting a ripperdoc, you are locked in from there. Visiting a ripperdoc is also incredibly underwhelming after your first time at Victor’s. One time and one time only, you get the chance to see yourself go under the digital knife, get ripped apart and emerge stronger. After that, its every interaction with a ripperdoc is back to being a menu simulator. You will emerge changed and upgraded, but the way it happens is so lack luster you won’t believe anything was done to you at all.
Upgrading weapons and cloths is much the same. You can install mods to improve stats, but that’s it. And since you don’t see it happen or the change reflected physically it is really as though you haven’t done it at all. 
Solution; Rework everything. V should be able to get a haircut somewhere in Night City. And ripperdocs should have some actual impact. At minimum I want to see V get sedated and then wake up groggy in the chair. Ideally I want V to be conscious and watch unique cutscenes that emphasize that my character is trading away their humanity in order to survive. And there needs to be significantly more variety in cyberware. I want to see and weigh the difference between replacing my arm with a Militech arm and or an Arisaka arm. Heck, even visibly replacing a single arm would be an improvement right now instead of this barebones flesh-colored everything stand-in.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Business Sympathy, Marketing Hype

bought this game to test my pc

A quick note: I played this on a low-end PC, but because of that, my expectations for visual bugs are lower. 

The positives:

The moment I launched Cyberpunk 2077, the game almost immediately hooked me into its immersive world of Night City. I quickly got invested in the first main mission called “The Heist”, and was even emotionally invested in the supporting character Jackie. The combat in the game is exhilarating, giving the player four main options for playing through the various missions(Guns, Hacking, Melee, and Stealth), allowing and forcing players to mix and match these to create a unique playstyle for each person. The story was so great that I played through the entire main questline without completing any side quests (Besides Panam’s and Judy’s as their questlines are attached to the main one) on my first run through. On my second run of Cyberpunk, I completed the vast majority of the side quests, leveling my character up to level 50 (the maximum level), and was shocked to find that the critical decision making found in the main quest was still largely intact in even the more mundane ‘gigs’ albeit to a lesser level. While traversing the streets of Night City, I discovered a large cast of unique characters from a talking gun or vending machine to the future mayor of the city. The impacts you have on the world are massive, from bringing down or raising up a gang, to deciding the future of the biggest corporation and even helping determine the next mayor. There are also many little secrets hidden in the game, and each of these little easter eggs gives a feeling of accomplishment when you find them (especially the one pertaining to the secret final ending). While having the internet available to us now does greatly diminish this feeling, a player is fully capable of stumbling upon them without outside help, and that fact makes them feel special. This game feels like a combination of Borderlands and the Witcher and it is pretty fun. 

Each type and subtype of gun felt special in the way they can be used. For example, a smart shotgun and a power precision rifle are vastly different in their uses, making using each type of weapon feel special. The best experience of using weapons and armor in the game involves crafting them yourself, especially because the best items you can get in the game are made not found (even if the recipe for them is found), which gives a unique experience to many people as they find the type(s) of gun, bludgeon, or sword that fits them best. Any of these legendary items can be modded and/or upgraded to be the best weapon in the game, as no type of weapon is truly better than the other. The system of mods that the game has allows for even more customization.

Stealth is a legitimate option in the game, especially when combined with hacking to allow you to defeat a group of enemies without ever firing a shot. The option of a one-hit-kill in takedowns allows for a player without great weapons to take down many foes. The vast variety of options for hacking allows a player to choose how they wish to play, without really punishing the player for not using it at all. For example, you can do anything from making machinery malfunction to causing a person to kill himself. This allows players who would rather avoid a firefight a great option for dealing with enemies.

The developers have been rapidly patching the game, and are even adding DLC “early next year”, and the biggest of the bugs have been patched by now, with more being patched every day. 
 
A quick thing about one of the controversies surrounding this game (the accusations of transphobia), Cyberpunk is in many ways criticism of consumerist culture, of both the megacorporations and the customers that make it up. Because of this, there are some advertisements that you will see in-game that are degenerate. However, in one of the most fun side quests (a racing sidequest) the main character that you are helping is a person who is transgender. 

The negatives: 

	There are many visual bugs in this game, such as glitching smoke, and textures that do not load quickly or correctly often. These issues are of course going to happen unless you have the top hardware. Sometimes these can be comical (such as NPCs randomly T-posing), but they ultimately break some of the immersion of the game. Cyberpunk 2077 is a game that requires its players to save frequently just in case of a bug that is more serious than these visual issues. For example, an NPC may not talk with you or a door might not open, or a crafting material may not appear in your inventory once you obtain it. These bugs are a much bigger problem, and although CD Projekt Red’s team is fixing these constantly, there are still many of them out there.

	On a note of lesser importance, the game fails to explain the importance of crafting, and even though I would consider myself fairly well versed in RPGs, my first playthrough did not really go into crafting, and my experience was more negative for it. The same is true for the system of mods, in which Cyberpunk does not tell you that different mods scale differently on different weapons. A combination of crafting with weapon mods greatly increases the ability of a character to take down large groups of enemies. This shows as, on my first playthrough on the ‘normal’ difficulty, there were missions that bordered on impossible for my character to complete certain main missions, compared to my second run where my character beat the hardest mission (Don’t) Fear the Reaper on his first try on the hardest difficulty. The game also poorly explains implants and hacking, both of which can be integral parts of a person’s playthrough, requiring timely and costly in-game exploration of these features (and that’s if a player knows where to look). The gathering of materials that are necessary for crafting can be a grinding pain (unless an impatient player uses item duplicating exploits) These things mean that it is hard for someone not versed in open-world RPGs to pick up Cyberpunk 2077 and understand it, which could lead to a lot of frustration. 

	While each type and subtype of gun feel quite different from each other, melee weapons (with the exception of the implants of the mantis blades and monowire) do not feel too different from each other, and have limited variety in them. Even though one of the potentially best melee weapons found in Night City is a dildo, wielding it and using a wrench in-game do not feel different.

	There are some parts of the story, specifically the side stories, that seemed to have been bigger plots to immerse oneself in, but these plots were either not fully finished or were removed (possibly due to the game’s rushed launch). For example, one of the more fascinating stories is that of the future mayor of Night City, but while you get to uncover a massive conspiracy involving them, there is nothing that comes from there. There are many situations similar to this that the player will get excited to experience only to have the rug pulled out from underneath them as they realize that the rest of the plot is not yet in the game. Inconsistencies are also present occasionally, such as the fact that although the police are withdrawn from the districts of Pacifica and the Badlands, committing crimes in either of these places will cause them to spawn on you. The police in this game also do not arrive in cars or any form of vehicle, nor do they run at you, but rather blink into existence around you. These same cops will also fire on you for being in their sight for too long (despite having not committed a crime) but will forget about any atrocities you have done if you simply run several blocks away from them.


TL;DR:
	Although Cyberpunk has more than its fair share of bugs, and it’s systems are not always fully explained to the player, the game is immersive with a fantastic story and gripping combat.

review_text:
Definitely buggy, in a 'Skyrim-at-launch' way.  Only encountered one bug that forced me to reload a save, though, when my camera detached from my model after a cutscene.

I want to say the combat is kind of nondescript, but I constantly seek out the next big fight.  I want to say the hacking is kind of basic, but I constantly prioritize expanding my deck and my programs. 
The loot treadmill is a little silly sometimes; all clothes have an armor value and you can find basketball shorts with triple the armor of your mil-tech fatigues. 
They've done a great job of incorporating your character's stats and backgrounds into your interactions with the NPCs, and to a more limited extent with the environments as well.

But I think the deciding factor in my "Very Much Recommended" is that this game is immersive in a way you can't easily define.  Whenever I check the time it's 1-2 hours later than I expected.  Maybe it's the city environments or the world building, but Cyberpunk 2077 is genuine 100% pure escapism.  

At least until you get the bug where your peepee pokes through your pants.

Still great otherwise.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Loop, RPG Integration

this game is terrible. it crashes every 5 minutes.

UPDATED 4 YEARS LATER

The game is great! I love it now.

If you didnt buy into the hype on this game you probably wont be disappointed. No it is not the open world rpg to rule all open world rpgs, but im having a great time. Combat is satisfying, visuals are excellent and the story is entertaining what more can i ask for.

So I have 33 hours on cyberpunk now. It's December 30th and I got it for Christmas. I'm not gonna say what some people might want to hear but I'll say what I truly believe about the game.

This game has a lot of bugs. It's been delayed for between a year and two, and many people are disappointed. But when you play it, it's a different feeling. Driving around the streets you can see the love they put into the game; making it look great, and building the world around you.

SLIGHT SPOILERS AHEAD.
The story I think is great. It's not just your average redemption story; Silverhand in your head really does add to it, as he converses with you time to time and you get to choose how your character interacts with him. Either he's an enemy, the guy who intervenes and contradicts your thoughts. Or, he's a friend, a guy who just wants the same thing as you: to stay alive.
The combat doesn't have many flaws either. The cover system is fine, I find it very useful for fighting high level enemies who you gotta be careful around. The guns all have their own special abilities and flaws, but ultimately you get to pick the one that fits your style. Having three weapon slots at once is great as well for quick switching and you can switch out what is in what slot anytime. The stealth is also very good. Using hacks to distract enemies is fun and the hiding containers can mostly fit more than one body for when there are a lot of enemies.

I could go on for hours about what I think about this game, but I don't want to. You should play the game yourself. In my firm opinion, the game's qualities overpower the bugs- because everyday the developers are working hard to fix them.

Cyberpunk 2077, developed by CD Projekt Red, is a monumental action role-playing game that has captured the imagination of players worldwide. Released in December 2020, the game immerses players in the dystopian future of Night City, a sprawling urban environment brimming with advanced technology, unchecked corporate power, and the struggle for identity. Despite a turbulent launch marred by technical issues, Cyberpunk 2077 remains a significant achievement in modern gaming, celebrated for its ambitious narrative, intricate design, and detailed world-building. This analysis evaluates the game's strengths and weaknesses, highlighting its profound impact on the gaming landscape.

Strengths of Cyberpunk 2077

1. Unparalleled World-Building

Night City is a testament to meticulous design and attention to detail, offering one of the most immersive open-world experiences in gaming. Its neon-soaked streets, imposing skyscrapers, and culturally distinct districts create a dynamic and authentic urban environment. Each area, from the industrial grittiness of Watson to the luxurious allure of Westbrook, feels alive and integral to the city’s identity. The game’s dynamic day-night cycle and atmospheric weather systems further enhance its realism, drawing players deeply into the world.

2. Complex Storytelling

The narrative of Cyberpunk 2077 is a compelling exploration of identity, ambition, and power. Centered on V’s struggle to remove the Johnny Silverhand engram from their mind, the story delves into existential questions and critiques of corporate greed. The main storyline is enriched by intricately crafted side quests, many of which rival the primary narrative in depth and moral complexity. These stories often challenge players with difficult choices, underscoring the game’s thematic focus on consequence and agency.

3. Customization and Playstyle Flexibility

Cyberpunk 2077 excels in character customization, allowing players to define V’s appearance, background, and skills. This freedom extends to gameplay, where diverse builds—ranging from stealth-focused netrunners to combat-heavy solos—provide multiple avenues for approaching challenges. The robust progression system, featuring perks and cyberware upgrades, ensures that players can adapt their playstyle to suit their preferences.

4. Engaging Gameplay Systems

The game offers a blend of first-person shooting, melee combat, and hacking mechanics, creating a versatile and engaging experience. The variety of weapons, gadgets, and cybernetic enhancements allows for creative problem-solving in combat and exploration. Additionally, the inclusion of drivable vehicles and fast travel contributes to a seamless traversal of Night City’s expansive terrain.

5. Exceptional Sound Design

Cyberpunk 2077’s auditory elements elevate its immersive qualities. The soundtrack’s fusion of electronic synth and intense rhythms perfectly complements the game’s tone. Moreover, the voice acting—with standout performances from Keanu Reeves as Johnny Silverhand and Cherami Leigh as female V—adds emotional weight and authenticity to the characters.

Weaknesses of Cyberpunk 2077

1. Technical Instability

The game’s launch was overshadowed by widespread technical issues, particularly on older consoles. Bugs, crashes, and performance inconsistencies severely hindered the experience for many players. Although subsequent patches have addressed numerous problems, the initial release tarnished the game’s reputation and highlighted the risks of over-ambitious development timelines.

2. Underdeveloped AI Systems

The behavior of non-playable characters (NPCs) and enemies often falls short of expectations. Pedestrians and traffic react minimally to player actions, breaking immersion, while enemy AI lacks sophistication in combat scenarios. These shortcomings detract from the otherwise vibrant world of Night City.

3. Limited Impact of Choices

While marketed as an RPG, Cyberpunk 2077’s role-playing depth is somewhat constrained. Dialogue choices and quest outcomes often lead to similar conclusions, reducing the sense of agency. Additionally, the life path system, which influences V’s backstory, has a surprisingly minimal effect on the overarching narrative.

4. Missed Gameplay Opportunities

Certain gameplay elements that were heavily promoted, such as dynamic police systems and extensive body modifications, are either underwhelming or absent. These omissions underscore the gap between the game’s initial promises and its final implementation, leaving some players feeling let down.

5. Overwhelming Interface Design

The game’s user interface can be daunting for newcomers. A cluttered map and complex menus complicate navigation, while managing inventory and upgrades requires significant effort. This steep learning curve may alienate players unfamiliar with intricate systems.

Conclusion

Cyberpunk 2077 is a game of immense ambition, characterized by its striking narrative depth and breathtaking world design. Despite its undeniable strengths, the game’s shortcomings—notably its technical instability and unrealized potential—highlight the challenges of delivering on ambitious creative visions. For players who value immersive storytelling and rich, atmospheric settings, Cyberpunk 2077 offers an unparalleled experience. However, those seeking flawless execution or seamless gameplay mechanics may find it falls short of expectations.

Ultimately, Cyberpunk 2077 stands as both a remarkable achievement and a cautionary tale in modern game development, illustrating the delicate balance between ambition and execution. Its legacy will undoubtedly shape the industry’s approach to creating expansive, narrative-driven worlds.

I'm getting 60-70 fps @1080p everything on Ultra RT on with an i7-8700 and 2080 Super.  Is it buggy? Absolutely.  I haven't run into anything quitting to the main menu and reloading couldn't fix.  Have been having a good time with the game so far.
It's good.

I didn't expect much from this game but I was still left feeling let down.

Most of my frustration (other than the wasted money) was down to not knowing what was happening. It felt like joining Games of Thrones in the 5th series! I have no idea who the character is or what they are doing. There's so much lingo in there that the story is like watching Bridge of Spies or some other film you pretend to understand, but secretly don't. You often get the chance to make conversation choices but given there are so many weird names for people, places, corporations, robots, computer chips etc I never really knew which option I should choose. It just adds to the confusion.

I was able to play on high settings at 1080p/50fps if I used Balanced FSR (it took about 3hrs of experimenting) but even the visuals didn't impress much, ...too much saturated colour for me.

I also didn't like the feel of the mechanics. It was a bit too Doom or Dishonored type feel. Some may like it but it's not for me. Maybe I just prefer third-person. I managed to get to the first 'shoot the baddies' part and I had no chance of hitting anyone unless I was really close. Even then, it seemed to take 10 headshots to drop someone, which is silly!

Also, why the character customisation (right down to pubic hair length and nipple size) if it's in first person? 

To try to acknowledge some positives...
I play on openSUSE and gtx1070 and it worked great. Not a single crash in the 8hrs I tinkered and played. I saw the odd glitch (the big guy you are with walking through a car, for instance) and the characters talking over one-another during the conversation choice scenes but nothing that would put me off a game. Is this a positive?!. The voice acting seemed OK from the bits I saw. err... 

Not a game for me.
Review_Angles: Narrative Clarity, Accessibility, Value for Money

review_text: Great Game!

Edgerunners was great.
However, this game is not comparable to edgerunners.
Edgerunners is a whole different story- so don't expect to get that from this game.

Three tomatoes are walkin' down the street. Papa Tomato, Mama Tomato and Baby Tomato. Baby Tomato starts lagging behind, and Papa Tomato gets really angry. Goes back and squishes him and says: "Ketchup!" Ketchup.

This game is great. Lots of fun, easy to get invested. The most valuable parts are with the characters. The characters make the game by making the world believable and interesting. The dialogue is expertly written, and adds a lot of intrigue to an otherwise quite empty game. 

Listen, you can easily put  70+ hours into this game just by investing in the side stories and other missions, but, at the time of writing this at launch, there game is quite empty. The main story is incredibly short, and your choices only matter during the last mission.  All choices you make beforehand do not matter and do not impact your ending whatsoever. However, doing the side missions opens unique opportunities in this last mission. 

For some poor qualities, the NPCs AI is shoddy at best. They're predictable, slow, and not much of a challenge in the later game. The only challenge being pure combat. Enemies will 2-3 shot you depending on your difficulty, but it's easy to lose them and beat them all in stealth.

You have a choice in stealth to kill or knock unconscious your opponent. This choice makes no impact on the story whatsoever and only impacts character dialogue in certain side missions. 

Police in this game are a joke. They will spawn behind you at any given moment, and know about every crime you commit. No matter what you do, if you get a police star, you are forced into combat and they begin spawning behind you. It is easy to lose them. They will not chase you in cop cars and they are easy to just run away from. Not very dynamic.

I make many comparisons to GTA V in this review, which may not be a fair comparison, but even if you look even further back to Skyrim, that game had more value in exploration and enemy AI. Items that you pick up around the world are all but useful. Only weapons and clothing have any value other than crafting schematics. In Skyrim, there were junk items but otherwise there were plenty of important non-weapons and armor you could find such as one-time spells, books, healing items, etc. This game has none of that.

I'll end this review even if this isn't a complete compilation of my experience. The game is good, and you can easily spend lots of time in it. However, this game only receives the thumbs up because I believe in its future. It needs more. I see no reason to replay this game whatsoever. The ending choices are the only ones that matter, so I'll just go back to a previous save and do the last mission again.
Dystopian future, Yes

i don't often clock in over 100 hours in a game, let alone this quickly.  having achieved 2/6 endings, there's still a wealth of content I haven't touched yet.

cyberpunk is a deeply flawed game around the edges, but at it's core sits some of the best writing and storytelling I've witnessed in video games.  if you're a sucker for storytelling, this wont let you down.

the combat ranges from functional to forgettable.  I found it to be incredibly clunky at first, but as the game progressed I grew more used to it.  I personally went in guns blazing, maxing body, handguns, and blades.  While the combat was enjoyable, my first firefight felt no different from the last one.  having a more in depth crafting system and weapon modification system would help solve this, as the current system only allows for adding scopes/silencers and a few stat amplifiers; I never felt like I had a special attachment to any of my weaponry and would swap out a gun at a moments notice if I stumbled across one with a higher DPS.  

And yet, I still found the gameplay loop to be enjoyable, as the constant switching of my loadout kept things somewhat fresh.  There are multiple ways to handle a situation, and I imagine most of my views on the combat system are due to my reluctance to try out the hacking/stealth style of gameplay until the endgame, which I found equally serviceable.  As the game continues to be patched and modders sink their teeth into this I could see myself starting a new game as a non-lethal build.  time will tell.

addressing the current state of the game (as of December 2020), it's very evident playing that mass amounts of content had to be cut from the game.  but with what the game launched with, I would still say it's worth the price.  bug wise, I only had one consistent and major bug - plants.  if a tree, bush, or flower was in render distance I would see it through walls, hills, and characters.  while this bug was relatively minor in Night city, exploring the foliage ridden wasteland outside the city was near impossible, as my screen would often be caked in half rendered scenery from 200 ft away, making spotting enemies near impossible and shattering immersion with missions.  and yet, I still found myself returning to the wasteland despite the damn plants due to the strength of the story.

is cyberpunk's story good?  very much so.
is the combat fun and engaging?  overall, yes, but nothing revolutionary.
is cyberpunk a game that calls for multiple playthroughs?  i don't know yet.

I enjoyed my time in Night City, I'm comfortable leaving this write up at that.  At the AAA price of $59.99, I'd say it's worth it.

Tips for preformance and enhancing the experience:

I recommend editing your inputContexts.xml and inputUserMappings.xml files in
Steam\steamapps\common\Cyberpunk 2077\r6\config

Line 905,906 of inputContexts.xml you can change the speed of crating and disassembling items to 0.1, wow does that make a huge difference, now I can craft 30 grenades in no time.

Also by using the Cyber Engine Tweaks (/mods/107/  on NexusMods) I was able to get another 10-15fps.

review_text:
TLDR :-
I don’t recommend the game right now. It’s too lackluster for what it’s worth. Leaving aside the buggy game, the game on its own is too stale.

Full review: -
What I dislike
1) how lackluster and how the choices made does not influence anything in the game story. I could be a bad guy on one side story and a good guy on another side story and we’ll still get the same ending. The ending is only dependent on the final missions. 

2) The open world seems full but it’s actually insanely empty. All mini side quests such as NCPD are generally the same. Run towards the NCPD assault area, kill everyone and collect the evidence. You do that for another 150 times. It’s the same thing.

3) Armor equipment feel irrelevant as any people will kill you instantly (in super hard). The power level of a weapons is insanely disproportionate. 

4) Some achievement is not doable if you made the wrong choice. You cannot reset the game or play new game plus. In addition to having leveling cap.

5) Open world but you cannot own a house, customize your own character or even your own car.

6) You cannot even take photo from an aerial view despite the beautiful scenery. 

7) The AI in the game is so bad. The police does not react but instead just teleport to you and just shoot you.

8) The obvious buggy game.

What I like: -

1) The scenery. The game despite the buggy run, does come with fine detailed in their design.
2) The music. 
3) Despite having a stale action side story, most of the side story are pretty well-written.
Review_Angles: Narrative Choices, Open World Content, Combat Balance

review_text:
TL;DR: Nothing short of adding tons of content like vehicle customization, more and/or better cosmetic character customization, combat reworks/build viability, and more interesting side missions would make me want to recommend this game to anyone at it's current price of $60. Since the above would entail a heavy development cost or dlc it's safe to say that it won't be coming. There are pieces that are great but it's unfinished. [b]Don't announce your game until it's as good as something like The Witcher 3[/b]. Don't even get me started on the 40 fps I average with a 1080....

Personally, I think it's too late for this game to make a come back. As some others have stated, the first impression is the one shot you have. It's safe to say that CDPR dropped the ball. I don't realistically see anything short of quite a few patches of free content making this even slightly better. Simply put, there's a stark lack of content and the combat gameplay loop gets old pretty quickly. You're either unloading sixty rounds into an enemy or it's a one-shot kill in terms of gun play. 

The start of the game was amazing. Three very different entrances into the main story line and I had to at least play the first mission for each beginning sequence. Unfortunately once the main portion of the game comes around there is hardly a difference save for the occasional life style speech option which in the end doesn't affect the outcome. Most of the content is shallow. This game suffers from the Ubisoft open world trope of 'there are a million things to do that are all designed to waste my time'. Plentiful side missions that are a few minutes in length to just run around and find.

[b]The big side quests are amazing and I keep seeing myself get sucked into the Nomad story line every playthrough[/b].

The player customization is pretty lackluster. I was hoping to be able to make myself a mini-Adam Smasher if I wanted to and get all chromed up. The extent of your cosmetic character customization after starting the game is being lucky enough to get clothes you like the look of that also have good armor and mod slots. If you want to buy them, the good ones are very expensive. [b]You can buy this $15,000 shirt or get freaking folding swords that pop out of your god damn arms like an alien[/b]. You want this cool freaking car? Yeah well the most expensive car in the game by far [i]can be found in a different color near the beginning of the fucking game[/i]. Save your money for weapons or upgrades. 

The crafting system is unnecessary. You have 50 levels which means 50 attribute points and 50 perk points (not counting the number of them you get for leveling up skills) and I need [i]how many[/i] to make crafting useful for anything past early game?? There isn't enough depth for the crafting system to justify existing. Sure, I can upgrade this unique item to the next rarity but doing that costs resources that are difficult to find and it just gives you an extra mod slot. No extra armor, unless you get lucky with a stat roll. The weapon and clothing mods for the most part are forgettable. 

I'm sure I could keep typing and make this as long as a research paper but it honestly isn't anything that hasn't been said before when talking about the [i]many, many, many[/i] unfinished, messy, and buggy games that have been released before.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Development Readiness

review_text: Its chrooming time

This game would have been an amazing work of art if the studio was allowed to finish it before release, sadly this was not the case here but still its a great game. 

I suggest you wait a couple of months to let the studio work out the worst of the bugs within the game through patching. Though it is still a enjoyable exeperiance as is.. but only if you have the patience to reload the game if you hit a gamebreaking bug. 

Pros- 
The world is top notch, a great fictional setting in a world set in the near future with the corporations that run the society.
Voice acting is great even if I wish some of the characters had been given even more lines.. 

Cons-
The game is buggy, estimate is that about 85% of the game was finished upon release and the rest just quickfixes to get it to run. 

Overall 
I would only recommend this for players that have the patience to deal with the bugs but give it some time and if the game is on sale later on it would be a great buy,
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, World Building, Voice Acting

review_text:
Great rpg ala the outer worlds and fallout with elements from open world titles like GTA or most notably Ubisoft. 

The best way i can describe this is if Ubisoft tried to make a fallout game. That doesnt do the art or graphics justice but the core game it self ignoring the cinematic and immersive nature of dialog... the core gameplay loop is all very familiar. Its a map game with great writing. It feels like it had the 4 years in development it actually had. 

The 8 year number you see? its when they announced they had rights to the IP and started hiring for it. For an example of this check out IO Interactives latest bond game trailer. 

If you can run it or live with lower than average performance this game is a killer "next gen" rpg but dont expect it to be star citizen in a single city like so many others did. Its just another RPG. For me that is enough, skyrim without swords and dragons? great! i dont like medieval stuff anyway. 

NPC's are the biggest con in this game. GTA III esque and its so jarring and sticks out especially after the most recent open world games like RDR2 and even Watch Dogs.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Loop, Technical Performance, Art and Narrative

They tried too hard to create something that was way out of their capabilties. I wished they had created something smaller instead of an open world so we could get a final product really polished. I believe; only a few districts open like in Deus Ex or vampire Blood line would have been a better choice. 

Low spoiler long review below -
I started the game and had to really push myself to continue playing. I started with nomad only to realize that after 15 minutes of boring story telling  and horrible car driving the "origin story" was over. 
Dragon age origin made them short but intense compared to what we get here. I get to meet my new partner and future best friend that is a real cliché, like they tried too hard to give us some gta san andreas feeling. 

When i arrived in the first district is got my second disenchantment. I did all i could not to watch any preview of the game before release and so i was expecting some real dystopic futurist city. Something alike blade runner or the fifth element. What we have is some kind of gta 4 / watch dog blend and a real feeling of emptiness. Felt really odd in what is supposed to be an overcrowded nightmare. It really hurts the feeling of immersion CDP is known for in their games. Deus ex series does it much better here. 

Main quest did not really get better as it forced me from one annoying BFF to another cliché character, an anarchist douchebag i had no other choice but to be tied with.
At this point i decided to leave the main quest side way, and to explore the city, doing jobs as the netrunner i'm supposed to be. 

The game runned well medium setting on my comp (gtx 970 - i5 4460) wich was a pleasant surprise. Loading and saving are real fast. Bugs are present but nothing game breaking. 

Jobs are all well made, giving plenty of choices (gameplay not dialogs) on how to complete them, always having some kind of backstory and i never felt restricted on how to complete them. As a stealth / hacker type, playing on hard the game fet good although you soon become really overpowered taking off any challenge.
Most fun came from side missions, some are really well thought. Also had this nice deus ex moment where game tells you to run for your life but i chose to go back and could save an ally that would have not make it otheriwse. 

This is where i spent my whole time playing, doing jobs and side missions as they came. As much as i had fun playing, the feeling of emptiness never left me. This is more an action adventure game than an rpg. Choices are really few and you never have any kind of effect on the districts no matter how hard you fight crime. At most you change some indiviual life but that's it. Game never reflects your action on the world like you could see in the gothic series or the more recent elex.

I like how some optional secondary missions really helps shaping the main 2 chars i first talked about (the BFF and the douchebag), giving them backstory and making them really more interesting than they first appear. In this aspect the game is well designed and even got some kind of liking for the second wich i would have never thought at first. 
 
Once i completed all gigs and side missions, wich took me over 70 hours, i completed the main quest. Final missions are just like the beginning, action packed more than well crafted. There are really 2 endings in 7 variations. All i did while playing, all the knowledge i accumulated on corps, gangs, powerfull people, all the money (more than 1 mill), all the allies.. all had no impact on  it. The ending i chose still felt emotional and i somehow like it, but it should have been one of many choices based on how you played the game and not be one of the 2 only available whatever you do. 

There is a lot more to be told but that is long enough. I will conclude saying :

Do not play this game expecting some kind of RPG like vampire bloodline or deus ex. Marketing clearly lies without remorse to promote games nowadays and the CDPR that built a reputation of caring for players has clearly taken a hit. This game feels like what fallout 4 is to fallout new vegas. I feel like this game will need a real Enhanced Edition like what they did for the first Witcher if they want people trust again.
Review_Angles: Game Scope, Narrative Quality, Gameplay Mechanics

review_text:
No.

Even one year later, the game is still crap. The openworld is lifeless and littered with the same issues it always had, like police spawning from thin air to pursue you.

Pros: Without doubt the best-looking game I've played, with exceptional character designs, appealing companions, and cinematic storytelling—all supported by stellar voice acting and fluid animations. The flexibility of play styles provides a fun, rewarding experience.

Cons: Halfway through the game, the immersion is fractured by the ease at which the supposedly near-apocalyptic morally ambiguous world becomes too easy to navigate. V, introduced as an underdog, suddenly becomes unstoppable—yet this meteoric rise doesn't translate into meaningful character development by the game's end. While technically stunning, the game's visual identity lacks memorability, oscillating between glossy advertisements with beautiful characters and a bland world design that fails to emotionally reinforce the story's themes. (Though perhaps this emptiness is intentional, reflecting the soulless corporate aesthetic of mindless consumerism and shallow thrills.) The main story's cinematic quality is its primary appeal, though it lacks lasting impact. While the multiple endings for main and side quests offer a refreshing departure from games that chase a single "perfect" ending, their moral implications feel hollow. Each path rewards the player regardless of their choices, reducing meaningful decisions to simple preferences—whether about rewards or one's opinion of Keanu Reeves. The endings ultimately fall short of their potential, failing to deliver genuine character growth or meaningfully resolve the moral dilemmas encountered throughout the protagonist's journey.

Conclusion: Cyberpunk 2077 is still a fun game that undoubtedly is worth the sweat and tears of many hardworking, creative individuals which alone I gladly pay for. However, I look forwards to improvements in future games, but right now, I've had enough of Night City.
Review_Angles: Visual Design, Narrative Development, Gameplay Balance

review_text:
The Good
 - Looks pretty good
 - 'Cyberpunk' aesthetic executed quite well, although with a 'pop' filter, should be grittier.
 - I've found exploring the city and completing side quests pretty enjoyable despite the legion failures. 

The Bad
 - Pointlessly frequent use of F word, half the time it feels glued in for impact
 - No Angelspit music.  This indie band's early material absolutely fits the aesthetic and deserving of a signal boost.
 - Janky at times. 
 -  Thus far in my playthrough the main plot often unnecessarily nerfs you character and closes them in in scripted environments.  Main plot is at times a terrible game for this reason, then is pretty great again once you're in the city.
 - The quest you get is the quest you do.  I was expecting a Witcher style level of world complexity.  This does not exist.
 - UI is often just bad.  It's often not clear why the target for hacks has been selected - e.g the enemy under the crosshair is ignored despite line of sight, and instead a radio far away and in no way under the crosshair is selected

In short, game needs DLC to fix its tragic simplicity.  This review started positive, but after playing through further the simplicity became more tragic.  Go play the original Deus Ex instead, it has a fleshier world.

Main story Quest. To be honest, very short, I was expecting more. Side quest, most are interesting but most of it are somewhat repeatable. I can live with the glitch for now. You can have a 100 types of different endings but in the end, player just wants to feel immersive in the game or more stuff to do.
After overcoming the bugs and glitches in the launch, this is by far one the best games i've played. The story is immerse, and makes you feel empty after it's finished. As intended, i guess?

review_text: What a wild ride, after 101.4 hours on hard, I completed everything I could think to do, while the game had the occasional bug or glitch, most of my play through was wonderful, the story telling and some of these moments where just magical and beautifully crafted, the world was richly detailed, but occasionally you would find some very lacking areas in nooks and crannies of the city but nothing to complain about. 9/10 the game doesn't really do anything new as far as gameplay, but it does everything it does well with lots of compatibility to play as you would like to play. And the really hidden gems of music like the camp fire guitar songs or on a certain yacht scene, goosebumps. 2020 was the worst year for everyone, but it ended with a delightful piece of art that managed to redeem some of this awful year. And for that, I am grateful to have gotten to experience it.
Apart of glitches, It is very good game.

Forces you to use the REDLauncher to play the game. No mention of this launcher requirement in the Store Page. If you're wondering, the launcher has ZERO additional settings for the game, except the "play" button, which doesn't necessitate additional software to play the game, instead only exists to advertise additional CDPR games, products. As usual the gaming community is useless, because not once did I see the anybody mention that a launcher is required to launch the game. And no, you cannot uninstall it because it seems to be baked into the main game installation.

EDIT:
After this review and a post I made raising awareness about the lack of transparency about the launcher requirement, my account was restricted to due to "disrespectful language" - well that seals my opinion, I'm done buying CDPR games. If criticism from gamers offends you then you're not worth my hard earned money or my genuine feedback.
Review_Angles: Store Transparency, Launcher Intrusiveness, Account Moderation

review_text: AWesome game. Just what I expected!

Some of the best RPG storytelling I have encountered in modern gaming. The voice acting is incredible, and it brings a richness to the plot lines that draw you in. I found that I was ignoring other in game activities because I wanted to pursue the current plot. I look forward to the calls and texts in the game as they provide interesting ways to interact with the world that aren’t based on DPS. It reminds me of Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind where Speachcraft was often more important than combat skills. 
I am also enjoying the skill progression mechanics as well as the crafting and other non-combat related content. I feel the game balances well, and it allows you the freedom to choose your path as much as one could in the circumstances.
The combat itself is good, but I started on Hard which has a pretty steep learning curve. Once I got some decent chrome and skills, it leveled out. 
As far as bugginess, I am only seeing what I would consider the normal amount for a game this complex. I haven’t run into reset or freezes, but you would still be wise to save often as autosaves may not allow you to get out of the jam you put yourself in. Specifically, you can work your way into areas that you can’t get out of requiring a revert to an older save. Again, similar to Morrowind, you had to take care when exploring. 

Overall: Excellent Game. 
I don’t regret buying it, and I would have happily paid full price in retrospect. If the developers add content, I will buy it.
Fantastic story. Bugs didn't break the game. Would recommend.

This game has some bugs, every game has some bugs. What this game also has is great and interesting game play, an impressive amount of landscape detail, amazing graphics if you have the card for it, and a story that is new and refreshing. It is what it is, a good game.
