The game is highly appealing to achievers because it offers lots of main and side quests and collectibles that give a sense of accomplishment to the player. It is also intended for explorers since it is an open-world game with a lot of secret locations to discover, and it also has a non-linear story that allows explorer players to choose multiple paths in the story for different experiences and outcomes. Killers would also find the game interesting due to the combat mechanics. It offers a robust combat system with a lot of guns, cyberware abilities, great gunplay, and even katana sword fighting.

The character animation is highly detailed and lifelike. The environment has a lot of neon and vibrant colors. The style is retro-futuristic with high-tech, holographic advertising, and cybernetic themes mixed with low-life visuals. In terms of VFX, there are a lot of explosions, gun fire, and hacking effects. Great environmental effects such as fog, rain, and electric sparks, among others.

The fact that the player can access buildings, rooftops, high-tech corporate offices, access to elevators, etc. gives the sensation of deep exploration in a dynamic city. The levels are designed to have multiple ways to go around. Something that I love is the way the player can interact with the elements in the levels, such as vending machines, computers, police, strangers, etc., which contributes to the feeling of a living world.
Review_Angles: Player Type Appeal, Combat Mechanics, Visual Style

review_text: I'm reasonably sure this is the first review I've ever bothered leaving on Steam. I just finished one of the endings at 49.1 hours and overall I have to give Cyberpunk 10/10. I feel sorry for the all the console players out there but as a PC gamer, I experienced only minor occasional glitches. Absolutely nothing that would entertain asking for money back on this masterpiece. I'm the type of gamer that only plays games for their story and this one knocks it out of the park! As for frame rates, I guess I didn't even look. After the opening scene, I reduced my resolution from 4k ultra to 2k ultra and never experienced so much as a single screen tear after that. Smooth as butter. I really liked this game and truly hope all the console reviews don't tank it to the point of cancelling all DLC. Thank you CD Projekt Red!

There are some bugs, yes, nothing game braking yet. The performance is okay, but really it's actually good when considering how great everything looks in mid settings.

The RPG elements are pretty standard, I have no complaints. The storytelling and world building, overall feel and tone of the game, there's nothing like it. It's on a completely different level to most games. And I've only just come out of the prologue. 

I feel like, bar the bugs and undoubtedly that has ruined some peoples' experience, you have to be on some kind of a hate trip to try and deny the game is great. So, even though I wouldn't like to review this yet, I feel like I have to recommend the game at this point to counteract the hate.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Narrative Quality, Consumer Recommendation

review_text: Lives up to the hype. One of my personal favorites of the year.

[h1] NO YOU'RE BREATHTAKING [/h1]

-if you're having audio crackling issues, go to your sound settings, find your audio device, right click it and go to properties, go to the advanced tab and change your default format to 24 bit 44100 HZ or lower. I had to do this through the focusrite program but it achieved the same thing and completely eliminated all audio crackle.-

Already run into a few bugs from AI, loot i couldn't pick up, objects disappearing etc, but overall the game feels nice to play so far. 

Performance could probably be a bit better going by feedback from others, but on an RTX 3090 + i7 7820x with 32gb ram, i'm getting 70-90fps on ultra settings with ultra raytracing and balanced DLSS @ 3440x1440, none of the dynamic fidelity stuff turned on, so i don't reaaallllly have too many complaints about performance.

Can see a lot of inspiration from The Witcher 3 in some of the ways things are done in this game, chances are if you wanted the game, you'd already have it and have been waiting for at least a few years for it though, so can't really say much other than enjoy it :)

Of all the games I could have EVER Played, i am so glad i could live in a generation to experience THIS one.
Cyberpunk 2077, and it's expansion DLC: Phantom Liberty, were life-changing experiences for me. I am a player that bought the game during its earlier years, at around the 1.2 update. I played the game during covid simply because i had nothing better to do and i was getting tired of reruns of RDR2 (though i love that game also)
Every single experience ive had in this game, has been funny, charming, tedious at times during earlier years and outright emotional in most cases. From how i played this game at a couple months post-launch, to Post-Phantom liberty, i have seen a massive change in my relationship to this game, and how i view it. And i came to grow an appretiation and downright adoration for every single reference, detail, mechanic, bug (sometimes), character, place and setting i've seen in this game, Night city is geographically a perfect size for any player new or old, and makes use of its wonderful command in colour, ambience, and roleplaying opportunities to create a custom tailored experience for every and any player looking to make their worth in Night city. And its every journey you take, from NCPD Side hustles, to side quests of a guy who cons you out of a couple bucks, to the botched heist of a lifetime. You see something fresh and new.
Phantom Liberty expands upon those same elements and turns them up to a WHOPPING Eleven! virtually every quest you do, every mission you go on, is thought out and executed by your actions alone, and should serve as a testament to all writing pieces on how to morally challenge a person, and see how far theyre willing to go for their individual desires and needs. and for each choice you make, their will always be a con. If cyberpunk had launched at this state its at now. i feel as if i'd have walked into a new world entirely... however, staying along for the journey, from buggy gigs and poor skill tree designs, to an anime that saved and rekindled the love and flame everyone had for this franchise. and to this. a climactic, ambiguous and heartbreaking finale that leaves more questions than answers, but at the same time, fulfills your every desire and expectation from a game that had so much hype initially. it may not have been perfect, but the journey that led to its destination... is its own perfection. i implore anyone, to play this game. with the Added DLC. make your own way through this story, and your own decisions.. and when you leave, you may just be a changed person
Review_Angles: Personal Value, Game Evolution, Emotional Impact

review_text: CANT STOP PLAYING IT RALLY FUN

[h3] This game, in the state that it currently is in, is the most immersive game I have ever played, bar none. [/h3]

I don't know why specifically, but this game just [i]clicks[/i] with me.

I've done several playthroughs at this point, with another ~150 hours on console as well. Every single time, I discover new details, new options, new characters, new items, new lore, new paths through scenarios, new locations, new dialogue, on and on.

[b]The one caveat I have to give,[/b] is that this game is very tempting to play like a looter-shooter. And sure, it is a lot of fun to do that, as the combat is excellent and the abilities are a blast. But I have found that getting into the [u]roleplaying[/u] aspect of this game takes it [i]SO[/i] far beyond that experience. 

[i]Cyberpunk[/i] makes it extremely easy to get completely lost in the world, events, and your character, and I highly encourage you to do so for, in my opinion, the best experience of this game. Shorter playthroughs where you don't do EVERY sidequest and only choose the ones your version of V would actually accept not only help the pacing of the game, but also allow for a totally different experience on subsequent playthroughs.

It is hard to condense everything there is to say into a short review, but I will suffice to say that if you even vaguely enjoy any open world games, the cyberpunk genre, first person shooters, immersive worlds, or story driven content, this game will blow your mind. If it's not your flavor, hey, it's not for everyone. But if you're still on board by the end of the first act, [b]  you [i]gooooottaa [/i] buy the DLC. [/b] It is 100% worth the price, even without a sale.

There have been many times that I've sat and watched the credits roll after a great game. That bittersweet feeling of the conclusion to a fantastic campaign as the names scroll up for a few minutes, and I get to think about the highlights of the game before I go on with my day. Maybe a couple chills down the spine, maybe a tear or two for a heartbreaker ending, maybe a pop-off for beating the toughest difficulty. But this game is the first time I've ever had to just sit in a stupor and reflect on my life for literal hours, long past when the credits stopped rolling.

[i]Cyberpunk 2077[/i] has done that to me 3 times now.

Needed an extra 3-6 months before it was released. The game is riddled with bugs, performance issues, night city feels like a lifeless facade with mindless zombies walking and driving down the street.

Come back in a couple of months.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, World Immersion, Release Readiness

(+) Main quest is interesting

Again, Thank you CD Projekt RED for not leaving this game. It's best game I've played.

review_text:
[h1]My review[/h1]

I am mainly going to focus on the things I didn't like about the game.
This can be considered feedback, or just a review of a picky gamer.

Here are a couple of things I really thought broke my immersion in the game: 
The most obvious one is [b]bugs[/b] of course, but those will be fixed so I won't dive deep into them.

[h1]Health bars on enemies.[/h1]
They are just bullet sponges and that annoys me quite much, I want to be able to kill someone with 1 bullet to the brain, not 20. 

[h1]Spawning enemies and NPCs out of nowhere.[/h1]
you can literally see them spawn in front of you, or the room next to you while in combat (when that's not possible). 

[h1]Dumb oblivious AI[/h1]
just standing with their backs towards you while others around them are fighting you in front of their eyes. 

[h1]Minimap.[/h1]
It is way too small while driving, I have missed so many turns because I can't watch the road and minimap at the same time. 

[h1]No 3rd person.[/h1]
I know this is a topic that is covered a lot. But I'm going to be honest, I can't enjoy an RPG game if I can't see my badass character all the time. even in the cutscenes/conversations, I would like to see my character's face while he/she is talking back. 
Only in the fighting scenes, I like to be in the first person to aim down the sights. 
There is a lot of debate about the immersion you get while playing first-person, well to be quite honest, I don't feel immersed at all. If you watch a movie you also see the characters, even the main ones. and I bet we can all get immersed in those. For some reason, I am also smaller than every single NPC in the game (maybe because I picked female, IDK). the FOV also seems to get smaller in conversations. 
So please make this an option to play in 3rd person, or someone make a mod that allows this.

[h1]The lack of freedom in the game[/h1]
This is an open world. Yet it doesn't feel that way (however I can't quite lay my finger on why it doesn't, maybe ill update in the future). 

[h1]Character creation[/h1]
CC is quite dull IMO, Can't adjust weight, Height, only 3 fixed t*t sizes. I need sliders, not fixed presets. 

[h1]Adult Content[/h1]
For a game that boasted a lot about adult content, it lacks there as well IMO. you see a couple of t*ts and a D*ck in character creation, and the same s*x scene with different NPC's, no matter what gender they are. 

[i] Its ok, not to agree with me. [/i]
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Combat Mechanics, AI Behavior

review_text: recommend this game to other players
Very good game with amazing story.

TLDR: 
The game in its current state is still fairly buggy in terms of AI, textures and minor quests; But its charm, style and action is still enough to make it a good game to pick up.

Overall this game is worth the 60$ pick up. Beginning with character customization, the choices are fairly lax, but that's expected for an action game like this. It is weird however that there is only one VA for each sex, meaning that if you chose an ethnicity that dosen't have a similar speech pattern to the VA's, it's going to seem off (much more noticable for the male character). Once in the game - make sure your drivers are up to date. Random flares, strobes and out of place textures will be apparent. The updates help tremendously, but are still visible if you look for them. AI also seems to have a difficult time in their death/sitting animations where once they are killed, they will 'pop' to other parts of the environment without warning. Lesser issues include the lack of understanding of the lingo (which will be remedied after time), strangely complicated yet simple lvl/perk system, and weird fluctuations in difficulty across the map. With all that said, it is still a good game - the story is interesting, characters are well developed, graphics are top notch and it gives you the freedom to do what you want after Act 1 (GTA style). Overall, still a good pickup if you're even remotely interested.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Character Customization

review_text:
Screw the critics, Youtubers, Journalists, whatever. This game has been one of the best games I've played ever since RDR2. I mean yeah, there's ALOT of stuff that needs improving...but omg the beautiful city--especially at night, the badlands, the storyline(so far I know they will be adding more soon but for where it's at now its pretty alright), the characters and how you can connect with them is pretty dope as well. Don't see how anyone can say that this game is lifeless because I just don't see it at all. I've played 200+ hours and i'm still finding new secrets and things that I haven't seen before. I don't know if people just expected another GTA(because that's all people compare it to for some reason) or what but I'll tell you this game exceeds GTA's storyline by a longshot(can't say anything about multiplayer because, you know). I already know imma get crap for just saying that I like the game-- and that's cool and all. But once they get this game sorted out, it will probably surpass the best open world games out there to date, in my opinion.

This game is no where near perfect, but to just flat out say that it's garbage(and i mean just straight up TRASHING the game like it's just the worst thing to ever hit the planet) just because the internet is saying it is just weird to me. 

Solid 8/10 for me, hopefully better once more content is added.

CDPR, I support you guys all the way! Can't wait for the upcoming dlc!

The main problem is in all the missing features (vehicle & character customization, in-depth hacking, additional mobility etc) that were promised and/or appeared in the demos. This paired with the 7 year waiting period and the insane hype that was created through marketing and some fake promises ended up in the game being published too early after being already delayed. It's full of (mostly) visual glitches and from time to time game breaking ones.

Overall the game isn't but most probably not worth the full price and surely doesn't live up to the expectations. In my opinion, if you have some disposable income to spend on an OK-ish game and want to play an RPG in a futuristic world, then go for it. If not, this isn't worth it.

review_text:
Been playing since launch off and on, Shadowlands has had most of my attention. The game was over-hyped and promised to play good on last gen nearly decade old consoles, which was a terrible illusion for some to say the least. This game wouldn't play on 8-10 year old PC hardware, WHY on Earth would someone expect it to play on last gen PS4 or Xbox. I mean i guess it kinda did, so that's a win. They made promises they shouldn't have was the problem imo.
Graphics are good, story line is awesome. There are some, bugs but that's almost a given(sadly) in the last 10-15 years on launch day. So far having a blast. Runs good and smooth but I do have the HW for it. Ryzen 5800x, Radeon RX6800, 32GB ram, game on NVMe drive etc. mileage will obviously vary. 

Biggest letdown is not having ray tracing capability on launch. I left Nvidia 20xx series and got a RX6800, which is an upgrade but i need my ray tracing back please lol. 

Will update review after more game time.

*Another 20 hours in and so far its mainly just a really good sci fi action RPG. Does it top the Witcher series, and especially Witcher 3? I don't think so but that doesn't make it any less awesome.

This game was sold/marketed as wanting to be highly immersive. One way to break a players immersion is to encounter a situation that doesn't make sense in the world the game is set in. There have been 2 immersion breaking problems for me.

1. There was a audio bug I had that broke immersion by creating a bit of static, and then making all voices sound a bit electronic. Now the in game phone adds an electronic filter to voices but that makes sense, so not immersion breaking. But for a character 3 feet away to sound like your on the phone with them, that breaks immersion for me. If it was just this bug I would have just waited until it was fixed to play it again.

2. During the prologue mission, you have to rescue a kidnapped woman. You find her naked in an ice filled bath tub with another body, or at least if you played on release day you find her naked, the day after release day there was an update, that made her and the other body be wearing underwear. There is another mission later on where you have to rescue a character from a group of people who record and sell snuff films. During that mission you come across a number of dead bodies that have been stripped down to their underwear. It makes no sense that the people who made snuff would go to the effort to PARTIALLY strip their victims when they are done with them. They either wouldn't make the effort, or they would go all the way. Yesterday CDPR said on their forums that this is NOT A BUG, but is working as intended. TL:DR CDPR made a design change after launch, said nothing about it for 4-5 days, when most players on steam would no longer qualify for refunds, and probably only said anything because they were getting thousands of bug reports about it, and their developers didn't want to have to keep reading the bug reports.

I am going to ask steam for a refund over this, and steam needs to allow people to get refunds even if they played for 60+ hours, because it looks like CDPR was hoping that people would think this was a bug, keep playing and then when it finally came out that it wasn't a bug, would no longer qualify for refunds.
CD Projekt Red turned this game into a masterpiece and it looks better than ever with DLSS 4.

Disclaimer: All in all I've enjoyed my time with this games, there's been a few rare bugs here and there, but for the most part of my 100+ hour single playthrough, the amount of bugs I experienced I can count on one hand, and none were game breaking.

Story wise I felt that they've done a very good job with the main story, the characters feel fleshed out and human, the scope of the story is pretty relatable and the atmosphere had me immersed for days. There were a couple of emotional twists that really caught me off guard and got me invested, though I don't want to spoil what specifically.

Gameplay was solid, guns felt pretty impactful, though I of course chose rifles and pistols mostly, only specking into melee if I needed to for missions. The ammo limits were probably the only thing that got on my nerves especially for rifle and shotgun ammo. I don't like that many missions forced me to go loud when I otherwise wouldn't, but the were thankfully uncommon.

Overall good game, weapon balance can be broken easily with certain perks and legendary grade weapons. Excellent side quests and atmosphere, the game will get better with time, and I don't have much to bash.

My current system is running an i7 7700K with a 1080 Ti, in case you were wondering my hardware.

I love the game it's amazing & it's lots of fun, so far i have like 56 hours as of this review & i barely did a few main missions, been enjoying myself doing side jobs & gigs (Which i never did in any other game of any type due to anything non main was boring af & felt like a task/grocery run, completely repetitive & boring) they're just so much fun, fully dialogued & immersive, nothing like any other games offers you when it comes to side stuff, legit it feels like you're doing main game stuff while you're not.

That being said, yes this game has it's kinks & features we all wish were in there or better then they are (such things however can be fixed/imrpoved/added), but the core game is amazing & that's one thing you can't fix if it's crap, so all the bugs & issues it has atm or lacking/bad features however can be fixed in due time.

So all in all, in my personal opinion game is worth it, if you're not a patient person then all i can say is straight up RIP, you should invest in your patience skill cuz it's worth it for this game, however i'd say wait a while before buying the game if you're not patient, as the only thing you'll end up with is lots of anger & complaints, so just wait a while for the game to receive some patches & polishes & buy later on, for anyone else who has the patience and can enjoy the game with bugs you should buy/not refund and simply stay patient like the rest of us & look forward to the amazing product this will be once it's polished out.

(Yes i know this game has far more bugs on it's release then any other game did/should have, but this gabe also shouldn't have been released for a while in my opinion & was rushed to much, but that's what you get when you rush & force for something to release, you wanted it soon/now and you got it, but with that comes the price & bugs/issues it has is said price, so deal with it it's a WIN/LOSE situation)

review_text:
I first pre-ordered Cyberpunk 2077 back in 2020. It was a joke of a game, so I returned it right away. I decided to give it a second chance now, after the "2.0" update. Unfortunately, the game is still ridiculously bad. It's one of the worst gameplay experiences I’ve ever had.

It pretends to be an RPG but plays like a looter shooter. The mechanics feel wooden and unnatural. Shooting is unsatisfying, and enemies are just bullet sponges. It still feels like over half of the features they originally promised are missing, and the things they did add are half-hearted jokes. Police? Don’t make me laugh.

Now, the most important thing: the plot. It’s pointless, dumb, and lazily written. The background choice still means nothing. If the developers had any decency, they would have removed it altogether—because right now, it feels like the game is spitting in your face. You should just start as a generic mercenary from the beginning. It wouldn’t change anything, but at least it would spare you some frustration.

Now for the main story: So you kill the CEO of the most powerful company in the world and steal cutting-edge, top-secret, world-changing technology. You survive, stay in the same city (even the same apartment!), use the same name—and nobody is looking for you? Seriously? In one of the story paths, you used to work for them—they should know everything about you. There are dozens of things like that that make no sense.

You have virtually no real choices. The missions are repetitive and linear. Open world is glitchy and lifeless. NPCs are dumb and unconvincing. The dialogue is so lazily written it’s painful. Your character is the biggest douchebag alive, and you can't do anything to change that.

I could go on and on, but the bottom line is this: it’s a very bad game with some really nice art style.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Mechanics, RPG Features, Narrative Quality

In 2077, the storm of world war had come again. In two brief hours, most of the planet was reduced to cinders and from the ashes of nuclear devastation, a new civilization would struggle to arise. A few were able to reach the relative safety of the large underground vaults. Your family was part of that group that entered Vault Thirteen. Imprisoned safely behind the large Vault door, under a mountain of stone, a generation has lived without knowledge of the outside world. Life in the Vault is about to change.

Still waiting for DLC.

GPU: NVIDIA RTX 2060
CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 2700 X Eight Core

I will start out by acknowledging the hard to love parts of the current game.

This game is obviously buggy af. I won't go into detail because I personally have not experienced relatively any game breaking bugs. I had a side mission I could not complete because it would not give me a button prompt to pick up the objective. But that's the only one. The bugs that I have experienced thus far have honestly just been hilarious and have added to the charm of the game for me. 

Now to the good part.

I have honestly fallen in love with this game. 

-The story is pretty great (although there are 1 or 2 obvious plot holes that I identified on my first playthrough) 

-The world sucks you in and makes you just get completely lost in immersion for HOURS 

-I got really attached to the characters too. Every time Panam would call, I would light up like a f@cking tree on Christmans day. I don't even get that attached to girlfriends I've had in real life. But somehow this game had me hooked on "My" love life 

-The ending that I chose honestly almost brought me to tears because of how sweet and heartwarming it was 

-The advancement in the game is pretty well thought out too. Although it's not as in depth as what they made it sound in interviews. 

-crafting is pretty rough in the game rn. It takes FOREVER to grind out crafting materials sometimes. Finding decent crafting schematics is also a pain.

-Armor/clothing honestly sucks in my opinion. There needs to be some kind of transmog option so that I can look the way I want to and have decent protection. I spent most of the game with a stat penalty because I didn't want to look like a complete doofus as I played the game.

-Weapons are pretty dope. I wish customization was little more in depth. Maybe add weapon skins or more attatchment variation.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Narrative Quality, World Immersion

Let me just say before anything else, this game has problems without a doubt.

The optimisation of the game overall is relatively poor. I run most games at a solid 100+ fps, and cyberpunk can dip to as low as 30 in more denser areas of the game.

Characters and vehicles often are not fully rendered when approached and the game will take a few extra seconds to fully render them.

Lip syncing works about 80% of the time, and can be a little distracting when it doesn't.

Dialogues often layer on top of one another, so you'll have 2 conversations at once occurring.

A few of the hitboxes around objects are bugged, so that standing inside them will insta-kill you, although this has only happened to me once so far.


With all my gripes about the game said, I can also say that the reason im giving this a positive review, is that the game is fun to play, even past all this. The storey is engaging and the side quests give a lot of volume to the city, making it feel more in depth than just what the main storey can provide, and this is also where i've found most of my enjoyment.

The game is very nice to look at, given you have a decent frame-rate and turn off motion blur.

The driving feels pretty clunky when you start off. Curbs launch you much higher than expected, and turning is slow (unless you brake and accelerate). However as you understand how the cars handle, this can be pretty fun to get around, and if you can't get around that, then the higher quality cars often have better handling, acceleration, and suspension as to be expected and make the driving feel rewarding.

The gunplay is pretty great actually, bullets penetrate object that you'd expect them to, recoil is manage-agable, and gets better the more you understand the recoil pattern. There is a lot of room to specialise in the perk trees, so that if you find you really 'click' with a certain weapon class, you can dump points into it and get great benefits that encourage you to use the playstyle you enjoy the most.


Thats about all i've got, although i would HEAVILY recommend coming back to this game in a few months, hopefully after the game has received some much needed optimisation patches and bug fixes.
Honestly love it in its current state and only bugs I've encountered are just funny visual ones that made me laugh

I really want to like this game, but after waiting 3 years for bugs to be ironed out on PC, I find I am plagued with a horrible audio and FPS drop bug that is so bad, it is unplayable.

The first 28 hours of the game were great (I wished I could play more). However, as soon as I hit my first gig with a Cyberpsycho, it went to crap. I started getting stuttering, crackling, and finally a full freeze . I thought this could have been a standard blip in the system, as nothing presented like this previously, but after restarting, it did not get better. It actually started to get worse.

I was getting drops of 57 with highs to 84 FPS running at 3840 X 2160 resolution with RT on with a RTX 3080 ,i7-10700. After this crash I cannot get my FPS to get over 25 and it tanks to lows of 7, and the sound crunching, crackling, and popping rolls right along with it. I have tried everything to turning all graphics settings to low or off (does not change frame rate), tried lowering my resolution (does not change frame rate), turning RT off (does not change frame rate), and ensuring NVIDIA drivers are updated, and they were. For sound I tried turning on/off every sound setting within the game system, tried lowering sampling rate, exhausted every video and blog link of common fixes, and none are working to even include turning off controller volume and haptic even though I use keyboard and mouse, cause this is a known issue. I also tried using the Realtek inputs instead of  NVIDIA  and...NOTHING!  Uninstalled, reinstalled twice, and removed all residual files manually...started new game, crackling and low FPS before I even get out of the tutorial.  I thought my graphics card might be the issue and ran a benchmark with Superposition and got decent scores on a 4K optimized run with over 100 FPS. The graphically modded Fallout 4 that I played before this game was of no concern either. 

This is so disappointing. I know from many threads that I am not the only one to experience this, but it is so sad, because it was running well and suddenly mid game, out of the blue it is completely unplayable. It is too bad. My only positive at this point is that I did not pay full price, but still over 70 CAD is a lot for a nerfed game.

UPDATE: I got the game running again after searching my computer for all Cyberpunk residual files after uninstall, deleting them, and fresh installed. Played for another 30 hours and bang, major frame drop. This time I tweaked my settings to get anywhere from 80 to over 100 frames during game play and loading screens were way over that. I ran MSI Afterburner to monitor and everything was good, CPU and GPU were performing well, and temps were 71 to 76C. Then suddenly (mid game) again for no reason I am getting 1-25 FPS. I cannot figure this out. I tried loading a previous save, I checked file integrity, I tried switching up DLSS settings and nothing works. I have never had this happen on any game before, and am not even sure I want to uninstall and reinstall again to get this working for a third time.
Lots of glitches but extremely great and enjoyable game.

This is a game with next-gen graphics and last-gen (or even previous-gen) everything else.  

The bugs aren't even in the top 3 problems this game has. Beneath the pretty graphics it's a very shallow game. The amazing-looking city is just a non-interactive facade - there isn't anything to do in the city besides kill criminals, pick up quests, and buy stuff from the lame shops. 

It is indeed an RPG in the sense that you can spec your character for difference combat styles, but from a gameplay perspective there's not much point because the game is very easy and somewhat unbalanced. The skills are plenty but a lot of them are useless. Vanilla combat gameplay is boring, so I recommend spec-ing into something more exotic just for the cool factor and to spice up battles.
Roleplaying during quests/interactions is there, I guess. The whole "different starting lifestyles" thing is basically a scam by CDPR - it makes a difference in the first 20 minutes and afterwards it has a minuscule effect in the game.  
There's a lot of quests, but the majority are the so called side-gigs, which are 90% repetitive trash. The actual side-quests are pretty decent though.

There's a big list of other promised but missing things, but it's been talked enough about those, I can't be bothered repeating.

Here are couple of good things about the game though, off the top of my head:
- The city is breathtaking. It's massive, it looks amazing and it's obviously crafted with lots of love. Sometimes you just want to drive around, jump on rooftops, and explore. There's always a new neighbourhood or street to discover and explore. Double jump parkour is very fun, although there isn't anything to explore up high except cool sights.
- I liked a lot of the characters, they are well made. Keanu actually really surprised me, he fits the role nicely. Female V voice actress is amazing - if you ever decide to play the game, play as female V! There's a lot of great voice acting all around.
- Main quest was also a pleasant surprise. It's a cool story and some of the endings really get to you, especially the bad ones.
- Couple of really good side-quests. Great, even.

[b]I sincerely doubt that the game that was promised/hyped will be delivered until the end of year 2021.[/b]

That said, I still enjoyed playing because the game still makes my brain release a couple of molecules of serotonin.
Review_Angles: Graphics Quality, Gameplay Depth, RPG Mechanics

review_text:
Cyberpunk 2077 deserves all the praise it’s getting—a development comeback like no other. I’m not usually captivated by many games, but I haven’t been this emotionally invested since I had to replay GTA V after realizing I accidentally didn’t save Trevor.

Cyberpunk's ending hits hard, but life is hard in Night City, as it should be—making it an almost once-in-a-lifetime gem that stayed true to its roots, delivered on its promise, and then some. What a ride.

Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Narrative Quality, Release Expectations

review_text:
So folks i'm Playing on i7-7700 and GTX 1060 playing on M&K. Simply leading to Graphics set at medium with no DLSS or Ray Tracing. Lowered the setting more that what may be required but i'm getting a wide range of fps fluctuation between 40-245 when keeping it uncapped. The game is not as incredibly optimised or polished as it could've been. And yes it has visual bugs. Cars in cutscenes starting boxy and rendering as the scene moves. Trousers going skin coloured and making my V into a kendall at times. Calls not closing in time. Not being able to pick up items right outside my apartment.

But it's a damn good game. I'm yet to experience most of the supposed best parts of it. And i'd like to complete every mission and get all the content, I also understand that it may lead to some frustrations along the way for me as i might not be able to get to everything due to some random bugs cropping up. Frankly most of the bugs are funnier than irritating. It's easy to disparage the studio for the current state of a game that was anticipated as a generation defining treat. But you have to realise the sheer range of platforms and configurations they have to support, across generations. A driver update between my first and second launch of the game made a whole bunch of difference. More than anything this should tell all the well meaning critics about how the game they've been waiting for is still a little ahead of the hardware and software combo we have. I see the potential for it to be even more amazing than it currently is and not being able to abide by some funny distractions while enjoying something at the zenith of games as we know it makes us more entitled than any of us have the right to be. If you can't even make these concessions, then just treat it as an early access and be glad that you can experience something like this in the making while you play it again and again and again, improving each time you go through a genuine playthrough. With the early access approach you may even come to appreciate the advances better than what you would've if it came out all polished, already having exhausted it's potential of growth.

Coming down to the elements of the game.
> Gun play is simply fun. 
With barely any mods and upgrades or cybernetics one can still enjoy the snappy trigger and fluid movements. you hear a lot about enemies being bullet sponges, well go and play some other games you'll see the range we've been through and if you can see how those mechanics and balances made sense when they happened you'll find no qualms with the gunplay. And far as i can tell it's only going to get better as i progress through skills and proficiency.

> Movement is simply fluid 
and feels pretty good even when the fps drops to 40, and that's saying something. Feels better than most modern games. Need to experience more of the game to say anything more on this, but why take my word for it, go experience it for yourself.

> Driving can be better, but ways better than a ton of rpgs
The cars feel a bit loose when taking turns, but gets better when you slow down enough. Seems intentional, may need some calibration or if subsequent patches let it to adapt the driving as it does with weapons it'll be even better. #FeatureRequest.

> NPC Interactions give a decent range of dialogues and reactivity
It's nice to see this range and how these can affect the state of the game. It can be better, but i'm yet to experience the new choices that come with cool points. Randomly generated NPC AI isn't that good, even the models repeat sooner than expected when i run around the map but a simple interactions while walking down the corridors where a gang member was harassing a visiting npc and being able to interrupt them and deal with the situation was something fairly rewarding early on.

> Tutorials can seem too simple
Early on you get combat, stealth and hacking tutorials. They are fairly straightforward and uncomplicated. to me they felt a bit lack-lustre given the build up and the said improvement over it. But it was enough to easily help me take down a machine gun wielding thug surrounded by his lackeys without taking a single hit - with the stealth approach as well as the guns blazing approach after a tactical recon. Seems to me that since the game is supposed to serve a very wide audience and the makers want us to experience things first hand in the game world than in tutorials it was a calculated choice of just giving enough of a tutorial for absolute beginners. Lesson learned, if you pay attention to the tutorial and keep your wits about you it'll click nicely. if you're just going to a be gun/blade toting pleab, you will feel cramped and bogged down with the mechanics but that's entirely on you. It's a brutal world in the night city, you have to deal with it as the NPCs would have to. That being said, i'd love to get a training mode or arcade battle sim where i can play around as one of the pleabs when i want to. #FeatureRequest if anybody is taking them.

In all I've experienced as of now, i'd rate it 8.5/10. (only coz I'm more of a sucker for games like Dragon Age & Mass Effect where you fall in love with or hate the same characters depending on how you are, not sure i see that potential in this yet.)

There's much for me to still explore and the opinions stated above as subject to changes as i experience more of the game. But right now
The game is FUN. 
The world massive 
and the potential for growth, unmeasured but tending higher with each sequence of the game.

Hope you have fun playing it. Would definitely Recommend
PS: First game I've ever pre-ordered and not regretting it a bit.

I never played it back when it came out and got all the hat. As it stands now i think its an incredible game. The story is excellent and captivating. The game play is super fun. I was sad when it ended.

I am loving this game so far. This is same kind of feeling that I had when first time I entered City 17 in Half-life 2. The city is full of activities. There are many people walking around and doing their things. I believe Night City is the main character of the game and developer highlighted that very well. The ads , cars , clothes, foods, guns etc... all are futuristic and how it supposed to be in Cyberpunk genre world. I am ready to spend hundreds of hours into the game and explore each and every inch of the city.

Now few things related to graphics. 

My rig

Intel Core i7 9700F
Nvidia GeForce RTX 2060 Super
16 GB DDR4 2666
ASrock B365M IB-R
ADATA SSD 512 GB
LG 1440p 144Hz 27 inch monitor

As you can see I have decent setup. I am able to run game at 70 FPS at 1440p with all settings on HIGH with Volumatric Cloud and RTX off and DLSS on balanced. Just do what I did.

(1) Make sure you install game on SSD or NVME drive and make sure game is upto date.
(2) Download latest GeForce driver. This is extremely important. Your game will CTD without it
(3) Run game at least once. Go to GeForce Experience and click on "details" under Cyberpunk 2077 and click on Optimize. This will set the graphics settings according to your system. This can be base line. From here you can lower or higher the individual settings according to your need.
(4) Go to most populated area in the city and check the FPS (Use MSI Afterburner for it). Remember game should run at least 60 FPS in order consider as playable. But you can play game at 30-40 FPS as well like you would do on most consoles. 

If you are not getting enough FPS. Do following

(1) Turn off RTX if you have that option. 
(2) Set DLSS on balanced if you have that option.
(3) Turn off Volumetric Cloud.
(4) Set Crowd density to Medium or Low. This should not impact Game or its quests. It will be just less people on street. This also should fix few graphical glitches happening here and there.
(5) Adjust any Shadow related settings as per your need.

This will take me to 70-80 FPS on 1440p which is much better then I was hoping when I checked few sites who ran benchmark before game release. I think CDPR improved performance with their patches and I am hopping for them to do more in future. Now I can lower my resolution to 1080p which should give me good performance even with RTX on but I would rather get higher resolution then turning on the RTX. On Witcher 3 , I am getting 80-90 FPS with 1440p with all set at ULTRA. 

Those who has old setup , remember this is very complex game (never seen this much complex game before) with very high graphic demand. So if you are struggling with FPS then It is good time to upgrade the system. When I say complex game in the sense it has lot of objects , animations , light sources , shadows etc in the single frame which require lot of CPU or GPU power to handle it correctly. Please don't blame developer if you are unable to run the game on your old machine. The game requires little bit more hardware then Witcher 3.

Also remember CDPR did big jump from Witcher 3 (Fantasy settings , Third person , Swords and shields, Horses) to Cyberpunk 2077 (Futuristic Cyberpunk setting , First Person, Guns and cars) So you can expect few glitches here and there but I can be sure that CDPR will fix most of these issues with their patches. I don't mind downloading 100 GB of patches if it makes game better.

I will add more of my review here but now it is time to get lost in Night city one more time.
The issues with this game are largely limited to the console version.  I highly endorse it for PC.

It is a good game, not a great game, not a bad game. Worth it in a sale.
Story and acting are excellent, atmosphere is great, and combat is fun.
Most of the "spells" are fun and none felt completely useless.

However, the crafting, armour/weapon system and perks are a bit of a lackluster. especially the weapon and armour upgrades.
The world is beautiful, but feels often somewhat hollow. 
Some side quests and all miscellaneous jobs get very repetitive quickly.

The game also requires a very beefy PC to run on higher settings.
GTX1070 + 6600K provided stable 60+ fps on medium-low settings.
RTX TITAN + Ryzen 5600X provided stable 100+ fps with everything maxed out. Though drops happened to 40 fps, but GSYNC thankfully negated the stutter. 

Experience excellent story and visuals, and prepare to be bored if you want to complete every minor job. 
Also remember to check your hardware compatibility, as this game is very demanding graphics wise.

review_text: Should've been delayed for at least 2 more years. -_-
Uhm, this is like revolutionary.

Warning, this review was made for v1.03 of the game. If developers gonna push some patches I'll update this review ASAP.

EDIT: Updated after 1.61 Edgerunners update

First of all, I'm huge fan of CD Project Red games and know the way they are released. Cyberpunk, like his younger brother The Witcher 3, was released pretty "raw". And by "raw" I mean really raw. Flying cars, T-posed NPCs, softlocks in story mode and etc, made it, if not the worst, but one of the worst releases, probably in whole game history. But, as time passes, the more and more fixes were released. And after almost 2 years of "after-development", it's in the state, where players can finally enjoy the game. Also, I need to mention huge base of mod creators, whose huge work has been done to fix or add some features (cyberlimbs / fixing vehicle handling / wall climbing , etc).
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Post-Launch Support, Modding Community

review_text: Very good game. Not bad as during the launch time, it seems.

I'm honestly having a lot of fun with Cyberpunk and after as much as I've played there's still content to explore. There was clearly a ton of effort put into the dialogue of the story and the world lore. There's a lot of fun little side quests to find, and I recommend doing them between the main story quests rather than leaving them until you have nothing else to do in the game. There are obviously a lot of issues with the game still, such as bugs and poor optimization overall.. CDPR clearly released this game before it was ready and hopefully we can see improvements in the near future. I hope QOL features will be added, like being able to customize your character's hair/makeup after initial creation or at LEAST a hide helmet button. Overall worth the purchase.

Game's good. Kind of a dream game for me really.
Big fan of the cyberpunk genre, good media is very hard to find.
Got excited for this game in 2013, but kept away from crazed fanatics hyping it up beyond reality.
Very happy with what I got, just about everything I hoped it would be and more. Can't wait to play it for years and years (after exam season is over).

And even if I do get tired of playing it, I can use it as a benchmark for new hardware. It'll be one of those games you boot up and play every time you get a new graphics card to see the game again with higher settings and better performance. Absolutely beautiful

Some technical issues that I'm entirely sure will get fixed in the coming months, but nothing too bad.
I'll write a more detailed review once I finish the main story I guess.
This is a pure masterpiece. I'm really grateful to the developers of this game for creating this amazing iimersive story

Yeah it's pretty good in 2024. Especially with 60+ mods (graphical, gameplay, immersion etc.).

And while even tweaked a bit, it honestly isn't the best game in a few ways, but still has many VERY memorable moments. And can be tons of fun once you learn various ways to complete the combat loop. Great world, art design & atmosphere, incredibly on point soundtrack, & a top tier DLC.

Many character build options. I like the cyberware system, and how armor is mostly tied to it. So your fashion can be whatever you want with virtually no penalty. 

Perks (skills) can be mostly be respecced anywhere, which is neat (say you want to switch from a proficiency in smart weapons, to katanas or something...). Base skill points a bit more work to re-do though, haha. 

And gaining certain bonuses for doing various actions (stealth, hacking, melee etc.) I always liked in games as well.

While subsequent playthroughs in years to come should still be fun, this is a game that has some real magic in your initial one, that's for sure. Among my favorite games I would say.

EDIT: A good 100+ hours into another playthrough a year later. And out of all the people who worked on this game, I feel the writers involved were the ones that worked the hardest. 

Sure, there were many things put directly into it from the existing cyberpunk universe, but there's an amazing amount of connectivity and uniqueness/detail with many places, characters, events etc. that if you pick up on (probably impossible if you're new to it, lol) makes everything feel quite alive. And can give many of your actions more weight to them.

Even though they're less and less these days, nitpicky and/or overall negative reviews of this game are kind of depressing, considering the achievement it is when you put it all together...
Review_Angles: Modded Experience, Gameplay Customization, World Atmosphere

review_text: sketchy launch but its getting better

This game is hardly perfect but goddamn did I have a blast.

Now, what are you waiting for?

This is one of the games, if not the only game, that motivated me to try to get 100% achievements. As a somewhat casual gamer, this is a testament to how impressive Cyberpunk 2077 is as a game. 

-----
Pros
-----
*Stellar main story
*DLC is an improvement on said main story
*Most weapons are viable
*Plenty of replayability when it comes to missions
*Engaging gameplay
-----
Cons
-----
*DO NOT use vehicle explosions to kill enemies unless you like losing out on loot. This bug causes loot that can normally be collected to no longer be able to be picked up, despite the game telling you otherwise.

Use explosives at your own risk, since I am unsure whether or not they also cause the same problem, for it has been a while since I last played, though this problem occured for me even after the most recent update. 
*There are still other bugs that can break immersion in the story, although those were quite rare in my pov
*WHY AM I ONLY ALLOWED TO RESPEC ONCE??????? It frustrated me to no end after 100 hours on my save that I realized that I wanted to respec some of my perk points elsewhere, but I couldn't. Apparently there was a method to do so, but the devs, for whatever reason, patched this out. WHYYY?
Review_Angles: Narrative Quality, Gameplay Engagement, Technical Stability

review_text:
I just finished my 1st playthrough after 100+ hours and i LOVE this game and can't wait to start my 2nd character.
I was fortunate to play the game on a high-end PC so i didn't have alot of the problems people were having.

All this game does is crash. That's it. Want to play as Corpo or Street Kid? Nope, game will crash after load screen. I can at least start to fix the car as a Nomad but it crashes right after.  Really CDProject? This is prety bad.... 

Don't buy, wait until they actually finish the game.

**After tons of testing I found out that ray tracing and DLSS was causing most of my crashing issues. My PC is able to handle those features on other games no problem so it has to be part of the game's optimization. That was after downloading the latest drivers and re-installing Cyberpunk as well. Oh and that only solved "most" of my crashing issues, game still crashes on it's own every 20 mins or so. Still not changing my review, this game was not ready for launch. **
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Game Optimization, Launch Readiness

review_text:
Pro:
-The city look good.
-The story is decent.

Cons:
-The AI feels like its been written with two lines of code. I coded better AI for my school projects.
-Perks are all just generic boring stats boost.
-There is only 1 implants that change your look, the arms one, that's it.
-Mantis blade in photo mode gives you 2 pair of arms.
-Explosive cans kill you in 1 shot even at endgame level.
-Mantis blade finish animation lock you in place and get you killed all the time.
-No 3rd person view. 
-The character shadow animations shows that the game is unfinished.
-First time that you get an implant, you get a very cool scene, but after that its just like swapping any other items. I really expected more than that after the trailers.
-Hand to hand fight is super hard but not in a good/fun way.
-You are the only one riding a motorcycle in the entire world.
-They removed most interesting features from the game.
-The 3 startup backstory choice you get doesn't matter at all.
-Bugs, toons of gamebreaking bugs.
-Its not a RPG at all, your choices doesnt matter much.
Review_Angles: Visual Quality, Technical Stability, Gameplay Balance

review_text: Even if this game was bug-free, it would still be a mediocre at best action adventure game. Passable story, terrible AI, a shallow open world, and an utter lack of most of the RPG elements the game was sold on.

Tedious.

Uninspiring characters, boring dialogue and the game will go to great lengths to keep you away from making any meaningful choices or even engaging with the mechanics (seriously, let me drive, Jackie!)

Probably won't pick this back up.
They lied about the system requirements. Don't buy it.
Glitchy? Yes. Fantastic? Absolutely.

Regarding the bugs:

I've encountered only 2 T-posing NPCs, as well as two game-breaking bugs that required reloading previous saves and a couple small bugs that were only slight, temporary nuisances.

In my opinion, the sheer amount of stuff to do, the variety of ways to approach quests and side missions, the excellent voice acting, the great music, the absolutely vast and architecturally diverse cityscape to explore, the unexpected surprises and new discoveries, the fantastic graphics, and the decent combat make this all worth it - despite the bugs.

I've only scratched the surface regarding the main quests so I expect to be able to spend many, many more hours enjoying this before I finish it or get bored. It may not be perfect, but it's one of the best games of its type that I've ever played.

AFTER COMPLETING THE MAIN STORYLINE:

Wow!

Definitely worth it. I have no regrets for having picked this one up, even if it had some issues. I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

By the seventieth hour, I had reached the end of my patience for the repetitive combat and mindless 'gig' sidequests. That said, if I wanted to play this game to total completion, I could easily out in the same amount of hours again.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Content Variety, Production Quality

review_text: California sucks

Despite a horrific launch, CD Projekt Red has kept pouring their soul into this game to make it what it is today. The world is alive despite a few minor bugs that can break the immersion, the graphics are obviously some of the best in the market and although ironic considering the companies' practices, the story sure as hell is good. It presents an unforgettable cast that all have their ambitions and experiences. This game keeps the morally ambiguous quests from the Witcher 3 and expands upon them making every side quest memorable. The gameplay is honestly rather fun and varied although it can feel too easy sometimes while other times the enemies are bullet tanks. I really loved this game and although it may not be perfect, it's one of my favourite games. I recommend this to anyone, especially those who loved the Witcher 3.

review_text: Johnny SilverChungus is breathtaking 100

Just as with Witcher 3, by the time I was nearing the end of the Cyberpunk 2077 main story, I couldn't wait to finish it just so that I could play the whole game over again from the beginning. I loved it.

Pros: CDPR, one of my favorite developers. They really put effort and passion into everything. Notice there is no nickel and dime micro transactions in their games. Notice they continue to improve and fix their games and offer free DLC. They are basically the opposite of Electronic Arts.
As you can expect from a CDPR title, the writing/dialogue and voice acting is all spectacular. The world is very immersive and my decisions really feel like they matter. How you speak to people can even radically change the outcome of certain events. There is very little hand holding here, you can fail entire quests and make enemies of whole groups just by being rude.
The gameplay is great. The gunplay is awesome. The cyberware is a nice touch and the depth in which you can upgrade your character really is top notch in terms of role playing.
Speaking of gunplay, the sound effects are very high quality and that is a huge factor in enjoyment for me. The melee system is quite nice as well. While it isn't perfect, it is pretty darn good and I hope to see a first person Witcher like this one day.
Even the vehicle physics are pretty impressive despite being highly arcadey.
The game runs very smooth and is well optimized for how giant this detailed area is. Some may complain of poor performance but the game genuinely requires a strong PC. I initially had to have settings rather low to get decent FPS but after building a new PC, I max out all settings (except DLSS at balanced) and I keep a solid 60 with v-sync enabled. FPS rarely ever dips below 54 or so running at 1440p ultrawide.

Cons: the crafting system is cool and all but upgrading your gear is a bit tedious. As you level up, you have to either acquire new gear to stay on top of things or upgrade your existing stuff which can take enormous amounts of materials in the long run. It is a minor annoyance.
There are still plenty of small bugs, the game is simply too complex to not have them. Nothing game breaking but sometimes immersion breaking though.

EDIT: Thought of a new con however there is an easy workaround for it. Just as with Witcher 3, you start at level 1 and there are areas you can't go...I mean you CAN go there but you'll die easily. I hated that in Witcher 3 because I was supposed to be the hero, the master monster slayer... Same with this game, why is one guy able to shoot me dead in 2 hits whereas another guy with the same gun in a different area can shoot me 20 times and I survive? It's a little immersion breaking. So there is a mod you can get on NexusMods which will make everyone the same level as you are all the time. There are other versions of the mod too but I am LOVING the game even more now that I can go where I want when I want right at the beginning of the game and it's always synced to my level so it poses a decent challenge consistently across the board.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Narrative Quality, Player Agency

Fun setting and solid combat/stealth mechanics.

The cyber mods are a great bit of power progression and allow you to make meaningful decisions to affect how your character plays. The weapons and perk systems pair well with this feature and make combat feel varied and interesting. 

Stealth is handled fairly well in the game. Requiring a good use of patience and quick hacks, you feel like some sort of action movie spy breaking into hideouts and neutralizing targets. Stealth is definitely optimal for most missions, but you still have the option of fighting your way out if you can handle the ensuing gun battle. 

Character customization is solid. My only real gripes are the lack of tattoo customization and of customizing body types. The transmog system is solid and intuitive, being a nice quality of life edition.

Game is still buggy, but usually the funny kind. Does kind of take you out of immersive moments when a characters cigarette floats a foot away from their hand.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Mechanics, Progression Systems, Character Customization

review_text: this game is addicting, i cant stop playing

This game makes me sad. I went into this game with a certain expectation. We all remember the horrible start it had, all the bugs and glitches, the controversies surrounding the company and the game's management. So I was thinking: "Hey! You wanted to play this when it came out but decided against it because of all that bullshit. Give them some time to fix it up. So it has been about 8-9 months since the release, things should be better by now. The game is on a discount, €40, might as well grab it and give it a go." And that is where the shitshow started. Let's start with the bad first, for no real reason other than I have negative emotions towards this game. I'm just gonna list a few things here that annoyed me.

Even after all this time, the game is still full of graphic bugs, something I would have expected to be better after all this time (maybe it is better, and it has been way worse, who knows). So I was looking through the settings to make things more bearable for me and found this "slow HDD mode", I though: "Hey maybe I should enable that and see what happens, maybe my data medium  isn't good enough and this fixes a few things" ... It did ... but also made a ton of other graphic issues appear.

The fighting: It's not my cup of tea really, I usually don't have a problem with this looter shooter gameplay style where numbers decide who you can fight and who not, event though they don't look any different than any of the other low level grunts you have been killing for hours. But it just felt off for me here. The parts I probably had the most fun with it were when it was disabled while playing Jonny Silverhand in flashbacks and being able to kill with clean headshots. Stealthing and stealth takedowns looks embarrassing and feel weak most of the time.

The main character, is fine ... for the most part, but sometimes I would have wished for a bigger range of dialogue options to play him, because he sometimes (and the way I played him that was out of character) felt like a complete asshole.

The cars feel floaty to drive at best and like an ice level in a platformer at worst. Not helped by the GPS, that seemingly at random switches between bee-line and roads, making navigation more of a hassle than it should be. ALSO, not helped by cars randomly despawning and spawning in again (I'm talking about driving on an empty road and a car spawning RIGHT in my car, creating an awkward crash that bugs me in the ground or high up into the air). This is especially fun when you have to chase someone down, leading to crashes you had no way to avoid. Cars sometimes just stopped working when I drove them. This usually happened around mission areas, so I guess there is a connection to that, this didn't bother me too much at first ... BUT it kept on happening and happening and happening, making me abandon my car sometimes in the middle of the desert and having to walk to the next street to call it again ... NO IM NOT PISSED, WHO THINKS THAT?!! Anyway, one more thing to the cars, the game has GTA syndrome, meaning that it is very inconsistent what you can and can't destroy while driving.

Sex everywhere: You can't go down a single street without seeing some picture with someone posing suggestively. I feel like this entire city is build on sex. There are strip clubs..., bars with strip clubs integrated, erotic stores and places you don't get fucked ... but your brain does. Well it was their vision for the game's art style, so I can't be too mad about it, didn't stop me from getting annoyed by it though.

Character AI forgetting that it has said AI and just stops dead in its path for no real seeable reason.

Quests can be a little broken sometimes. I remember this one quest where you had to pick up a key to open a drawer, it would respawn shortly after picking it up, not updating any quest markers. I later found, searching for a solution on the internet, out that the key wasn't mandatory to pick up to progress, but at that point I had no clue to that circumstance and just assumed the quest was bugged. BUT to be fair, I could complete all the side quests without soft locking at any point... good job game.

Ok, there are probably many more things I could list, but that's the stuff that I was mad enough about to write it into a text document, so I could mention it in this review.

Let's talk about the good. Leading back to my opening statement... This game makes me sad, even while considering all the stuff written up top. The quests stories are good... amazing even. Not just the main plot but also the side quest are memorable, engaging and just great to experience (there are mundane filler quests, that every open world game needs to have it seems like, but they are in my opinion relatively well distinguished from the higher quality stuff). It just makes me sad that these awesome stories are stuck in this technical train wreck of a game. Yeah, thats all the good I wanted to point out.
Let's come to the end here: Should you buy this game?... I can't in my good conscience recommend playing it, everything this game stands for makes me say: "NO" The way this game was launched, the way it is now, the €60 PRICE TAG for a game that is broken in so many ways and the message it would send to publishers (yes I know I'm part of the problem here, I guess my good will was exploited)


Anyway thanks for reading and for anyone sticking around this long a little joke for the end:
Wow, this game is amazing and the world resonates with the main character really well, it only makes sense that the town and its citizens are a glitchy mess, after all our character's brain gets damaged more and more the game progresses, great idea to integrate it in this manner. 10/10 "It has a little something for everyone" -That one guy from IGN
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Launch Expectations

review_text: Cyberpunk 2077 is really a masterpiece that got bad press for being buggy when it first released. The story and storytelling are fantastic, the graphics are great, the gameplay is engaging and enjoyable, and it's one of those games that is a very memorable experience. You'll be saying "wow" as you play through it.
Gooner oriented game

So here's the deal. This game has issues. It's a janky, awkward technical mess. There's pop in textures and weird frame drops. Sometimes, you have to reload saves because the game soft locks. The crowds are weird and act unnaturally at the best of times.

And yet, I love it. When the game works as intended, it's a freaking blast. The combat feels good, the music is incredible, and the aesthetic is everything I've wanted in a game. It's incredibly pretty, the weapons are cool as hell, and the cyberware is awesome. 

I have the benefit of a beefed up rig, and I know not everyone has that good fortune. 

So, if you shelled out the money on a decent computer, then you might want to consider dropping the cash on this one. When it works, it's a ton of fun. But if you're gaming on a budget, there are better choices for you.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Gameplay Enjoyment, Hardware Requirements

review_text: Cyberpunk 2077 is an incredible game to experience 2 years later, now that they have more or less finally finished the game. The story is incredible, it has an immense amount of replay value, and the controls feel slick and rewarding. This is the kind of game that can be fully appreciated at both high and low levels of skill, character progression is easy and makes sense, perks are well explained, and they even allow one reshuffle per character. Highly recommend purchasing when on sale, with DLC
Despite the few bugs here and there it is still an amazing game and am more then happy to play it. still on my first run through and plan to play it through at least 2 x more minimum!

Having played the game for a bit now, I can say that it is far from perfect, thought not horrible. Being a avid player of the Cyberpunk roleplaying game prior to this, I came into it with high hopes. I have no prior notions of CD Projekt Red, as I have not played any prior titles they published. So I am not sure of the normal pattern with them. That being said, it feels very bare bones at this moment in time. Most of the skill trees are not viable as they only have a use once or twice and no use in the open world. I was hoping to remake my character from my first time doing the tabletop as a younger person. But without much techy, stuff to do in the open world, it isn't a useful build. 
Customization feels lacking. Not much to do once you finish creating your character and no way to alter them further once you enter the game. I was hoping for extremely wild colors and styles. Instead it feels utterly.. Plain. No real attempts at custom looks relating to cybernetics either. Just some on your face and that is it. What if I wanted to become a fully converted borg? Or a character with cybernetic limbs? It feels like they boasted about customization and then did as little as they could with it.
Vehicles are okay at best. Some handle alright and others feel like you are trying to drive a plane that is wanting to take off. You don't get to customize vehicles at all. Only buy new ones and then summon them through magic basically. Not a big deal, most of the vehicles you can personally own have there own personalities anyhow so it still allows for someone to have a somewhat custom experience. 
What I am hoping they will add in the future is more... Interactive portions to the game world. Beyond the main story line, most things are just ignoring you. No real interactions with the world. You just kind of drive from one point to another doing tasks and objectives and then wait for the next thing to present itself.
I would still recommend this game. It has a good base to pull from and hopefully in time they will add more to this. Perhaps it needed more time in development. I know, I know. It was in development for a long time but perhaps they had more ambitions and just truly not enough time to get it all right. No idea, I wasn't involved in making it. Despite this, it is still one of the few solid cyberpunk adventures you can have in the modern gaming era. So as a huge fan of the Cyberpunk genre in itself, I am quite happy.
Review_Angles: Build Viability, Character Customization, Open World Content

review_text: Really good, its mt favorite game, i love it

After few years of patching this game, after 2.0 patch, there is no other game with such juicy, immersive gameplay and first of all - atmosphere pouring out of the screen. I practically don't use fast travel system, because I drive slowly trough the Nigh City in my 911, Silverhand is chilling with me. Looking up, I see a city designed in chaotic beauty - office buildings, monumental blocks, AVs, viaducts, cables. Looking down, I see punks, or maybe nomads, or maybe rich people consumed by consumerism, it depends of district. It's nice to slow down sometimes and to inhale the air of this city.
Gameplay and difficulty level is something you need to try. No excuses.
It depends of you if you want to be a shadow, or a tank, but I think trying to be yourself is the best option - you can't eat a cake and have a cake.
If you know CDProjekt, you have to know, that the narration and story are at the highest level. Details, Easter Eggs, original stories, genitals.
They redeemed their sins after a failed debut and now you have one of the greatest AAA games in history.
Review_Angles: Atmospheric Immersion, Gameplay Depth, World Exploration

I held off on playing Cyberpunk 2077 when it first came out because I didn’t want to ruin the experience with all the bugs and issues that everyone was talking about. I waited until after Patch 2.12, and honestly, it was worth it.
The game now feels polished, and those frustrating bugs are a thing of the past. Night City is immersive, the story is gripping, and the visuals are stunning. It’s clear that this game was released way too early back then, but with all the updates and improvements, it has finally become the game it was meant to be.
If, like me, you were hesitant to dive in at launch, now’s the perfect time to experience Cyberpunk 2077 in its best form. It’s easily one of the most enjoyable single-player experiences out there today.

What can I even say?

I thoroughly enjoyed the story and gameplay in Cyberpunk 2077. I felt immersed in the roleplay and decision making: there was variety, sincerity, and I had genuine reasons to care about the decisions I was making and how they would impact the rest of the story. I loved the fact that I got to craft V into who I wanted her to be; that the game responded to my morally grey decisions, my slight flexibility depending on the case, or my overall chaotic nature that would make even Maelstrom gangoons shake in their boots.

My major complaint is probably an obvious one: the crashes.

Throughout my entire playthrough, I dealt with crashes. Sometimes every 5-10 minutes, sometimes randomly after about 2 hours, sometimes before I even loaded into the game. Essentially, the only way I could ensure that I got to complete Cyberpunk and it's DLC is by spamming F1 every time the game would let me (and god forbid it crashed during a cutscene or lengthy dialogue (thank you Johnny.)) Considering the fact that I put 105 hours into my first playthrough, you can imagine that I dealt with an obscene amount of quicksaving, crashing, and frustrating treks back through content and missions that I had already completed. By all accounts, my PC should be able to run Cyberpunk. I ran the benchmark, I had the game dictate what it thought my computer SHOULD be able to run, I scrolled dozens of Reddit threads and tried numerous different potential fixes - nothing.

I'll still recommend this game because truth be told, I loved playing it, despite how much the technical issues frustrated me. Maybe there is a fix I didn't find, or maybe my computer truly is just hot wet trash and I am unaware of it, but either way, I know based on the hundreds of other people I found with similar issues that I am not alone in this struggle.

Anyway, buy the game at your own risk, and remember that bombing Arasaka tower might be secretly based (?)
Review_Angles: Narrative Immersion, Roleplay Depth, Technical Stability

review_text:
This is a review that was long overdue but i felt it warrants one now. this game had an incredibly rocky launch, everyone is aware of this and i am sure many people, including myself, experienced the amount of bugs and issues this game was plagued with. in fact, right when i started up the game day one, a character gave me a sort of training chip to stick into my neck and play the tutorial. however, i assumed it was supposed to be a ship because instead he shoved a whole pistol into my neck instead. i knew instantly that this was gonna be a bumpy ride. HOWEVER, even with the issues and bug this game had, i would be lying if i said that this game was incredibly fun with its tight gunplay, melee mechanics, and gripping story that kept me in the game. my first playthrough i never finished and stopped somewhat half way as i was usually busy with work.

it wasnt until i saw the cyberpunk edgerunner anime. that show alone was one of the most beautiful shows i ever saw and not only did it baffle me on how great it was, it stoked the fire in me to go back into cyberpunk and replay it all over again. after many updates this game went through, it is now in a incredible( though not perfect) state and i am incredibly in love with it again. 


my recommendation: if you have the time, watch the show first as it is a good sort of pregame before the actual game. the game is amazing on its own but the charm is in both the show and the anime. 


ps: rebecca best waifu
Game is fun but it's buggy AF
Super dope game. Runs really good on PC. 10/10 would recommend.
1.5 completely broke the game for me. Not happy
Despite all the bugs still innovative and fun to play.

Simply too many issues to recommend, lots of noticeable cut content and poorly thought out systems. Plays like a game released a decade ago with a new shiny paint job. Bugs and tech issues are mostly fixed, but its still just a boring looter shooter slog with a main story quest back bone. Very easy gameplay, even on harder difficulties. 

The updates only highlight the flaws in the gameplay and RPG/FPS/Hacking systems. It still chugs on my system. A year later and It still feels like a unfinished game with a bunch of potential, but so far its been 2 months with no patch as they focus on next gen release. Play something else.

2023 update - Now I have a 4090 vs a 1080ti so RTX is a very nice/now its not chugging. They reworked the RPG Skilltree. People say its now up to snuff but 3 hours into a new play through I was just not impressed. With all the other games to come out in 2023, I would still recommend playing something else. The game is just not my bag....
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Gameplay Loop
