review_text: They've redeemed themselves

Storywise the game is one of the best . The writing is really damn good. And as of patch  2.0 the gameplay is pretty damn good as well. i had gotten the chance to play through the game long back back when it was on patch 1.2-3 ish. and compared to then its a day and night difference . now the different builds you can have in the game actually changes up your playstyle in a significant way . the only thing i miss from the old version is the silenced revolvers. 

and the dlc improves upon the base game in a lot of ways as well. your choices feel more meaningful throughout. theres more stuff to do . the gigs are way more interesting with fun stories and encounters. the only real problem with the dlc is the fps drops . sometimes it drops to well below 20fps. after the latest patch 2.11 it hasnt ever dropped that low but its gone down to around 25 once in a while. restarting the game seems to fix the fps drops temporarily. in the base game im averaging around 55-60 btw.

the game has been improved a lot compared to launch. the combat is much better. so is the driving. and a lot of the bugs have been fixed. but i still wouldnt call this is a polished game ;)  some side quests still have audio bugs . rn the scanner doesnt seem to scan a good number of dead bodies which im 90% sure wasnt the case before. cars still sometimes spawn falling from the air. the el capitan vehicle stealing missions are currently bugged. no matter what you do a lot them end up failing automatically once you reach a certain distance from the destination. i still cant close the windows in my megabuilding apartment since the romantic hangout. also the radioport seems to stop working for like 2 seconds whenever i start climbing a ladder.

anyway the game is still great and definitley worth playing . the main story missions and 90% of sidequests as well are completely bug free. its got a great story , really good gameplay and phenomenal music. definitely one of the best video game soundtracks ive ever listened to.
Review_Angles: Narrative Quality, Gameplay Improvements, Technical Stability

review_text: It's an alright game. The screaming issues to me poor optimization, graphical glitches, and bugs. Other than that, it just feels stolen. Want fun hacking in an open world? It just shows that forcing your developers to work under sweatshop conditions does not produce a good product. Please CDPR, take your time and give your devs a goddamn break.

My only criticism would be the key bindings that they don't let you remap if your an arrow key / number pad player like myself. review_text: So much Dick.. so much everything els.. the best game ever.

Alright, this will be a long review. So where do we start? From the beginning would be best. 

I got this game back on release. Was real hopeful even though I heard some real bad stuff about it. 
I got majorly disappointed back then. My gear could barely run it and it all broke apart in several places frequently. It all ran like an already faulty implant installed by a shitty ripperdoc out of the slums of NC. I stopped playing not too far after the first act. And like that it stayed in my Library for years to come. 

As of writing this, CDPR released the 2.0 patch, along with the Phantom Liberty DLC (which I will not cover in this review as I am downloading it while writing this.) 
All I can say is wow. 

My gear is still the same old rusty bucket I had back at release and the game actually runs, and I don't mean runs as in functioning, I mean the game runs, and it looks amazing, even if I don't have everything maxed out.

As for the game itself, it feels immersive cruising the streets of Night City, the world feels alive. People walk the streets, cars drive up and down, criminals doing their thing and hiding in all the corners of the city. There's work to do and loads of Eddies to make for mercs who really want to live out that power fantasy of becoming a chromed out killing machine. 
Weapons to try out of different sorts, skill trees to play around with (and yes you can experiment all you want as the game freely allows you to re-allocate them whenever you want). Implants that you can install, loads of different implants, enabling you to play in whatever way you want. (The Sandevistan is insane though and has carried me for so long I'm part of it and it's part of me).

Hacking machines, taking out Cyberpsychos, Investigating crimes, committing crimes, hell even doing good deeds, figuring out conspiracies. The game has a lot to offer if you let it. 

As for the main story, I was satisfied with the way they put it. I felt it was rather short, but I put 40hrs plus into the game before I even finished it. Although you could probably do faster if you don't suffer from completionism. 

At the end, I was left with a lot of different feelings (I did them all for the sake of wanting to see it). The game really puts the dystopia of a corpo owned world in your face, everything's run by 'em and there's little you can do to resist it. 
But even in this run down world where everything seems so depressing, where the city will eat you up as it doesn't care for your feelings, your situation or where you come from. But even past all that, interacting with the different fixers, mercs, to be friends, adversaries, there is beauty, hope, love, hate and sadness. 
The people of NC come in many forms, chromed out scavs, corpo fanatics, hustlers and Monsters of the human kind.

The game is by no means perfect and I shall make no such claim. 
But it's damned good. 

Information about my setup for those curious;

Processor: i5-9600KF 3.7ghz
Graphics: GTX 1660 Super
Ram: 16GB
SSD: Shark 512GB NVMe M.2
OS: Windows 10

RIght... so my negative review stood for over a year before I played the game again.

It's... better. It's never going to be as good as we wished it was, as we were promised. But is it worth a go now? Yeah.
Review_Angles: Post-Launch Improvement, Expectation Gap, Consumer Value

review_text:
Cool game overall. Though even with the dlc you hit the end like a brick wall. The options/decisions could use some fleshing out. The city could use some more fleshing out too. In the beginning its like wow theres so much possibility here, but by the end you end up visiting the same handful of places so many times you start to see just how limited the explorability is.

Also the dlc ending I chose was a frign nightmare, just be warned. 

Needs a new game plus and more content, but had fun with whats there.  (also this isnt my actual playtime, i left the game running during my entire playthrough even when i went to work). I hit 3 separate endings. 

Overall very cool game but i feel like each story/questline could be longer and have more options, and being able to do missions and work on the storyline you chose for your main ending would really be great. Once you hit the end it just cuts you off and sends you back to your last save before your moment of "no return" for said ending. 

Gunplay is great, graphics are great, and story and characters are fantastic but the actual questlines for each person , and interactions with them are incredibly basic and limited. 

If they released a couple more dlcs id buy them, just feels like a lot was left undone/ would love to play further, but nothing im interested in is left to do.

good in general, but could be better=)

Firstly to all the people that bought this game and are complaining because you have a prior gen console or an old graphics card/ cpu all I have to say is; just because you don't have the proper hardware to run the game doesn't mean it's a bad game. Secondly to all the people saying that it's an "unfinished game" you're probably the same damn people that where writing death threats to the developers when they delayed it. This game has flaws, but so did Skyrim, GTA V, and ALL OTHER OPEN WORLD GAMES. This is one of the most graphically intensive games that has ever been released and it's absolutely stunning! I have an rtx 2080 and it does chug along a little bit but it's easy to see why. The lighting/ shading/ color schemes are all very complex and crisp. This is the new benchmark that makes you say "can it run Crysis?" to now saying "can it run Cyberpunk?" The game play is a first person shooter style but it definitely is more of an RPG than anything else, so keep that in mind if  you are considering purchasing this game. It has very intense moments and fantastic character development. The acting is pretty average which isn't awful but if it was a movie it probably would give out any awards to the actors, but the story is riveting! This game is on definitely in my top 5 already but I can see how it's not for everyone. Buy this game if you have the right hardware and you like rpg's with fps elements. Don't buy this game if you are a call of duty player that wants a visceral shooter experience, because this definitely isn't that.

review_text: Well worth upgrading your rig for this game.

Im glad i waited a long time before playing this.
It was pretty unplayable before apparently, but you wouldnt know it from, how it plays at this time.
There are still some issues. Some options didnt seem to like my specific graphics card and there are rare non game breaking bugs. 

The story is great and i dont want to spoil anything, so i will leave it at that. The english voiceacting is impressive and i recommend the female V over the male one, though male V is still good.

Night City is probably the most impressive city, ive ever seen in a videogame. Every bit feels unique somehow, even if i know logically, that they did reuse assets. Cant really explain it.

The gameplay might be the worst part of the experience, but i hate bullet sponge enemies with a passion and played on hard. If you keep up with gear, they go down quickly, but if you fight enemies above your level, you will artifically do almost no damage, like in the witcher 3. Things like that just destroy my immersion. 
The enemy ai is pretty bad, but serviceable. Fights will look spectacular, especially if you use the slow motion implants and play aggressively. Slicing through an entire squad in slowmo and seeing limbs fly everywhere at the end of it, might not be challenging lategame, but very fun.
Cyberpunk 2077 had a few radical balance patches, but its clear from just looking at the perk tree, that the actual balance is still pretty wonky.

Mods do exist on nexus, but no total conversions or radical overhauls worth mentioning. There are options for tweaking the balance and crafting system though, which is always good. Get a respec mod. Starting a new game takes a long time, even if you skip all the dialogue. I do plan on playing once more from the beginning, but if you are just unsatisfied with how your build plays, respecs save a lot of time. Also some perks can feel detrimental, so trying them out can be a hassle.

Earlier i wrote about not wanting to spoil anything, but i would recommend you to look up the requirement for the secret ending. I played unspoiled and was lucky enough to get it right, but if i hadnt, it wouldve required replaying a huge chunk of of the game. The requirements without spoiling the actual ending: [spoiler]Tell Johnny, that he fucked up with you as well and then give him a second chance. Happens during a sidequest and you can not miss the choice, unless you declined the quest.[/spoiler] If you have done that, just wait a few minutes at the end, when you are presented with your options for tackling the very final mission. Johnny will put forth another "plan".
That ending might be the most fitting depending on your V and is most certainly the most badass. It inspired me to write fanfiction for the first time. 

Strongly recommended.

review_text: you need to get this game choom

Cyberpunk 2077 is not perfect, but it really is worth the money and is only going to get better with time! From stunning visuals, to deep characters, to quirky sidequests involving AI taxis -- it's obvious that an immense amount of love and care went into this game.

Cyberpunk does have it's issues, but it's not the calamity that so many people make it out to be (at least not on PC). If you're like me and have pretty capable hardware, you won't have most of the issues that the internet is so fond of reiterating. I ran everything at high or ultra settings without ray tracing, and only encountered a few bugs (nothing out of proportion with your average AAA release). If you have lower-mid tier hardware, you might want to wait until CDPR has had a chance to patch things up a bit.

One word of advice -- don't go in expecting Blade Runner. I say this because it happened to me. It's not Blade Runner. It's Cyberpunk. It's literally in the name... If you accept it for what it is, you're going to have a blast!
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Content Quality

review_text:
I wanted to like this game, and I certainly put in enough hours giving it a fair shake.

But far too many of those hours were spent reloading and redoing things I'd already done before because BUGS. LOTS OF BUGS. Not to mention bad AI, weird control schemes that are hard to remap, and poor optimization.

And no matter how much you might think this is an RPG—you do have SOME choice in your character background and personality, but not much—the storyline eventually pushes you in ways you may not have been interested in roleplaying for Plot Reasons.

DO buy this game if you're aware of its flaws yet still intrigued by great world-building and interesting combat mechanics with plenty of side missions to help you ignore the main plot.

DON'T buy this game if you're not prepared to deal with more bugs than a Bethsoft game on launch day, the most hilariously awful vehicle-driving experience ever (an XBOX controller makes it SLIGHTLY more manageable, but you can't remap its controls so a bit hit-or-miss), limited RP choices, and shoehorned-in-despite-your-choices end-of-game outcomes worse than ME3's original endings
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Narrative Freedom, Gameplay Mechanics

review_text:
its not a perfect game by all means but its definitely one of the most memorable games ive played in a while. i love all the characters you meet and interact with. Johnny is probably one of my favourite NPC's i have ever interacted with in any game. He is an absolute bro. Night City is such a beautiful environment to run around in. the combat is simple but feels so good. the music is really good and fits the theme very well. most of the bugs i run into usually give me a laugh and nothing game breaking (only played after 1.5). this game just satisfies the itch of an RPG set in the not so distant future 

now to the problems. while there is a pretty decent customisation system in the game it could definitely be better. thankfully they added in a transmog system in 1.6 because man you ended up wearing some ugly clothes when trying to have good stats. You can tell the game definitely focus more on Fem V than male V just from the clothing alone. the crafting system is so underwhelming its crazy. maxed out crafting my first playthrough just to find there really isnt much to craft. couldnt find a legendary blueprint for my favourite gun (outside iconics) nor for any of the items of clothing i liked. definitely feels like the crafting department got shafted. A more personal problem in that i dont like endings that take you back to previous save before the final mission. It makes me lose all sense of completion after finishing the game. 

overall the game is a solid 7/10 and i recommend it to anyone who loves RPGs and Cyberpunk settings.

I love this game but I can't give a positive review to something that was rushed to hell and is borderline unplayable.

Edit: after replaying this game again and purchasing a new graphics card, a lot of improvements have been made. The game is a lot more stable and less buggy but not perfect. the game still falls short in its attention to detail compared to most open-world games. I can only hope that cdpr still updates this game to make it closer to what they promised.

With mods and, to be fair, somewhat without, actually, quite a masterpiece.  Not sure about bad reviews other than buggy release.  

Regarding Mods: The Witcher 3 suffered from a similar issue without mods: great yet unfortunately not challenging enough.  Now it's not as bad but to someone who's played Overwatch for years, I found hard mode a touch to easy and read that the game gets easier the further you progress.  Fortunately, there's just the right mods for both problems.  Level Scaling & Balance, Harder Gameplay, Enhanced AI Netrunners, Lifepath Bonuses and Gang/Corp Traits, Better Crowd Behavior.  I'm thrilled to have these mods available for my first playthrough unlike W3, which I completed long before it 'got good'.

The RPG progression elements in the game are superb, some of the best in the genre.  Between gear, cyberware, hacks, attributes and their perk webs, there's not a whole lot more you could ask for.  Tons of builds you could craft, tweak, and roll with.

The Combat (again modded) is excellent.  It rewards positioning (primarily survival) and aim (obviously your damage output). There's a wide enough variety in the look and mechanics of weapons that you're sure to find one or a few that feel right to you.  There's a great variety of 'spells' (hacks) and grenades (which are definitely worth a mention).  It really is the shooter-RPG that should have been done half this good by now: it doesn't let you down on either end of the genre spectrum.

The story is flat out superb.  It's a complex, well-acted, and, at times gripping, plot and this is coming from someone that isn't easily impressed with storylines.  Of course the general outline has many parallels: people don't get that today everything's been done already on a vague level which leads to comments-like "It's a cheap Altered Carbon ripoff" and therefore it's the finer-grained details that count.  Mimicry and derivation are artforms in themselves and Cyberpunk 2077 nails it.

The gameworld is great but I don't feel it makes much sense to comment beyond saying it's a beautifully rendered open world since a cityscape may not be everyone's thing.

Mods exist and more people should use them.  Seriously, the combat is fun and engaging as I've already stated, but what some fine tuning does for a game cannot be overstated.  Increasing enemy health makes it so that the player is pressured to deal damage fast and effectively, finding the optimal position and adjusting according to the enemy's.  Reducing level up bonuses and gear scaling keeps the player from becoming an inflated immortal (what's the point of all these tools if you don't have to use them to win).  AI Netrunners Enhanced forces you to respond to a constant stream of hacks (spells) and a real incentive to neutralize the enemy netrunner(s) first.  Lifepath Gang/Corp Bonuses amongst other things makes each npc faction unique to fight against.  An example would be 'The Animals' can't be 'stealth killed' (amongst other bonuses/traits).  This doesn't eliminate the purpose of stealth, there's still bonus damage for getting the drop on someone, but it can drastically change how it feels to take on 'The Animals'.
Review_Angles: Gameplay Difficulty, Mod Enhancements, RPG Progression

The game runs better now but not flawlessly. The gameplay is still pretty weak. The leveling/progression systems have somehow lost depth in the latest 2.0 update. You do not role play as a customized Cyberpunk from the year 2077. You are V who is a pre-generated character with a pre-determined story to follow which you can do little to change besides what side quests you choose to complete and which ending you pick. 

I've tried about a dozen times since first completing the game to go through it again and after bouncing off a half dozen times over a few years I'm doing a second playthrough now in 2023 to see the DLC and 2.0 rework. I think this is mainly because the gameplay isn't all that fun, and there aren't enough meaningful choices to make between playthroughs. 

TL;DR Watch Edgerunners. Also, maybe buy the game for like $40 on sale including the DLC. I hope we get another Witcher 3 and not another Cyberpunk 2077 from CDPR, BUT this game is now at least worth playing.

I think I was one of the few people who bought this game with no expectations whatsoever. I wasn't even planning to buy it before the release, but I decided to give it a try and was extremely disappointed.

The combat is the main aspect that brings this game down. For it to be such a significant part of the game and still be so unimaginably poorly designed is genuinely shocking. I could understand if they tried to go for a new twist on combat that just didn't work out, but that's clearly not the case: the combat is extremely generic and basic, and they still somehow managed to make their rudimentary system feel clunky and horrible to play.

The level to which your decisions influence the course of the game is also much more limited than it seems to be at first glance. I was actually impressed in the beginning at how much seemingly small decisions affected the story, only to realize upon watching other playthroughs that they had no effect whatsoever.

Overall, if you're interested in a (slightly) interactive story, this game may be interesting to try out. However, the combat is so atrocious that there is no way I can recommend this game without an extreme rework.
The bugs within this game are part of the experience

5 Hours in, I really am enjoying the game. I get other people and consoles are not enjoying the bugs and glitches but, I think I either got lucky, or I'm doing something right. Regardless this is a quick review of what I had experienced.

PROS: 
-Fully sold my-self in the game. I'm personally having a lot of fun. I'm a sucker for an all around great story. 
-The bugs I had we're minor. While doing a machine my car was in the background break-dancing hitting random civilians of NS. Also had one bug of my cock and balls clip through my pants while at the afterlife bar talking to Jackie. 
-I enjoy the combat system. It's tricky but really fun. AND the combat trees are amazing and looks like they scale well. 
- Seems to be a long game. since 5 hours later I finally got a TITLECARD. 
- Game looks flawless for me, I was actually in awe of the first time I got in Night City. (Nomad Player) 


CONS: 
- Bugs are bugs. They are there. You can see them. Smell them. Feel Them. Taste them.. 
- Okay, Picking how you start. I chose Nomad. I was like, hell yeah I gotta be a Renegade riding around the badlands for a few hours before night city. Nope. I get to go through a border check and poke an Iguana that kinda jump scared me. Then BAM 6 months later you're in Night City and the entire hood knows you and wants to box you and sell you guns and you have no clue who they are. I wish we could have not had the 6 months jump and just played it to get to know the NPC's. 
- Driving sucks. But it does get a little better. 
-NPC's seem lifeless. Talking about the ones that roam the city.
- Had a few bugs through a quest where I could just do a save and load it and it's fixed. 


In all, The bugs felt like 11/11/11 bugs. Talking of course about Skyrim. They didn't take away from the game. Shit sometimes they were a great moment of comedic relief. The games is fun try it. I'm only 5 hours at this point but will edit as we go further into the adventure that is Cyberpunk 2077.



EDIT: Game was fun. I just expected the main story line to be a bit longer. Still worth it. CDPR are fixing things so please give the game a chance. 

SIDENOTE: Pick Skye.
Review_Angles: Narrative Quality, Technical Stability, Combat Gameplay

NO SPOILERS BELOW

The "decisions" and "choices" you make largely have no impact on the late game - or worse - the game forgets which path you chose and gives you a different closure than you expected. It violates your trust, and takes away your agency by invalidating the "choices" you make along the way. Up until the last act of the game, I was prepared to mark this as a "yes, I recommend..." However, it becomes abundantly clear how much content was actually removed (just from the story, not talking about anything else) - and how insignificant your impact is up until the final act choices - that's infuriating. 

Story and bugs aside, it's a fun game - but it's not the game we we were sold in the advertisements and marketing and first looks over the last few years. I'm hopeful for the future, but skeptical.

edit: 90 hours in - all story content complete, including all available side missions... There's literally nothing left for me to do in this game. Had fun with what was there, but the unfinished content just makes me feel like there was so much more out there... I wish they'd held the game another year. BOO.

I'm not surprised that older hardware is struggling. The quests, and missions are great, you feel part of the world and you buy into the characters. I'm already looking forward to my second play through as there's so many choices you can make to change how the game flows. Not all good, sneaking is hard, picking up loot is not fluid, the abilities and skills / upgrades is clunky and can feel overwhelming. Driving again is clunky and the AI could be a bit more intuative. The vehicles really could do with some work, for example, windscreen wipers when it's raining, or all the cars having lights on in the dark. Also would love to see real seasons with the weather. But all in all what a great game. When the bugs get ironed out and hopefully more lifelike updates for AI, you could really get lost in this world.

review_text:
Went into this without expectations. 

Glad I did. I see why people are pissed off with the game but honestly it's a solid title if you see it for what it is, a flawed game, but one that lets you have a lot of fun. I hope they end up adding in missing features if they're reworking it.

Story wise, it feels like they cut 3/4th of the story. It feels like the Johny Silverhand story should have been one of multiple routes to take, but then Keanu was in, so of course they magnified that part. Understandable, but disappointing. 

Gameplay wise, I am loving it, hacking is a lot of fun, sneaking is fun, handguns handle well, but there is too many shotguns IMO.

Crafting seems useless to me, and it still breaks your save as per 1.05. 

The cyberware seems wildly under utilised. I would have preferred to go over the top to the point of being overpowered. Only a charge jump? Why not stack charge jump AND double jump. Mantis arms? why not add an extra pair of those? That would have been awesome.

Bugs. Well, there's bugs. Personally I haven't experienced more than the usual open world game. I hope they patch the weirdness, but I hope they keep the speed boosting glitches. It would be fun to see this in speedruns. Walking on a slope for example will excellerate you massively. If you have a time slowing ability, when you use it and use the dodge forward and jump, you'll shoot into the distance. Glitching is fun though, so I don't mind. 

All in all, quite happy with the game.
Give it like 18 more updates, and this will be the best $30 game of 2025. 6.5/10.

Super fun game. It can be buggy at times. They fix it after a few patches. But CD Projekt Red does a great job of creating a super fun world. It is up there with a Rockstar Game. I've played 224 hours of this game and keep coming back. Always more trouble I can get into in Night City and Dogtown!!
Awesome, immersive. Great story, action is fun. Really all around great game.

No performance issues thankfully, but it's just not done. Going to try to get a refund but I doubt I'll be able to. Don't waste your time, wait a couple years until they finish it. I had low expectations and they were still not met.

Edit after finishing the game: It definitely got better, but I'm still let down by it. I thought I'd want to immediately start another play through with a different play style, but honestly I might just mess around for a few more hours and uninstall. The story was great, but once that's done you really don't feel the urge to keep playing. There's no gameplay loop, nothing that feels worth grinding towards, the non-main missions are pretty much all the same, zero customization, among other let downs. I'm honestly kind of sad. I didn't get caught up in the hype and honestly had no expectations beyond a good cyberpunk game, but it's clear the crunch to get ~something~ released ruined this project. There's also just so many small things they cut corners on that add up. Water doesn't react to anything, citizens literally do nothing except run away, there's dozens of frustrating UI bugs and things which require changes to improve the quality of life of playing the game. I don't know. I could go on. I guess it's worth the money, and when it's good it's great. But I leave this game feeling bummed. They'll probably fix it, but I honestly think it's too little too late. No Man's Sky became amazing because the way the game is a sandbox they could just keep adding more systems and stuff to do, but with such a narrative story driven game, what's the point in coming back to it? The open world here was almost useless, especially considering how easy it is to fast travel. Whatever. Idk why I'm writing this nobody will read it. I'd recommend the game, but think of it more as a cool linear cyberpunk story, not a true cyberpunk city to explore and be amazed by. Sigh.
Review_Angles: Game Completion, Gameplay Loop, Replay Value

However, 2077 is not a bad game. Not anymore. It's a solid 8/10 and that's in a very deep, and harsh sense. It's a must play, even if it's not what it could have been. There are still a few glitches but it's much better than it was. CDPR still has a a lot they need to deliver on and they better do so. But, for what it is, I like the game enough to recommend it.

Extremely immersive and deep world. Incredible game that absolutely lives up to the hype.

While the history of this game is infamous, the nature of how the game came about is part the reason of how the game should also be played. Its based on a paper based TTRPG and not a JRPG - so part of the experience is how you choose to play. Its far closer to games like GTA than it is Final Fantasy, with a vast open world and a great setting. 

The main story lines lead to 5 different endings and yes, the choices you make only change that path so much. But the vast amount of side quests, sudden instances and achievable achievements is what has entertained me so much. Memories of cruisin' down the beach in Vice City listening to 80s classics has now been joined of screamin' down the main highway on my bike listening to Samurai.

Is it glitchy? Yes, but not so that its unplayable - yet to play a game that didn't act odd at some point.

But what is fun is to play how the character thinks - TTRPGs are all about immersion, and if you immerse yourself in this game you do get rewarded. A streetkid living by codes or an ex-corpo turned renegade out for revenge.. make the "Open" part of the world your own narrative and you will have fun.

Plus you get to meet a talking gun.. whats not to like there?
Review_Angles: Playstyle Perspective, Content Depth, Technical Stability

Coming back to try the game after 2.0 came out, however the game wont load past the very first intro screen after a 10-15 second black screen right after starting the game. A little troubleshooting didn't change anything about the issue. Hopefully a 2.11 patch will come out and fix this, I've seen a couple others post about it on reddit or the steam forums. Not using mods. Looking forward to an update &n changing this review.
Feb Update, issue persists.
Playing again in November of 2024 and the issue is resolved. I'll review once I get 40-50 more hours into the 2.0 update and totally re-edit this information without the former issue mentioned soon.

After watching how bad this game was when it released, I put it on my "ignore" list and forgot it existed until about a month ago when I picked it and the DLC up on sale for 1/2 price. I didn't expect much... my Steam & Epic accounts for full of RPGs that I started and never finished. 

This game is different, though. I've been gaming for 40+ years, and this quickly became my favorite game of all-time. I sank 92 hours into my first run as female Nomad V, beating the DLC and then the main game both on the same day. I'm already 10 hours into my 2nd run (male Corpo V) and I'm amazed at how differently the story is playing out and how many clues I never saw in the first run.

The game itself is beautiful. The music, while 90% of it is not my taste, still fits Night City perfectly. The driving, the fighting, the stealthing, the upgrading, the crafting... the game is perfection. It really takes me back to GTA Vice City, a game I dearly loved in the early 2000s when it came out. I got hundreds out hours out of that, and I can see the same thing happening with this game.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Narrative Replayability, Aesthetic Atmosphere

review_text:
997.1 hours, over 8 full playthroughs. 48 of 57 achievements. Seven endings. Two deep exploration, completionist playthroughs. I only play on Very Hard now. Effing, fricking, frapping love this game.

With the 2.1 Patch, CP2077/PL officially became a masterpiece. Just think of it... an adventure RPG where it's actually a very, very cool thing to do to get on the virtual mass transit system and ride around the imaginary city for half an hour and just take in the sights. If you'd suggested to people just twenty years ago that today we'd be casually playing with simulations of this complexity and beauty as if they were simple toys, you'd have been laughed down.

I have on the order of 340 hours in Baldur's Gate 3. I am neither surprised nor dismayed that it took Game Of The Year. It's a riotously good RPG game and fully worthy of great praise. Larian sets the bar for making fans happy. But, if I could, I'd vote for Phantom Liberty as GOTY.

What a game.

Play it, you fool.

review_text:
Biggest waste of time on a game in recent memory. I'd say 12 hours is enough to try and find some ways to enjoy it. This is what I found:

Pros
-Nice scenery, plenty of places to see and visit. Perfect for screenshots.

Review_Angles: Visual Appeal, Gameplay Mechanics, Technical Stability

review_text:
I don't usually play early access games, so I guess I am spared most of the common debilitating bugs that may occur early on in development. This game is easily the most incomplete game I have played to date. The world looks great, but it keeps reminding me that this is a broken product. This is like playing a alpha version of a game that has a complete story.

I hit a bug where I can't equip any of my weapons. So I get into a firefight in a mission, and I can't pull out a gun. I had to solve it myself but finding a mission with a cut scene that finally fixed it.

50% of the time the people speaking in front of me will have duplicated sound, one as if they are standing in front of you, one in your 'headset'. It's very annoying. 

Sometimes as you drive by streets will just explode as cars load into the scene, but they are supped to be burned out. So instead of loading a burned out car, it explodes it a la carte right in front of you, dozens of times. 

You may need to reload because of a bug, sometimes that doesn't help at all, like the gun bug. 

I go back and forth from enjoying myself, to being reminded that this is a mess. I can't recommend a game that shouldn't have been released to the public. We can only hope that these things will be fixed in time, but this game may not be relevant by the time that happens. This game does not touch the quality, polish, or completeness of Red Dead Redemption 2. It is closer to a response to GTAV which is 7 years old. This game has not advanced the genre in anyway. It's pieces of games that we've seen from the last gen, without any innovation. So even if the bugs didn't exist, it still wouldn't receive an A+.
very moist billboards in game
Freaking awesome.

Terible
game is not as bad as ppl say, if u have an outdated build can't expect the game to run great, so far I've only seen minor bugs nothing game breaking

Currently I have played about 22 hours of Cyberpunk 2077, and i must say that it is pretty good. Yes the game is buggy, but nothing has been game-breaking(yet) and it looks great. I feel bad for my PC though, I have a ryzen 7 2700, a rx 5700xt and 24 gigabytes of ram and the game runs fine. I run the game at 1080p ultra setting at 60fps generally, but the game is not that optimized i'm afraid, performance is completely inconsistent but it's not unplayable. The story is great so far, but I have mostly been doing side quests because the main story is so short, but the side quests are great. The gamplay is pretty good, but the enemies are far to bullet spongy, and in earlier stages of the game it is incredibly frustrating. Overall though the game is fantastic but it still needs some work.
Review_Angles: Technical Stability, Narrative Quality, Gameplay Mechanics

review_text:

I recommend it, because I *like* it.

review_text:
It's really epic, the detail and diversity in this game is an achievement!  I'm taking it slow unlike some others reading everything and checking every corner and it's really immersive all while the game waits on me no problem, it's not rushed as in you can't follow anything that's going on.  

All the mechanics are working great, stealth and hacking is really fun but yea, it's buggy and the AI in the street, not in combat, is cheap like it's going back and forth on the same path when it's not getting terrified because you got withing 5 meters of them with your car while repeating the same catch phrase, same goes for car AI. The bugs are nothing game breaking though and are not ruining my experience though I consider the amount high, mostly positional bugs with characters having them flying or go through objects temporarily.  

The game runs really well even when fps drops to 30 because I set my graphics too high and there's too much action going on, smooth as hell.  I find the balance of the loot pretty good and the levelling also, there's a lot to do and I like that very much, maybe not in terms of free roaming but I haven't been interested in that since GTA3, I like having objectives and don't get really much fun from just going crazy in the streets, haven't even tried yet to go on a rampage.

Epic stuff really, it's been years since I've played a game 10 hours straight, well worth the full price right now as I'm normally the guy who waits years for games to come cheap..!  Don't get turned of by the Mostly Positive rating at launch, half of the bad reviews are people having problems with their own computers or I'm guessing they just want to be the one to make a bad review on an epic game, many hours in sight as I still haven't end the lockdown which is the beginning of the game..!
Review_Angles: Immersion and Detail, Gameplay Mechanics, Technical Stability

review_text:
[h3][b]A definition of keep progressing until it becomes a masterpiece. They try to make the game as good as possible. They didn't lose their hope.[/b][/h3]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3376571342[hr]I mean, it's crazy how the game went from a broken-glitchy-buggy game in the first release to this-is-it! This-is-how-it's-supposed-to-be! I'm glad I played it from last month when the game has been patched to 2.1 and shoutout to my bud for the sharing, thanks a lot.

I encountered minor bugs but it doesn't ruin my experience that much. Like, somehow I got crashed by an invisible car or wall in freeway and sometimes enemies showed on the map but didn't appear, or the radio playing in a cutscene. I don't know if it's caused by me using too many mods. And here's the one who might have the same bug as me, there's one NCPD Scanner in Santo Domingo. I encountered the cowboys that are stuck inside the factory. I tried the teleport method, it didn't work. But I found the solution with a mod, I used [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/cyberpunk2077/mods/9298][b][u]Quickhack through walls from Nexusmods[/u][/b][/url], and the job is complete.

Spending 70+ hours just for the base game by completing main/side story, including undiscovered Side jobs, Gigs, Cyberpsycho, NCPD, and Events, I'm really satisfied. The first time I played the prologue, it gave me goosebumps by just how beautiful all the things are. The city, the view, the NPCs, the ethnicity, the dialogues/voiceover, and those people. They're alive, it feels alive.

Speaking of it, I'd probably say the endings can be good but it can be nothing good nothing bad. Hell, to get the secret ending you need to pick the right choice when with Johnny and make your bond with him around 70%. I also liked how they include some voicemails from the people that V's met or helped. It reminds me the journey. Feel empty after done playing the base game. Cyberpunk 2077 has become one of my favorite games.[hr][/hr]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3172196974

I know both are cautionary tales of what the future may hold for humanity but getting to explore it for yourself in 2077 and seeing how others navigate it and are  affected by it in edgerunners is an amazing experience. I think they have made me feel a sense of longing, a longing to be something more, to try and make sense of my life and to live a life that no matter when I go, I'm happy with what I've accomplished and who I have around me.

TL;DR: Watch the anime, play the game, it may spark something inside of you :)

Also its been great to see CDPR stick with this game and get it to where it is today, a very enjoyable experience compared to when it first came out.

review_text: CyberComeback 2077!
Simply the best
I love this game.

*Written as of the 1.05 version of the game. I have played through the story once and currently on a second 100% playthrough*
I enjoy this game, a lot. Yes, it is a bit buggy at times and I need to reload saves from time to time, but that is nothing new in games (Skyrim for example still requires it from time to time to this day, unmodded. Yes I like vanilla Skyrim). I, however, also seem to have lucked out from what I have heard from my friends who have this game. They have run into many bugs and glitches that I have not even seen or would have known about if not for being told about them.

I do not own a RTX card, just running the game on a GTX 1070. Game runs great with minimal frame drops and other nuisances while looking great at 1080p.

So, onto the lists of pros and cons. Reminder, these are my opinions and based on my experience of playing the game:

Pros: 
-Great characters, makes me want to hear them out
-Selection of gear is good
-Great writing, makes me actually want to listen to the story
-Atmosphere is next level, immersive AF
- Looks very nice, attention to detail is very good
-Many things to do
-Overall good time

The middle ground:
-Combat is meh (CDPR not known for great combat, went from "haha I swing sword and throw magic" to "haha I shoot gun and hack your brain"). It is decent enough to not be boring
-Cars seem to be a "do I want to walk or do I want to go find a road and call my car" kind of deal. They look nice though

Cons:
-AI sometimes seems to need to load through AOL servers to know what is going on
-Bugs
-Glitches
-Kind of a short game

Things I would add to the game:
-Sitting. Let me sit on benches and at the bar and take in the atmosphere. The game boasted immersiveness and it is still missing some elements that would help it. I can look in the mirror but I cannot sit at the bar/restaurant and drink/eat without it being required for a quest. I know the vendor menu is to let people go in and out quickly, but add an option where the character sits there and is served to add immersiveness to the game.
-Hide head option. Lets be honest, we want to see our character's faces when looking in the mirror, the inventory, or the photo mode.
-Addition of "attire slots" or whatever you want to call them. Saves the look you have on and keeps it no matter what you are wearing.
-Addition of barbershops, etc. to customize our characters during the game.
-Car customization and further weapon customization, ability to make them truly ours.
-Would not mind "mini-games" for doing something with V's friends. *"Cousin, lets go bowling" echos in the distance*

I have faith that CDPR will make the game a lot better, as they did with Witcher 3, people seem to forget how buggy it was. The game is definitely not finished at the moment, like 80% done and should not have been released at this stage. Should of had the "Early Access" tag.
10 hours... So far, so good!

If you're touchy about controller stick sensitivity and response curves like me, this game is not for you. Better controller support would make this game 10/10. All of my almost 8 hours in this game has been trying to get the sensitivity decent (and yes I've tweaked every setting in the 'advanced' section too). I can get normal look sensitivity to be decent, but then ADS is way too fast. When I implement changes to make ADS decent, normal look has jerky sensitivity increases. It looks really good, and when I play it on mkb, it's excellent, but I have nerve damage that doesn't allow me to use wasd very long and need controller support. 

Very disappointing.
Refunded. 7 crashes in less than 5 minutes.. I think I made it to the main menu once. Did Adam Kicinski quit yet?

review_text: A huge step down in everything compared to Witcher 3.

One of the greatest games ever made! Well worth every penny! I needed to update my NVIDIA driver, but once I did it took off with no hiccups for me. I had a bit of lag at first, but after a while it smoothed out, and it seems optimized now that I tweaked the graphics a little bit (dialing back a few ULTRA things for the sake of improved FPS). So far, I am fully immersed! I told everyone I know that I will be going on a vacation to night city for a week straight! Beyond that, I doubt I will be able to tear myself away from this masterpiece often. It's the whole package. The driving is beautiful, gunplay is great, aesthetic is unmatched. I would give this game a solid 10/10. And for anyone struggling with getting it started, have patience and look for the fix. It will work, and you will be amazed! Cheers, see you all in Night City!
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Gameplay Immersion

review_text:
[strike][h1] I would advise you to wait a couple of weeks or until the next major patch [/h1]

I'll start off by saying that this game is great. And it looks great, performance is far from the best, but it definitely doesn't look bad, don't really know what people were expecting. It looks like a 2020 game to me.

But, and this is a big but (eheh) i consider this game unplayable. And i'll try really hard to avoid playing it for now (something that i will probably fail to do unfortunately). The amount of times i reloaded in "just" 8h (actual in game time) is incredibly high. reasons being:

- Objects that are suppose to be intractable refuse to work
- Analysis mode keeps getting stuck (needs reload)
- The dodge animation triggering in stealth sections ( easy to fix with a remap and it might just be my clumsy fingers but i don't understand why you can dodge when crouched), or exiting crouch (stealth) just by bumping into stuff or because the game decided to (needs reload if i want to keep stealthy)
- Braindance showing missing stuff to interact with when i already interacted with them ( i found that i need to wait a second or two after a character as finished talking before scanning and that fixes it)
- Getting stuck on walls (literally, also needs reload) 
- Floating people, floating cars, floating assets
- Lots of sound issues, people talking over each other, sound not triggering.
- Missing assets (Searched for a gun for like 15 minutes that i knew it had to be there, finally caved, looked online and.. it should've been on the first place i looked, needed reload)
- Quest items that i can't interact even after reloading 3 times

I would "accept all of this" just because i really want to play this game, because as i said the game is incredible and reloading although extremely infuriating fixes [b]most[/b] stuff, but this is an rpg, and i keep thinking, "did  messed up? was this intentional by the game? am i missing something? is this a bug? is the script broken?" it's just unplayable, i've already had to check 2 guides online to see what was wrong (both times, it was a quest breaking bug and not my fault), and on the second time google's search results spoiled the entire quest.


Like i said the game is amazing and i will update this review in a few weeks into and amazingly positive one, but right now,
for the love of your sanity [b] WAIT [/b], usually most major stuff gets fixed on the month of release, or at least that's what i'm hoping[/strike]

UPDATED REVIEW since launch

I had to come back and give my thoughts after finishing the game at launch and leaving the review below. (I still gave it a thumbs up at the time).

I have sat back and watched with indifference as CDPR released various patches, until a few weeks ago I got an itch to come back and see what changed. Can I just start by saying... I am now on my third play through since coming back and already thinking about my 4th! And I am NOT somebody that normally replays a game (outside of GTA or Elder Scrolls).

Good Points:

1) Firstly, this game is the BEST at one thing IMO. It brings the characters to life and makes you feel immersed in the setting with good dialogue, multiple choices, outcomes and options. Characters become more than bobbing heads you just want to shoot and forget about. This echos throughout the game and I can't think of any other game that does this quite so well. 

2) The small touches have had a HUGE impact, more than I could have imagined. Extra weapons, buying apartments, being able to changing your look without messing your stats etc It has made a big, big difference. 

3) The side quests are a MUST, i normally ignore side quests for the most part, but CDPR actually put a lot of effort into these. Including a back story, a good setting, dialogue from johnny and others. DO NOT skip them, they add a lot of great gameplay and immersion. 

4) I can't fault the amount of content, between Side quests, police events (can't remember the correct name, side stuff) honestly there is no reason you shouldn't have 40+ hours of content. I STILL do think that the main story line is shockingly short, and its a downer that the main character is dying, I felt the same when i found out arthur was dying in RDR2...

5) The level of lore, that you can optionally dig into, is great! It adds that Elder Scrolls level of background lore that gives the city a life and a history. 

6) The combat is decent, but TOO EASY, i want more of a challenge, and not just the option of upping the difficulty in the game to just make them bullet sponges. 

7) The NPC AI has improved, but hitting people with cars, or how they react to you sometimes, while not a big deal for me, is a bit shit. 


Bad Points

1) Without specific missions, side quests etc there is little you can do to feel apart of the city. More in this area would make a big difference. 

2) The rag doll effects and the feel when you use melee weapons doesn't feel great. Plus when you shoot people in the head etc the visual effects are repetitive (i could shoot someone strait through the left side of the head but the gaping hole would always appear on the opposite side for example. 

3) The gangs still don't seem 'alive' or different, doing the side quests makes it a bit better i guess. But still, i was hoping to get more immersion from having all these gangs. 

4) Weapon customization has improved, but is still quite limited. 

5) No car customization. 

6) Getting 'chromed up' doesn't make you look different (besides your arms).

7) Map is still a bit small, and very small when you venture outside of the city. A lot of the hinterland is oil rigs etc that could have been used to put more towns / city there.


I'm very surprised to say this, but I am still enjoying it alot right now and I will def be buying the upcoming DLC.




Original Review: 

After the buzz, I can't help but feel disappointed..

1) The main story is too short and the pace is really bad (long talking scenes followed by short game play parts).

2) Very limited amount of weapons. 

3) Customizing weapons is extremely limited.

4) It's not an RPG in a sense that you can create your characters life-path and buy homes, build a crew, and so on. It's moreso choices you have within the main story. I am on my second playthrough and I am going to do the side quests but I'm asking myself what is the point...  

5) The various gangs, hell even the city itself, it a shallow show piece with no real substance to the story, they are just different looking bad guys. 

6) (On a more personal note) I really dislike the story plots where your playing someone who is 'serious ill / dying'. Instead of feeling like your making your mark on the gameworld and creating a bad ass character, you feel obligated to just clear the bloody thing. I felt the same with Arthur Morgan in red dead 2 one i found out he was dying, it was a downer and I just felt liking clearing the story strait away. 

This game looks great, the main story is pretty good and i felt emotionally involved. But to call this some sort of open world rpg in the sense of GTA 5 or Skyrim - not a chance. I wouldn't have paid the asking price for this game if I knew all of this before hand. The main story was great, but everything else had no soul, no re-playability. 

All in all, I would recommend it, its not a 'bad game', its just not the heavy hitter its making itself out to be.

Overall a fun open-world RPG, plenty of things to enjoy in the game - true, not exactly what was advertised and hyped up (not a next gen rpg for sure), but still a good solid game on its own. 
Pro:
Graphics are beautiful, quests are solid and plenty, story was well written, fighting is fun.
Negative:
Driving is bad, which is a pity as it would be great to just roam around driving. Some bugs remain but nothing game breaking, minor glitches. Annoying at times, but not a big issue.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Gameplay Mechanics, Technical Stability

review_text: Back when this game realeased it wasnt so great. Now playing it 3 years later all the bugs my friends told me about seem to be fixed. so woo woo this games is pretty good. 47.7 hours in the last week ish

review_text:
Polygon released an article stating that Cyberpunk 2077 raises the bar for open world games. And after a broken launch, years of fixes, and now, the absolute overhaul that 2.0 brings, I'm inclined to agree. Few open world titles fit that bill for me, one of which is of course Red Dead Redemption 2. I consider that an absolute gem. Cyberpunk 2077 isn't quite like RDR2, though. But that's okay. I think they both have different focuses...Though I would've loved to see the same emergent dynamic gameplay that's in RDR2 in Cyberpunk, along with the ability to interact with all of Night City's citizens. But that's okay. Like I said, different focuses.

Cyberpunk 2077 is an RPG where you make your own character, and choose your own backstory. And not only is it a damn good RPG, but it's also a banger of a shooter with deep visceral combat where you can feel every pull of the trigger, every landed thrown knife, and every swing that you take at the enemy. Coupled with this is the spectacular and glorious backdrop of Night City which just bleeds atmosphere and cyberpunk aesthetic. You feel it every step you take, and every region you visit. It's like watching Blade Runner for the first time and taking in those wide sweeping shots of Tyrell Corporation and Los Angeles as Deckard navigates the skies in his spinner. And thank god there's plenty of reason to stay in Night City, from gigs, shops, cyber psychos, crime scenes, and many more that I'm sure you'll discover yourself.
Review_Angles: Open World Quality, Technical Stability, RPG Elements

[h1]IMPRESSIONS & TIPS FOR BETTER IMAGE QUALITY & PERFORMANCE[/h1]
Well, I'm only a few hours in and I must say I'm loving it! There are a few glitches here and there (Like npcs spawn infront of you or npcs clipping into each other) but nothing game-breaking (version 1.03). Now for the tips:
1- It's a good game [b]IF[/b] you have a good PC. (No, the recommended specs are not enough to fully enjoy the game, at least for me).
2- [b]INSTALL IT ON A GOOD SSD DRIVE![/b]
3- Just turn off the [b]RTX[/b] stuff. You won't notice a big difference in most scenarios and if there is a difference it ain't worth the fps drop (Ultra quality is enough for me).
4- Enable DLSS [b]Quality mode.[/b]
5- Enable [b]Image Sharpening[/b] from Nvidia Control Panel (Sharpen 0.20, Film grain 0.13). This fixed the blurriness for me.
Review_Angles: Technical Performance, Hardware Requirements, Graphics Optimization

review_text:
11/26/2022

Cyberpunk 2077.... What can I say    /   TLDR: The game has improved but still lacks in some areas, I would buy it, at a small discount tho.

As someone that bought the game on launch,it has gone through multiple large updates to correct the errors that the devs allowed to get through due to the Hype it created since its announcement and probably pressure from investors.

From a story perspective It has rich lore, if you take the time to read through the MRAM's that you'll find through the world.
Every since the EdgeRunnerss Update the lore has expanded even further (to even include references from the anime adaptation that Netflix created). 

World setting somewhat fits the Cyberpunk style. What I mean is that yes there is a dystopian world ruled by corrupt governments, Corporations that hold the power and lawless areas in the city ruled by the strongest gangs. But the way is put forward it makes it sound as if Night City is the only place in this fictional America that has the level of issues and corruption. Now that might change with the Phantom Liberty Update but until then this is my opinion.

Visuals are good but disappointing , unless mods are used Night City doesn't really reflect that Cyberpunk feeling, while day time is hardly used in Cybepunk visuals which make it hard to get that dystopian feeling, night time feels lacking, hardly any bright lights and heavy populations in the central area of the city, the rain feels poorly implemented and the ambiance, the feeling of dystopian future isn't really felt.
So I feel while some wish this could be reworked I hardly doubt it would happen, as it would require changing the Visuals completely. Thank God for the Modding community I'm I right?

Gameplay, while I want to like it, it feels so limiting.The AI is atrocious, yes reworks have been done to the AI but it still feels like I'm play CS:Source bots on easy mode. There isn't that feeling that I'm going against dangerous party or faction but rather a clumsy lot of bots that know how to shot or swing a katana. Even with that issue I would be fine if at least the player side movement and melee was decent, why is it that even though I'm Chromed up the ASS in upgrades but I still swing a katana like a 5 year old in a pewee baseball club, I feel like combat movement and gameplay should have been focused on more than ever. We all know we want to be that badass Assassin wielding a pistol and katana at the same time DAMIT!

Overall the game is passable, at a discount though. While the devs are making updates and changes to the game that was something they already promised before the fiasco release they had. The only reason the player count is higher than expected is because they made the right moves in the marketing department post-release by creating an anime which hit a different demographic that didn't even know the game existed, which simultaneously released the EdgeRunners update which fixed majority of the issues that Plagued the game upon release. 

Cyberpunk 2077 and its lore has so much potential but unfortunately it was cursed with the hype beast that can break or make a game. I would recommend this game still but at a small discount price $60 dollars isn't something I would pay for it now, so get it while on sale.
Review_Angles: Consumer Value, Technical Stability, Narrative Depth

review_text:
[h1]Cyberpunk 2077 Is My Second Life[/h1] 

Hello, hello! I'm Arif Iqbal.

I have spent a significant portion (an inordinate amount) of my real life in [b]Night City[/b] as [b]V[/b] and [b]Johnny Silverhand[/b]. At this moment, I've got Steam registering up to [i]644[/i] hours of play time. That is [i]26 days straight[/i] (if you do pedestrian maths and only divide by 24 hours). Almost a month logged into this CDPR created world! But that isn't the correct metric to use. We need to factor in sleep and other daily rituals & responsibilities (let us say... 8 hrs a piece). So, accounting for 16 hours of each day relegated to those human necessities, and dividing 644 hours by 8 hours, we come to a whopping [i]80.5 days![/i] We are pushing 3 months here! [i]That is a quarter of a year here on earth.[/i] And I can honestly say I'm a better person for it.

Why? Because Cyberpunk 2077 is a great game despite its many, many flaws. I've learned a ton about the solo mercenary life, developed my narrow decision making skills, and how to handle different sociopathic personalities. I've kept my hand and eye coordination strong, and my reaction times quick. That is what's really important here.

I mean, who cares that I've neglected my family and friends, physical fitness, diet, and spirituality? Or that I am unemployed, lost my girlfriend of 8 years, and am basically homeless (but not really... Thanks Mom!)? Not me. Instead I've got sweet, sweet V and her glistening 6 pack abs, thunder thighs, and big booty (thank you Spawn0 mods!!!). I've got Legendary guns of all types, sizes, and calibres! I've got razor sharp, designer katanas! I've got countless clothing items, accessories, designer drugs (oh, wait! they removed them, thanks 1.5 patch), and fast-as-fack cars! And last but not least, I've got countless game mods.

I think the plethora of available PC mods for this game are another great reason I've been able to spend so much time in this fictional world (other than the glaringly obvious fact that I'm using it as an escape from my real world and all its problems). There are many mods to correct the annoying and downright dumb issues that CDPR managed to incorporate into their [i]"finished"[/i] product. Everything from the incredibly important Underwear Remover mod to the [i]nice-to-have[/i] Vehicle Combat, Flashlight, and Car Modification mods. Or maybe that's backwards? Either way, the mods for Cyberpunk 2077 make the game a genuinely enjoyable experience instead of a frustrating slog-fest.

I recommend adding as many mods as you can actually. Obviously CDPR won't do it. I know, I know! What about the 1.5 patch?!? Well, it did fix some of the glaring issues with the game and added a few little bits, but at the same time it went and fucked up all my mods. I had to wait a few days for Cyber Engine Tweaks. And I'm still waiting for the Full Game Rebalance to be updated post 1.5 patch (c'mon Scissors!). I already said I don't have a real life outside of Night City.

But honestly, the game is great. It has an incredible story that is immersive, engaging, and coherent. The voice acting and character visuals are beautiful  and intriguing. I really enjoy customizing V's appearance and perfecting every detail. Also, I didn't realize until now how much I enjoy women's clothes. I mean, you're not gonna catch me on Grindr wearing my ex's panties or anyting [unless you're in my area ;) ], but I have grown an appreciation for garment fit, color matching, and accessories of the female variety. Much like dressing up a Barbie doll I'd think.

Back to the game...So, Night City is gorgeous and huge with many interesting sites to explore, hundreds of Easter Eggs to find, and more than enough Gigs and NCPD scanner hustles to complete. Also, side missions-a-plenty. And despite the silly vehicle traffic, annoying pedestrian behavior, overcrowding of NPC's causing PC performance lag and FPS drop, as well as Playstaion 2-ish distant vehicle animations, the map and most things in it are still great. Again, get those mods! Almost all of these issues have a mod to fix it or make it better. I'd buy that for a dollar!

Wait! There's more! While playing there have been many times where I found a rare Easter Egg or discovered a hidden mystery in-game and wanted to share it with real world people. So, I'll immediately jump on Brave Search or Reddit to see if anyone else has found what I found. And usually, of course they have. But, I've put so much time and OCD level effort into experiencing just about every facet that this game has to offer that there have been a few Easter Eggs or mysteries I've found that only have one mention of it online. But that is the fun of it. Like being an explorer. An explorer with a crippling case of OCD and addiction unfortunately. All the same, check out r/FF06B5 for plenty of Cyberpunk 2077 mysteries.

I could probably write a novel on this game (Maybe I should, actually?). But this review has gone on long enough. Much like my most recent game play through. And I need to play through another ending option (and possibly a hidden one? I don't remember how many there actually are). I won't spoil anything but I found one of them to be highly fun and entertaining. Most of the others are just sad (crying face). 

Alright, that's it for this review. If you haven't played this game yet, then shame on you. It is worth it. Not the greatest game ever, but it could have been. And with the right mods and future updates it may get close. You'll be playing a piece of history right here and that is what is important. We won't see a Game of the Year edition but CDPR has promised to right its wrongs and remain dedicated to patching the issues and providing some minor content additions (definitely not any DLC content, however, no matter how many times CDPR uses the term to denote two pieces of clothing additions to the game). 

This has been you're man, Stan! Join me for another day in our City of Dreams!!!
